“Now father, please tell us what has happened.” Tenmar dragged his hands over his face trying to wipe away his scattered thoughts and regain his composure. One final deep breath, his biggest yet, brought him almost completely to himself again.

“It’s the waterfall.” He opened his mouth to continue but must of thought better of what he was about to say for he immediately closed it again. Daniel and Isabelle looked at each other in bewilderment; while Aurora experienced a flicker of fear.

“It would be better if I showed you.” And with that Tenmar gestured for them to follow him out the front door. They had no choice, so they followed him in silence out the door and to the water’s edge where a bridge of lily pads had only minutes ago led Isabelle through the waterfall. No sign of that bridge now remained.

Throughout the village they could see people running about urgently gathering up children and animals and packing anything they could get their hands on much like Tenmar had begun to do back at his house. However, just as many were standing at the shore staring at the waterfall in shock. Daniel saw that same shocked expression on Aurora’s face. He could even see a glimmer of shock on Isabelle’s face, though not nearly as profound. Clearing something had changed for them, but all he saw was a modest looking waterfall.

Isabelle, on the other hand, knew that something about the waterfall wasn’t quite right, even if you couldn’t put her finger on it. It seemed to have lost some of its magnificence. It did not spray as much glistening mist into the air. It did not roar as loud as the water cascaded down from its heights. It did not shine with the same ethereal luminescence as it had before.

“How can this be possible?” Aurora asked, her voice hardly about a whisper. “It is too soon.”

“I know child. Never the less we must prepare. We haven’t a second to spare.” Without another word Tenmar turned on his heel and headed home, intent written in his every move to complete the job he had begun of packing up his life. Arurora glanced once more at the waterfall, heaved a sigh, and followed her father. No closer to understanding the cloud of impending doom falling on the town, Daniel and Isabelle did the only thing they could and fell in step behind Aurora. They walking in silence all the way back tot eh house where they found Tenmar already at work packing. Aurora moved to help him.

“Pardon me, but what exactly has happened?” Daniel asked unable to stay in the dark any longer. Tenmar ignored the question as he continued shoving clothes into a bag. Aurora gesture them into a couple of chairs at the other end of the room.

“I’m sorry, I’ll have to keep this short; we don’t have as much time as we previously thought. Basically, the waterfall is dying.” Daniel opened his mouth to ask what that meant, but Aurora raised her hand to indicate she would answer his question if he would only wait and continued, “As you’ve seen Daniel, water here isn’t always simply water. That waterfall was imbued with powerful magic a long time ago, long before I was born. It not only shields us from the outside world, but it is also the only means we have of escaping this world into another realm should the situation become too dire for us here. We should have had many more years, plenty of time for us all the eventually leave when we were ready or to find a way of saving this world. But tonight it is clear that in no time at all the water will stop flowing, and with it our chance of escape and our greatest protection. We will become painfully vulnerable.” It was a lot of absorb, for all of them. Aurora had never fully reconciled herself to the idea of leaving this world, and now the moment had jumped up out of nowhere and grabbed hold of her. She had to leave – soon – probably before this night was over or else lose the chance forever. There just wasn’t enough time to wrap her mind around the idea. Daniel was likewise having trouble wrapping his mind around the idea that a waterfall could be so important and that it could so suddenly, simply die.

There was one idea, however, that Isabelle’s mind could not let go of until she gave voice to it, “But the waterfall was just fine a few minutes ago when I went through it and talked to Zarion.”

In the kitchen Tenmar dropped a wooden bowl he was about to pack. It spun around like a top on the floor. Tenmar left it there completely forgotten as he stepped out of the kitchen and marched into the main room, his eyes glued to Isabelle. “What did you just say?”
1111121111111122111211112.title: The Waterfall

11111211111111221112111121.content:
The sound of the bowl clattering to the floor had jerked the three from their thoughts. Tenmar’s reaction further unnerved them. Daniel and Isabelle had risen from the seats when Tenmar marched into the room. Barely two feet from Isabelle, Tenmar stared hard into her face. She was more than a little scared. What had she done to provoke him like this? Even Aurora could not remember the last time she had seen her father in such a state. He did not appear angry or violent in any way, but there was a quiet authority surging just behind his eyes.

In a quiet voice Isabelle tried to respond, “I said that the waterfall looked fine when I went through it a few minutes ago and…”

“And? And what?” Tenmar prompted when her voice trailed off.

“And I spoke with Zarion,” Isabelle managed to finish.

Tenmar looked thunderstruck. He took a step back shaking his head before falling into one of the chairs and gesturing to the kids to do the same. Aurora and Isabelle took their seats, but Daniel instead chose a standing position right beside the latter’s chair.

“That is not a name I thought I’d hear again, especially not from one ignorant of our people.” Tenmar shook his head again. His expression softened, he turned to Isabelle and asked, “You are sure you spoke to ‘Zarion’?”

Isabelle nodded her assent. “In fact he gave me this bag and everything in it,” she added, indicating the sack at her feet.

The atmosphere of the room finally calmed, the air no longer suffocatingly thick with tension. For a few moments everything remained still – just breathing.

“What was he like?” Tenmar asked of Isabelle, all thoughts of packing washed away as footprints are by the tide.

“Wait, wait. Who is this Zarion?” Daniel interjected before Isabelle could answer. Aurora, also in the dark about the identity of this man whose mere name could inspire such awe in her father, sat up straightened in her chair poised to hear every word.
11111211111111221112111121.title: Who is this Zarion?

111112111111112211121111212.content:
“Apologies, of course the name must mean nothing to any of you,” Tenmar began. “I do no believe even you Aurora would recognize that particular name. For many years now he has been known by another. Let me begin by saying that what you have seen of our people and of those rare creatures that live within the boundaries of our lands is but a shadow of what once was. In the days of magic long since passed, our clan was called the Nikken. Our people could not only bend water to our will, but they could themselves become water. This gave them a unique connection with nature, as water flows through all things living.

“However, as will happen, there were those who sought to use the abilities of the Nykken and others touched by magic for their own purposes. None were immune to the temptation of quick and easy personal gain. Many of species of animals with magical properties were hunted to extinction as people sought to harvest them for their magic. What you have seen here are some of the only ones lefts. The people of the Nykken and other magical clans were also sought out for their abilities. Some desired to buy their services, but some were willing to use force to gain the benefits of magic. Luckily there were those with the wisdom and strength to fight the temptation whenever and wherever they could. They managed to keep the worst from coming to pass long enough for things to change. By this I do not mean that avarice was exorcised from the hearts of men, instead the weapon of that avarice was blunted. Magic began to fade from the world.

“No one knows what cause the Decline. Some say that magical bloodlines were diluted by unions between clans, both magical and human. Others say that the source of magic, the world’s soul, was corrupted by the exploitation of magic. Whatever the case, those born with the gift were less powerful and less numerous than those who had come before. The Nykken retain their ability to manipulate water, albeit to a lesser extent, but they lost the ability to transform their own shape into water.

“It was during this Decline of Magic when the prophecy was made about the rise of a powerful and evil magic in the distant future. The elders of what remained of the magical clans feared that if magic continued to fade as it was, then there would be none left to combat this evil. So they began gathering precious magicks to be hidden away and hopefully protected from the Decline until such time as they were needed. They worked tirelessly to gather all remaining powerful magicks they could find and to find a way to place all the necessary spells and charms needed to keep the cache magically sealed and undisturbed indefinitely. Most spells dissipate once their casters die, but the elders must have found a way around this. They labored the rest of their lives to make this happen, and their children spent most of their lives finishing the task.

“Generations after the Treasure of Higani, as it had come to be called, named after the man who had foretold of the coming doom, had been safely sealed away, a child was born. His mother came from the Nykken, while his father was human. They named him Zarion. And he was no ordinary child By no means was he the first child born of parents from different clans; at that point clan names were rarely ever mentioned. Direct ties to specific clans were often tenuous and at times only symbolic. They could be used to trace family lineages for those who wished to learn about distant ancestors. Or they could be used to identify a type of magical ability, but with magic in decline and seen as something to be exploited, it became pointless and/or dangerous to be identified with any magical clan.

“What set Zarion apart was that even at t young age his abilities were stronger than others his age, and he demonstrated a greater control of those abilities. As he grew, so too did his powers, until one day in his teens it was discovered he could transfigure his body into water. Generations had passed since the last person known to have possessed this power, and she only ever used it a handful of times in her life, for each time she did it used so much of her strength that it took weeks for her to recover. And here was a boy to whom the transformation came as naturally as breathing, just as it had for the elders long before the Decline. People believed – or they hoped – this was a sign of the rebirth of magic into the world. But as the years passed, no children were born with powers comparable to Zarion. Child were still being born with magic, but their abilities remained ever declining remnants of what they once were.

“When people finally gave up hope and recognized that magic continued to fade unabated, some become even more desperate to exploit those with magic. They felt it was their last chance before magic disappeared entirely. Many sought out Zarion; they pleaded, they bribed, they threatened, they tired everything to usurp his powers for their own aims. However, not only could Zarion use his power to hide himself form the desperate people, he also possessed an inspiring strength and purity of heart and mind which guided him down a path where he never let his power be abused for selfish reason, not even his own. Cut off from Zarion’s powers, focus turned toward anyone else with a talent for magic. Even those born without any recognizable magical qualities were not safe if it was known they were descended from one of the magical clans. Many tried desperately to hide the fact that countless generations ago they had a family member with a hint of magic. Others left everything behind and went into hiding. An unlucky few were caused untold physical and mental anguish when they were punished for not being able to perform the feats demanded of them. And then there were the charlatans selling potions to cure this and that, trinkets to ward off evil or to attract good fortune, and spells to ignite love or to punish enemies; charlatans who only fueled the flames of desire of real magic.

“Finally Zarion could no longer bear to see such suffering. So he gathered those who wanted to live peaceful and quiet lives safe from exploitation here at this lake. He cast a spell that would hide the village from the outside world. We cannot be detected by magical or nonmagical means. Strangers can neither stumble upon us on accident nor seek us out with greed in their hearts. Only those with pure intentions can find us. Such was the way of Zarion. Power is meant to protect life, not to control it.

“People from all clans gathered here to live safe and harmonious lives with others who have shared their pain, though even to this day we fear we will be discovered and once again made prey to man’s depravities, which is why we continue to train in the ways of combat. But in the years after Zarion established Te’alom the people here lived happy, unmolested lives and the outside world returned to normal mostly forgetting about magic.

“Though most of the world had forgotten about us, at the end of his life Zarion wanted to make sure we would continue to be protected even after he was gone. So Zarion climbed to the crest of the waterfall, which at the time was but a piddling stream, and he gave all that he had left. He transformed himself into water and gave every drop of his remaining life force to the waterfall. His very essence flows throughout the waterfall and lake. As long as that waterfall flows, his spells live on. One spell keeps us hidden, even from the arts of Radigan. Another spell opens a doorway through the waterfall to another realm where several villagers have already journeyed to prepare the way for the rest of us. Both spells are far beyond our ability to conjure. His incredible abilities and the wisdom with which he used those powers has earned him a title once reserved only for the counsel of elders who united and guided all magical clans in the long ago. A title by which he is still known today while his birth name has been all but forgotten. He is known as the Nyx.”
111112111111112211121111212.title: The Nyx

choices: They have news of the princess
1111121111111122111211112122.content:
Isabelle could scarcely believe there was so much she did not know about her own kingdom. Her tutors certainly never told her anything like this. As a child she had once delighted in witnessing the fantastical presentations of travelling magicians, but for years she had been old enough to know what these were mere legerdemain, clever tricks to deceive the senses. It was color entertainment, nothing more. But just imagine, magic – real magic – had not only existed but had once thrived in these lands, and if they succeeded perhaps it could again.

“I had always thought of the Nyx as some incredible character of legend,” Aurora mused. “He was so powerful and did so much, he felt little more than a myth. I knew he had once been flesh and blood, but I never considered who he was as a person or what kind of life he had led before he gave himself to the waterfall. And to think you actually met him Isabelle.” Aurora’s eyes refocused as she lifted them from the floor to gaze at Isabelle as if reappraising her in a new light.

This was all too much for Daniel to fully process. It went against so much of what he believed the world to be. He wanted to confront this new version of the world, but he didn’t know how. First he had to let everything sink in. Once he could examine everything he had heard he’d know where to begin. So Daniel kept his mouth shut and his mind open. He was particularly interested in hearing what Isabelle had to say about meeting this so called Nyx. It sounded like yet another unbelievable tale, and yet there was something about that name – the Nyx – that ticked at the back of his mind buried somewhere deep beneath all this information – the old as well as the new.

For a few moments Isabelle closed her eyes, focusing solely on the sensation of her breathing. Feeling her lungs expand and contract as she breathed in the fresh air. Isabelle summoned up the final reserves of her energy. Dawn had come and gone as they listened to the story of how young Zarion became the Nyx. After leaving Melish in the woods yesterday morning she had fought brigands, entered a world beyond a waterfall, spoken with a legend, heard a tale which strained her imagination, and slept not a wink. But she could not sleep yet; first she must repay a story with a story. So she opened her eyes, and, beginning with the voice whispering her name and the formation of the bridge of leaves, Isabelle told of her encounter with Zarion the Nyx, while three sets of ears eagerly listened to her tale, enraptured.

~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~


At the same time five knights attempted pursuit of the wayward princess and stableboy.

“This simply is not possible.”

“What is it Andrew?” asked the second of the three knights trudging through the Dracoon forest.

The third knight jumped out of the brush onto the hard packed dirt, cheering, “Hallelujah. Look Bernard, an actual path!”

Crouching by the path, examining the tracks in the dirt, Andrew felt like doing anything but cheering. “This path should not be here.”

“No more bugs and mud in my boots, the third continued to cheer as he found a tree stump by the edge of the path to sit on while he shook said bugs and dirt from first one boot then the other. “No more branches swinging out of nowhere to strike me in my face. No more roots rising from the group to trip my feet. No more – ”

“Jonothan, enough,” Bernard demanded. Though still smiling, Jonothan kept quiet. Returning his attention to Andrew, Bernard asked, “What is wrong with this path?”

“It should not be here,” Andrew reiterated. They had been forced to abandon their horses where they came upon a section of the road which had been damaged by a rockslide. The horses could not safely cross the debris and that particular part of the forest terrain was too dense and hazardous for the horses. They were branded with the royal seal and the knights had no doubt they would quickly be found and returned to the castle. The three knights had cautiously gone around the debris on foot and continued journeying on the main road until they were attacked by wild dogs, forcing them into the woods. They escaped the dogs and immediately retraced their steps but were unable to find the path. Orienting himself based on the moss growing on the trees and other nature landmarks he had learned over the course of a lifetime spent developing a thorough understanding of the land, Andrew had pointed them in the direction they needed to travel: east. They bedded down that night somewhere in the woods. They spent several hours hiking and being driven off course by animal attacks the next day before eventually coming to the river that flowed from one end of the forest to the other, they followed its path believing it would soon guide them to out of the forest. But night fell and once again they were diverted from their course when attacked by other forest predators. Once again, however minutely they tried to retrace their steps, they could not return to the river. They lost the river, but had somehow stumbled upon this path. “The river only comes close to one forest path: the main road, and they only approach each other in one area of the forest. The river takes a more direct route through the forest, but it so passes through some of the more dangerous parts of the forest which the established paths all try to avoid.”

“Perhaps this is merely an animal poor or migratory path. Or it could be a path newly formed since last you visited these woods,” Bernard suggested, hoping the answer could be so simple. The truth is he hadn’t felt right in these woods, as if a cold breath had been working its way up his spine which he now felt clearly on the back of his neck.

“You don’t understand,” Andrew insisted. “Despite being diverted by those animal attacks, I have kept us moving in a more or less easterly direction towards the opposite end of the woods from where we entered. Look around, doesn’t this look familiar?” Bernard and Jonothan looked around. They couldn’t be sure if it did indeed look familiar or if they were just incapable of telling one tree apart from any other tree. Few people had spent as much time studying the natural landscape of the of the kingdom as Andrew; Bernard and Jonothan did not count among them.

“This is the main road we left yesterday. At this precise spot. This is where we were chased off by those dogs. These are our footprints leaving and road and running into the woods. Either I have gotten lost for perhaps the first time in my life, or something unnatural in this forest has led us back here.” Looking at each other, Andrew and Bernard were at a loss. Neither man suspicious by nature, but both men had learned to trust their instincts, instincts that now told them something was wrong and this forest was not what it seems.

Ever one to jump feet first without thinking, Jonothan chimed in with a comment he thought sure to break the tension with a laugh or a smile at least, “Maybe it was Melish.”

“Don’t be s – ” Bernard began to say only to be quickly shushed by Andrew. With one hand raised warning Bernard and Jonothan to remain still and quiet, Andrew’s other hand gestured to the woods directly opposite. Thus on alert, they immediately identified what had drawn Andrew’s attention: at distinct rustling of the underbrush suggesting movement of a living creature or creatures, the volume of which indicated something fairly sizable. As the sound neared, the three knights readied themselves not looking forward to yet another animal attack. They placed hands on the hilts of their swords, silently freeing them from their scabbards, and adjusted their positions, prepared to either fight or flee the moment they ascertained the nature of the unknown danger before them. Tensed for action they watched as two figures leaped from behind the cover of the trees.

At first the glint of sunlight off of scabbards alarmed the three knights, but those fears were quickly allayed when they recognized the faces of two comrades.

“Thomas, Donovan,” Bernard began to greet his fellow knights only to be interrupted by a call of “to arms” from the former. As one all five knights drew their swords and faced the woods from whence Thomas and Donovan had emerged. They listened. Indeed there was again the sound of rustling in the underbrush before them. Though lighter than the recent sounds of the knights’ boots, it was unmistakably the sound of something alive moving just beyond their view. However, the sound was moving neither toward nor away from them. Instead it seemed to be pacing. So they waited with drawn swords for the creature to decide its next move. After a time the decision was made clear when the noise began to fade as the animal drifted away and the men heard the frustrated howl of a wild animal denied its prey. Evidently, while confronting two men amounted to sport, facing five armed men proved too great a risk for the animal. The threat gone, swords were sheathed and greetings were resumed.

“You are well met gentlemen,” greeted one of the two newcomers. “He had been harried by those beasts most of the night.”

“It is good to see you Thomas,” Bernard replied. “You as well Donovan,” he greeted the second. “But when we parted at the fork I did not expect to see you so soon. Have you some news of the Princess?”
1111121111111122111211112122.title: While Isabelle tells her tale

choices: Story returns to Isabelle, Daniel, and Aurora
Check in on the King and Queen
11111211111111221112111121221.content:
“Indeed we do. The day after we parted we reached a small village where, after questioning several villagers who had seen nothing of the princess or her faithful stable boy, we encountered an old woman who had. She described the children so precisely she must have seen them. According to this woman they entered these woods shortly before dark the first day of their absence.

“We immediately turned around and returned to the fork. There we discovered your horses and the note saying you continued on foot. Hoping to catch up to you quickly we hastened our pace and chose to press on when it grew dark. Like you we abandoned our horses at the rockslide, but as soon as we left the road we were attacked by wild dogs. Besieged and lost ever since, this is the first time we’ve managed to find the road again,” Thomas explained.

“Don’t look at me,” Donovan insisted with his hands raised palms forward before him. “It is not my fault we got lost. We all know Andrew is the tracker of the group.”

“That is true,” Thomas agreed, “How comes it that you three are still in these woods? If I am correct this road shouldn’t take more than a day, even on foot, to traverse. It’s now been nearly two since you began.”

Attempting to hide his chagrin, Andrew defended himself by ominously stating, “There are forces at work in these woods which defy nature.”

“I cannot speak for the unnatural forces, but the natural ones have definitely led us astray,” Bernard offered in conciliatory tones. “We have, like you, been attacked on numerous occasions by the predators of the forest. So unpredictable have been their attacks, it has been difficult to gain our bearings. It seems they have been leading us in circles for the better part of a day.”

“I told you Bernard,” Andrew insisted, “even with the constant animal attacks, I would know if we were travelling in circles. We may have returned to where we began, but I guarantee we have been travelling steadily east since leaving this road from this spot.”

Donovan did not attempt to hide his mirth. “Finally, the great tracker Andrew has gotten lost,” he laughed.

Ignoring Donovan’s pointed beaming, Bernard addressed his concerns to Thomas, “Whether we got lost or not, I have not felt at ease in these woods since we were forced to abandon our horses. If I were a more superstitious man I might accept Jonothan’s suggestion that we are being led astray by Melish himself.”

“Who?”

Jonothan replied, “The keeper of the forest, or so the legend goes.”

“I thought the Lady Dracoon was supposed to be the keeper. It is called the Dracoon Forest, is it not?”

“The woods are named for the Lady,” continued Jonothan, who always enjoyed telling a good story, “but it is said that when Melish was cursed to the shadows, she named him keeper of her woods, giving him dominion over all within the forest boundaries. She may even have blessed him with the use of magic.”

“Why was he cursed?” Donovan asked, intrigued.

“I’m not sure anyone really knows. Except of course for Melish and whoever conjured the curse. All I know is that supposedly even the Lady Dracoon hasn’t been able to lift it. Now he spends his time living in harmony with nature; protecting travellers from the animals, and protecting the animals from hunters. Usually he guides lost travellers out of the forest. But I’ve never heard of him trapping them inside. Perhaps we have done something to displease him.”

The others were engrossed in the tale, almost believing, but Thomas had heard enough. “Enough of these silly legends, we have a job to do. Let’s focus on what is real and in front of us.

“Do not be so quick to disregard ‘silly legends’,” Bernard advised. “Legends may be intangible, exaggerated stories from our past, but every legend is a great tree frown from a very real seed of truth.”

“And watered by the faith of gullible fools,” Thomas countered. “They are meaningless stories.”

Do not underestimate the power of story,” persisted Bernard. “Sometimes it is all we have.”

“If you say so.” Trying to put an end to the discussion, Thomas began walking down the path joking over his shoulder, “Now can we get back to work before the imaginary cursed man from Jonothan’s fairytale arrives to whisk us away to the bottom of the lake or up into the clouds to a birthday party for Father Time where – ”

His diatribe was cut off by a resounding crack echoed by a splintering of wood and rounded off with a deafening crash as an ancient and enormous tree fell across the path immediately before Thomas forcing him to leap back several feet or else be crushed.

~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~


“That was awfully close wasn’t it my dear Melish?” her melodious voice asked as a woman appeared by Melish’s side hidden in the shadows of the trees.

There was a noticeable jerk of Melish’s body as the Lady Dracoon’s disembodied voice preceded the appearance of her body. “M’lady, I would never have allowed the tree to harm him, in accordance with your wishes, but he could do with a splinter or two.”

Lady Dracoon smiled as she wrapped her arm in Melish’s. “Sir Thomas is a brave man, but much of that courage comes from his faith in his ability to control his own destiny. He is not ready to accept the existence of those of us so far beyond his control. Have you enjoyed toying with them?”

“It has given me an opportunity to learn more about the character of each man. I can see why King Edward would trust his daughter’s safety to them. If what I have heard whispered on the wind is true, she will need their help.”

“Yes she will,” the Lady conferment, clasping Melish’s hand in her own,” but not yet. Keep in the woods overnight. Let them continue on their way in the morning. One more day head start will give the children the time to get to where they need to be unhindered without getting too far away from the aid of the knights.”

“As you wish M’lady.”

“And Melish.” She hesitated and looked into his eyes. “If events unfold as we would wish, it will bring us a step closer to freeing you as I promised.” After briefly squeezing his hand, the Lady Dracoon vanished as quickly as she had appeared, leaving Melish to return his attention to the five formidable knights.
11111211111111221112111121221.title: Comrades reunited

Stay a bit longer w/ other characters: king/queen, knights, Melish, Radigan, etc
111112111111112211121111212212.content:
Distraught, the queen sat on a chaise lounge in the sitting room of their private suite of rooms. The king paced the room, caught between his own distress and his desire to comfort his wife.

“It has been two days, Edward. Where is she?” Queen Jasmine demanded.

“I don’t know, my dear. They can’t have gotten far. The knights will find her and bring her home,” King Edward insisted, kneeling before his wife and covering her hands in his.

“I should have known better, that she wasn’t ready for marriage,” she chastised herself as fresh tears began to fall from her bloodstained eyes. “I knew she wouldn’t have been happy with the idea of getting married so soon, but I never thought she’d run away.”

“Don’t say that Jasmine,” Edward consoled, gently wiping the tears from her cheeks. “We couldn’t have known she would overhear our conversation. Nothing had even been decided yet. We were just talking. She knows we would not force her. That we only want what is best.”

“Does she? Does she really? Oh Edward, if anything were to happen to her…” Unable to finish the thought, Jasmine attempted to choke back a sob.

“Do not think such thoughts. Of course Isabelle knows we love her. And weren’t you the one telling me what a responsible young man that Daniel is. Surely he is looking after her. And if the knights have not yet found her, they will soon.” It was hard for Edward to see the woman he loved like this. His own eyes began to mist; he fought the tears, fought to stay strong as a husband, as a father, as a king. But the idea that something could happen to his daughter nearly broke him.

“But why haven’t we heard anything? Maybe we should send out more knights,” the queen begged. At that moment was a mother first and queen second. For a queen must not beg, but, for the sake of a child, a mother will do anything.

“We must be patient. Of all our knights, I have sent the very greatest.” He knew this was true. There were perhaps none other to whom he would trust the life of his daughter. And yet, no matter what precautions taken, what parent ever feels they have done enough to protect their child? Especially now that reports had reached the castle that Radigan’s forces were approaching his kingdom’s border. Even if he felt these five knights might fail, he could not spare another man. They all needed to prepare for war.
111112111111112211121111212212.title: Concerned Parents

1111121111111122111211112122121.content:
"What do you mean you aren't coming with us?!" Aurora's father shouted.
"I mean what I said father. Our people have fled and hidden from Radigan for too long. Even if we leave now and he succeeds in finding the treasure, nowhere we go will be safe," Aurora firmly replied.
"Sir, Zarion also spoke of another prophecy. This lesser known one foretells of 4 young adults who would find the treasure and then together defeat the great evil. Zarion thinks that I am one of those four, and I would guess that Daniel and Aurora are two of the others." Isabella explained.
Tenmar paused from his packing, seemed to consider Isabella's words. Finally he spoke,"Aurora , you realize that after the portal closes there will be no way to escape or for me to return?"
"Yes father, I know."
"There might be something in the treasure that could open another portal." Daniel added.
1111121111111122111211112122121.title: Story returns to Isabelle, Daniel, and Aurora

choices: At the same time with the knights
11111211111111221112111121221211.content:
After helping Tenmar pack the few things he planned on bringing through the portal, Daniel and Isabella quietly followed behind Aurora and her father. No one spoke on their walk down to the lakeside. Isabella had a feeling that Aurora, while still determined to stay and help, was starting to realize just what staying meant. Her father on the other hand was proud of his daughter and her will to stay and fight Radigan. He would have stayed himself, but because he was to take over as elder, he knew that the village would need him more than ever on the other side. As they reached the lake front they saw several of the other townspeople gathered around the lake. They had already finished packing and were waiting for the Elder to open the portal. Daniel and Isabella looked around and saw an older man approach the water. When he reached the edge he stopped and knelt to touch the water. As he did so, he muttered something, than backed away. Isabella watched as for the second time that night, all the plant life gathered together to form a walkway. Daniel stood awestruck, as this was his first time seeing this and magic still fascinated him. As soon as the path was completed people began moving across it and into the waterfall. Tenmar told them to wait there for a bit as he went to speak to the elder. When he returned the elder was with him.
"So Princess Isabella, I hear that you had the honor of speaking with the Nyx."
"Yes sir, he told me of the treasure my friend and I are after, as well as some of the prophecies behind it."
He then walk over to Aurora and asked "What is this about you wanting to stay behind?"
"I am tired of our people running from Radigan, sir. Someone is finally standing up against him, and I want to help them."
"You always were a strong willed one, I wish you luck on your journey."
"And you must be Daniel. I do hope you have learned not to laugh at magic," the old man said with a grin. Embarrassed, Daniel replied that he had. After the elder had spoken to Aurora her father had taken her closer to the water to speak to her alone. While they were talking, the elder turned to Daniel and Isabella with a stern look on his face. "I know that Aurora won't be dissuaded from helping, so I want you to both promise me to watch after my grand-daughter."
Shocked, Isabella and Daniel gave him their word to do so and turned back to a softly crying Aurora.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
"What is it father, what did you want to say?" Aurora asked.
Her father had turned and knelt in front of her, "You still have time to come with us. I understand why you want to stay, but as my daughter I will miss you."
"Father, I will miss you too, but I feel that my place is here."
"If that is how you feel, than I want you to have this."
As he said this, he reached around his neck and removed a silver chain necklace with a blue gem that almost seemed to glow.
As he took it off,Aurora gasped, before saying,"I cannot take mothers necklace."
"Yes you can," her father replied,"because she had told me to give it to you when you were older. I know I may not act like it sometimes, but I am very proud of you and I know she would be too."
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
By that time most of the villagers had made their way through the waterfall and there was a bright pulse that emanated from it. Turning to it the Elder and Tenmar walked along it. Before they passed through it, they turned and shouted to the three,"Good luck, help yourself to whatever you need in the village, and be sure to check in my cabin. Though I would hurry and move on before morning comes."
"Before they went through, Aurora quickly shouted,"I love you father and grandpapa."
As they walked through they returned the sentiments, and there was a blinding flash.
11111211111111221112111121221211.title: On the lakefront

111112111111112211121111212212111.content:
At the same time, the silence on the path leading out of the Dracoon forest was broken by the rustling of bushes, then by Jonothan jumping out into the open, and shouting, "Oh sweet sunlight how I have missed you."
"Jonothan quit being so over dramatic, we've been in pitch black caves for longer times."Thomas shouted from the brush, as he and the others emerged.
"I'm just glad to be out of there," Bernard said.
"Yes, it took us far longer to get through there then I anticipated." Donovan said.
Just as Donovan finished speaking, there was a flash of light coming from the forest down the path. This drew all of the knights attention from what they had been doing.
As usual, Jonothan was the first to speak up, shouting." What was that!"
Bernard was the first to reply,saying" In all of my travels I have never seen anything like that."
After he spoke all of the knights stopped to see if anything else would happen. While they stood still, they each felt something shift in the air.
"Did you feel that?",Thomas asked the group.
"It felt like some kind of breeze blew past." Donovan said.
"That wasn't any kind of breeze I'm familiar with. It wasn't the air moving, but something else." Bernard said.
"Whatever it was we need to keep moving, we lost to much time in that blasted forest." Andrew said, snapping the others out of their wonder.
Thomas stood up and said,"He's right, we'll have plenty of time to talk about this later. Now we just need to move."
They had not made it much farther when they stopped again, this time to inspect several bodies they saw on the road.
As they search the bodies, Donovan called Bernard over and asked him,"Have you seen this emblem before?"
"Indeed I have. This is the emblem that slavers from the south use. Though they almost never come this way."
"Men, I fear you all have seen this emblem." Thomas said gravely as he held up a piece of cloth bearing their kingdoms seal."Andrew see which way the Princess might have gone."
It didn't take long for Andrew to find a path of disturbed brush to indicate which way they had gone. Donovan pointed out that this is the direction they had seen the flash. Worried what this might mean, they entered the forest with Andrew leading the way.
111112111111112211121111212212111.title: At the same time with the knights

1111121111111122111211112122121111.content:
Back at the village Isabella, Daniel, and Aurora stood at the side of the lake, staring at where the waterfall used to be. Isabella looked over to Aurora, before asking,"Are you going to be okay?"
Aurora nodded, then quickly turned away from the lakeside and began walking to one of the villages huts. Daniel and Isabella quickly followed after her.
"We need to hurry now, Radigan will have felt that burst of magic and will definitely be curious as to what it was. I don't know what my grandfather has in his house, but it must be important. He almost never let anyone in there, even my father has only been inside it once."
Upon arriving at the hut, Aurora lightly pushed the door open. The inside of it looked like some sort of wizard's tower from different stories Isabella had been told about when she was younger. There were bottles of all sorts all over the place, and two of the walls were covered entirely by book cases. While most of the place was a mess there was one table in the center with a satchel and a book on it. Aurora walked over to it and began to read aloud a note that was next to the book.
"These should help you get along on your journey Aurora and friends. Use it wisely and make haste.
Love, your Grandfather
Also, I always knew you would do great things someday."
After she read the note and Isabella was next to her she opened the bag to reveal that it was full of gold coins. Daniel had opened up the book to reveal a map. After examining it for a moment and comparing it to their book, he came to the conclusion that it was a map of the area they were in with a red line going across. He looked on the front of the book, and saw the title embossed on the front in gold,"The Treasure of Higani".
"This should help out too." He said as Isabella and Aurora came to look at it.
Aurora pointed to a spot on the map, near the edge of the page, and said "We are about here."
Turning the page to see if the map was continued on the next page, Isabella sighed and asked,"How can it help if it doesn't show the rest of the map?"
"I don't know, but lets hold onto it anyway." Daniel replied.
1111121111111122111211112122121111.title: Back with the trio

11111211111111221112111121221211111.content:
After running to Aurora's home and packing some traveling supplies, the three were ready to leave. As they began walking through the woods, Aurora stopped and looked back. She felt a hand on her shoulder and turned back to see Daniel and Isabella looking at her.
"Don't worry I'm fine," she said as she started walking again,"we need to get away from here though."
They began to walk through the forest, with Aurora leading the way back to the path that was on the map. They walked on in silence for an hour before Daniel broke it and asked. "What are we going to do when we get back to the path?"
"According to the map in the book you were heading the right way before you came across me so I think that we should go back to that path and keep going." Aurora told them. Silence took over again as the three walked through the forest for a few more hours. Finally they broke through the tree line and began walking along the road again.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
"I don't understand why we had to go back into another forest, I mean we just got out of one that tried to keep us in it." Jonothan said.
The five of them were following Andrew as he lead them through the forest.
"At least this forest doesn't have some fairy tale to go with it." Thomas said.
"Actually while its not a legend there have been strange occurrences in this forest." Bernard said.
"Like what?" Andrew asked.
"Most of the hunters I know say that after walking through the forest long enough they end up at the same spot on the road they had left. They said that some of them have even tried to walk straight forward and the same thing happens." Jonothan said.
"So they basically get turned around?" Donovan asked.
Andrew wasn't happy to hear this and told the rest,"Don't worry we are following their path perfectly. Though it looks like they have a companion now, and that two of them are almost dragging the other."
By this time the knights were halfway to the abandoned village.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Isabella, Daniel, and Aurora found themselves in another predicament. It was almost noon now and they had covered a good distance, but they were at another fork in the road. One went east to the city of Arrya. The other went north through the plains region, before leading into the mountains bordering Radigan's realm.
"Which way do you think we should go?" Aurora asked, looking at the two paths confused.
Daniel had pulled the book out, and started flipping through the pages when he stopped and said "Amazing". Seeing the amazement on his face, Isabella asked "What is it?"
He only responded by turning the book around and holding it out to the others. Isabella and Aurora looked to see that Daniel was holding the book open to the map page, but the map had changed. It now showed the area they were in, and the path was leading to Arrya.
"And so the magic continues." Daniel said as he puts the book up and they head down the path to Aryya.
11111211111111221112111121221211111.title: They move out now.

choices: Go with Anton as he gathers some things and speaks to his uncle.
See how Zarion is holding up the knights.
111112111111112211121111212212111111.content:
It was getting dark as Isabella, Daniel, and Aurora approached the gate into Arrya. They passed through, and made their way to a nearby inn. Daniel entered to ask about some rooms, while Aurora and Isabella waited outside. While they waited Aurora spoke.
"What are you going to do if someone in this town recognizes you?"
"I don't know, but the only people who might realize its me is the baron or his family, and I plan to avoid that part of town." When she had finished speaking Daniel had returned and told them the rooms were ready. They followed him back in and turned in for the night.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
The next morning as the three ate a light breakfast in a corner of the inn, they poured over the book. The map had again changed, this time showing the layout of the city. There was no red path on the map though. Instead the entire city was covered in a shading the same color red. Daniel was the first to speak up, saying,"What does this mean? Is their a clue or something in the city?"
"Maybe what ever it is will come to us, and all we have to do is wander around the city." Aurora practically stated.
They agreed that they would need to gather some more things before they went further on their quest, so they went to the market district to purchase supplies.
Upon arriving there they found that the streets were already crowded and began making their way through the clustered streets.
Isabella was leading with Aurora following her and Daniel behind them. Isabella was carrying the bag Zarion had given her, Aurora had the coin purse, and Daniel had a back pack with the book and the things they would need to travel. As they made their way through the streets a young man bumped into Aurora and stealthily reached into her bag. He was interrupted when another hand grasped his wrist and pulled his hand out of her bag. The would be thief looked up to see Daniel looking down at him. Daniel told the thief,"What is ours stays with us." After he said this he held his hand open underneath the thief's, and giving a light squeeze coaxed him to open his hand dropping several gold coins. Daniel turned and handed them to Aurora, then turned back to the thief and said,"Don't try anything like that again." He then released him and watched as the young thief ran and disappeared into the crowd.
"Thanks for that Daniel." Aurore said as Daniel turned back to them.
"Don't worry about it. I might just be a stablehand but I know when to be on the lookout."
Isabella looked in the direction the thief had went. She then said,"We should go, just in case he doesn't listen to your warning."
With that said they continued on through the market.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
In an alley in the market place Anton sat on a ledge, confused and angry at himself for being caught,"This is the first time I've been caught." Anton hadn't been in this trade for very long, only about a year, but he was always cautious and his small stature always helped him move towards and away from intended victims. But there was something else that was bothering him. The other girl that was with them looked familiar somehow.
"Your not still hiding away in here because one person caught you, are you?" A male voice asked. Anton looked towards the street to see his uncle and mentor, Ronald walking into the alley.
"No sir, there was just something odd about one of them. The other girl looked oddly familiar."
"I wouldn't worry about it, you remember just about everything you see so you've probably seen her before, just not up close."
"I'm gonna go look for them. I'm curious now and if I see them again I might remember." Anton told his uncle, getting up.
"Are you sure that is a good idea Anton. What if one of them sees you?" Ronald asked, only slightly worried.
"You taught me well enough to know that won't happen." Anton said, before going into the street.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
The three had finished their trip to the market and were making their way back to the inn to discuss what to do next. They arrived and as they were about to enter Daniel stopped and turned around, then told Isabella and Aurora to wait and look around.
Anton was on a rooftop across the street when the three stopped and looked around. As the familiar girl turned and he saw her face clearly he immediately remembered from where he had seen her.
Isabella stopped and looked around, and then looked up only to see someone ducking down out of sight on the roof. She whispered to Daniel and Aurora,"It's that thief from earlier. I'm going to try to get him to come down, Daniel don't do anything okay."
"What if he tries to hurt you, though."
"Just let him come down, he must have a reason for following us." Isabella replied.
With that said, Isabella called out."You can come out, my friend won't hurt you." There wasn't any response for a moment, then they heard someone say "You promise?"
Isabella looked at Daniel who nodded, before replying,"We promise."
After he climbed down the four went into a single room at the inn. After they had the shut the door, Anton spoke,"Are you Princess Isabella?"
Taken aback, Daniel asked,"I'm sorry what did you say?"
"Don't try to play dumb. I know she is. I remember almost everything I see and I remember her." He said to Daniel.
"Ok you know who I am, but how do you know me?" Isabella asked.
"That is a long story, but I guess we have time." Anton said as he went to sit down.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Anton was running as fast as he could from the other boys. He always was their favorite target, mainly because he was much smaller. He was tired of them picking on him, and he was getting exhausted from running. As he turned a corner he looked around for somewhere to hide. Seeing an alley he hoped he could make it before anyone saw him. Running into it, his hopes of escape were dashed as he heard someone yell "He went into the alley." It wasn't long before he was cut off and surrounded. He cringed and closed his eyes to wait when he heard a girl yell "Leave that kid alone!" Both Anton and has attackers looked to the voice to see a girl about two years older than Anton standing in the street staring at the older boys.
The leader of the group asked "And what will you do if we don't?"
"I'll get Daniel to make you." was her reply, just as a boy the same age as the others walked up beside her.
The leader then told his gang,"Come on, lets teach these people a lesson. Starting with this Daniel." After they had left Anton, the girl ran up to him and asked "Are you ok?" He only nodded to her as he heard Daniel yell "And don't try to pick on him again." After he stood back up and went back to the street, they all heard the sound of several armored footsteps against the road, and then someone calling for the Princess Isabella. He looked at her in shock as she said "Oh no they've figured out I've gone away again. Come on Daniel we've been found," then turning back towards Anton said,"You be careful and don't let them just pick on you." After she said this, she and the boy ran off towards the incoming guards.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
"That was two years ago, when I was twelve."
"I remember now!" Isabella exclaimed.
Daniel then asked "Did they try to mess with you again?"
"No, they left me alone after that encounter."
Aurora, who had been silent until then, asked "But why did you try to rob us, where are your parents?"
Anton visibly winced at this and Aurora quickly added "you don't have to tell us if you don't want to."
"No, it's okay. They both came down with a fever a year ago, and didn't recover. My uncle takes care of me now, but he is poor and has to steal to survive. He taught me everything I know."
As Isabella and Aurora talked to Anton and told him of their quest, Daniel had taken out the book and turned to the map. He called them all over to look as the map had again changed, this time leading down the path they had taken to Arrya and through the plains region.
"Aurora, Isabella come look at this. The map has changed again."
"What could have caused it to change again?" Aurora thought out loud.
Anton was curious by now and as he came around to look at the book, a look of understanding came across Daniel's face. "Anton your fourteen now right."
Nodding Anton replied "Yeah."
Turning to Isabella he asked her "What was that other prophecy Zarion told you of?"
"The one about the four teenagers who will find the treasure?" she asked.
"Do you really think that I am this fourth person." Anton asked.
"I don't see why not," Aurora said,"the map only showed the city of Arrya when we last checked it, and now it shows that we must backtrack."
"Ok, if you are sure and its okay with all of you I'll come with you. You wait here while I gather some things and tell my uncle." he said, then left wondering what to tell his uncle.
111112111111112211121111212212111111.title: Follow as they arrive.

1111121111111122111211112122121111112.content:
In the dawn of that morning Zarion stood inside his cave near the entrance. Before him was the now abandoned village of his people. Deep inside the cave there was another opening which showed a similar scene, but this village was not abandoned.
He stood there with an unwavering gaze, as if waiting for something to appear. There was a brief gust of air, and without even looking away Zarion said "I am not as easy to sneak up on as others, Lady Dragoon."
A form gathered from nowhere beside Zarion and said "It was worth a try." as the shape of the old woman fully appeared.
"You can also drop your guise, the spell protecting the village may have ended, but this cave is permanently enchanted to block any outside view." He told her as he turned and showed her to the chairs that he and Isabella had sat in. She nodded then concentrated a moment, her form fading out and then back. Standing where the old woman had been was a tall, beautiful woman with long white hair that was giving off a soft aura. He offered her a seat. As they both sat down Zarion spoke "I presume you are here about the Princess and her friend."
"Indeed. I assume you know about the knights that were sent to recover her?"
"Yes, and I am already planning was to stall them. But I fear there is a new player. The magic wave that came from the portal collapsing has gotten Radigan's attention, and by my guess some creature under his control will arrive very shortly after the knights."
Alarmed by this news Lady Dragoon asked "Will the knights be able to handle it?"
"I believe they can, but I have some surprises planned just in case."
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
As the knights walked out of the forest they looked around amazed at the village hidden in the forest.
Thomas was the first to speak, saying "Donovan, Jonothan you two go to the left. Andrew, Bernard you go right. I'll check this building. Meet back in five." The others moved off to search their designated part of the town. Thomas walked into the elder's home, where he found a piece of parchment on a table in the middle. Upon inspecting the parchment he saw handwriting he recognized as the Princess's. It read:

To the five knights,
If you are reading this, than you are on the right track. Daniel, Aurora, and I have set out again. Aurora is a girl from this village who is coming with Daniel and I to aid us on our quest. You must keep following us, but you can't and won't stop us on our journey. I have a feeling that we will need your aid on our return trip. I am also writing this to let you know that I am fine, and that Daniel has been doing a fine job guarding me and keeping me safe.

Princess Isabella
After reading the note Thomas quickly looked around for any more ideas as to where they could have gone. Seeing none he returned outside. While waiting for the others it finally struck him as odd how he had not seen a single person, besides the knights. As he pondered this, the other four knights returned. They all had the same news.
"Every where we looked was the same scene. The people who lived here had to pack in a hurry, but no signs of fighting of any kind." Donovan said.
"Same thing for our side of the village, but no sign of the Princess." Bernard said.
"I found this note from the Princess so we are on their tail. And it seems that they have a companion." Thomas told the others as he passed the note around.
When the note got to Jonothan he grinned and said "I knew that giving that Daniel boy a little bit of training would help someday."
The others looked at him and Andrew said "You did what?"
Jonothan nonchalantly replied "Oh quit your worrying, it was just some sword and hand to hand stuff. I figure as much time as the Princess spends around him he might as well know how to properly fight."
"I can't believe you gave a stableboy any amount of knight training." Andrew said in disbelief.
Their arguing was stopped by Donovan who held his finger over his mouth, then said "Listen"
Stopping what they were doing they heard a faint screeching sound that was quickly getting louder. They all recognized the sound and looked up to see ten winged creatures, each about seven feet tall overhead, slowly circling towards the ground. Thomas whispered "Gargoyles, what are they doing here?"
"Radigan probably sent them here for some reason." Bernard said.
"Then lets take them out so they can't report back" Jonothan said as he drew his sword.
"I agree with Jonothan, for once." Thomas whispered.
"Great, get ready, I'll get their attention." Jonothan replied, before looking into the sky and yelling "Down here." This got there attention as they looked down and one dived towards Jonothan. As it sped towards him he readied himself and as it reached him he quickly ran it through and spun out of the way as the creatures corpse hit the ground hard then pulled his sword out laughing. There was a thud behind him and he quickly dodged a blow from another gargoyle. The others had landed and were fighting the knights. Despite being outnumbered the knights fought off and killed the rest of the gargoyles.
Their fighting had taken them closer to the waters edge of the lake, and after the last one had fallen the knights made their way to the lake to clean their blades.
After they had done that, they sat to rest for a moment. As they sat looking over the lake they all heard a faint whispering come across the water.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
"How much do you think I should tell them?" Zarion asked.
"I would tell them of the quest and its importance. And about how they will be needed soon." Lady Dragoon said.
"Very well then." Zarion said before whispering the story to the knights.
1111121111111122111211112122121111112.title: See how Zarion is holding up the knights.

choices: The group come across a farm
11111211111111221112111121221211111121.content:
It has been two days since Anton joined them and they had left Arrya. They had made great time the first day, making their way back up the road that led to Arrya and starting through the the plains region. This region was responsible for most of the kingdoms food supply. The view was unobstructed for miles, and the view was rather breathtaking. They had traveled for several miles, but the plains were vast and to get anywhere would take several days travel.
As they walked along they spent most the time getting to know each other and talking about the treasure.
While they knew they would have to eventually, they avoided telling Anton about Auroras abilities for as long as they could. Daniel thoroughly enjoyed Anton's laughter, than stunned silence when Aurora tried to tell him, only to have to prove her magic to him.
While they had stopped for a moment to let Anton calm down, Isabella asked him "What did your uncle say about you leaving and coming with us?"
"Oh, he wasn't too happy about it and he tried to convince me to stay, but he let me go."
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Back in Arrya there was a commotion in a back alley, near the residential area.
Ronald was carried and then thrown into an alley by five men in full plate armor after having been caught picking the lock to a rich merchant's house. He had been working on how to escape when he was thrown into the alley. As he stood back up he dodged a blow from one of the knights, before one the oldest one walked up and said to the other "Donovan I'd like to try to keep this civilized as possible, I'll let you know if he needs some convincing." He then turned to Ronald and said "I assume you are Ronald?"
"I might be. Who's asking?" Ronald replied, brushing himself off.
"I presume you need some convincing as well." Thomas said as he produced a small bag of gold, then threw it towards Ronald. Ronald caught it, and as he inspected the coin said,
"I have some questions of my own. First does this have to do with my nephew? Second, what is going on, and last how did you find me?"
"If you nephews name is Anton, then yes. As for what is going on all I can say is it in involves the Princess. And you of all people should know that the beggars of a city are a have a wealth of information to give, for a price though." Thomas replied. "But I believe that answers all of your questions so I'll ask you mine now. Where did your nephew go?"
"He didn't say much about where, he just ran into our home and grabbed a few of his personal things and a travel cloak. He was inside and then he was gone."
"Did he stop long enough to tell you what he was doing?"
"He was pretty excited when he spoke about it, and all I could gather was something about a quest. I didn't hear much else, so I must be on my way now. My wife must be worried sick be now." Ronald honestly told the knights.
As he said this he walked towards the exit of the alley way and after the other three knights moved, he made his way down the street, disappearing into the crowd.
"Did you learn anything new?" Andrew asked walking up.
"No, he didn't get to speak to his nephew for long. But from what I can gather from everything that has happened so far, we are constantly one step behind them." Thomas replied. He looked away in the direction Ronald had disappeared, before looking back and telling the other knights "Split up and we will each go to a gate and ask around after that we will meet up at the barons castle to discuss what we found and get a good rest. I have a feeling that we will need it."
11111211111111221112111121221211111121.title: Back to the four

choices: The four stop to rest for the night.
111112111111112211121111212212111111211.content:
The knights split up, with each one of them heading to one of Arrya's five gates. Jonothan went to the gate they had entered through. The same beggar who told them where to find Ronald was sitting in the same spot.
"So did you find your man?" the beggar asked.
"Yes but he said he didn't know where his nephew was heading. So now we don't even know which way they have gone."
"Are we still talking about Anton and the two girls and boy who were with him?"
"Yes."
"Well why didn't you say so, they all left the day after they arrived. And that was two days ago." The old man replied.
Jonothan looked at the man in disbelief and asked "Why didn't you tell us this when we first entered the city?"
The man laughed and replied" Well you didn't ask."
Jonothan shook his head as he turned to run to the Barons home.
111112111111112211121111212212111111211.title: They meet up again.

choices: See how the King and Queen are holding up.
Follow as the four examine the light.
1111121111111122111211112122121111112111.content:
That night, the four adventurers gathered around a small campfire. As they sat they spoke about their plans.
"Ok, the map in the book says that we just need to head north. But the map also changes when we leave a region." Daniel said.
Anton was looking at the book along with Daniel and said "If it does that, then it could lead us on forever."
"I don't think so. If I were one of the ancient elders who hid the treasure, I would have hidden it in the mountains to the north." Aurora said.
"Do you mean the mountains that border Radigan's empire? Because if so, then this is going to be far more dangerous then I anticipated." Isabella asked.
They all sat thinking for a moment, but Aurora broke the silence saying, "Even if it is in the mountains bordering his kingdom, we will be able to prevail." They agreed, and after Aurora put out their fire, went to sleep.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
The next morning, after they had gathered all of their things, they set off down the path. They had just begun to walk when Daniel asked Anton, "You said in Arrya that your uncle taught you almost everything you know."
"Well he taught me everything I know about being a thief. My parents taught me to read and a little bit of writing, and my dad taught me how to use a dagger and bow real well. He had been a soldier before he was wounded. My uncle taught me how to pick locks and pockets, and how to move about unseen. I hadn't ever been caught before running into you." Anton replied.
"What did you get from your uncle's home?" Isabella asked.
"Well I got my cloak, my bag, and most importantly my father's dagger. I always try to pack light so I can move fast." Anton said as he patted each item, as if to make sure he still had them.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
It had been several hours since that conversation and the sky had become dark and cloudy. Aurora and Anton were confused by this, as the storm seemingly came from nowhere.
"The plains are known for their inclement weather. It's one of the reasons they are called the Skyfall Plains." Isabella responded.
"And having traveled through this area before, I know we are going to need shelter and fast." Daniel said as the winds suddenly picked up.
The group moved along, though at a faster then usual pace. They had only gone on for another half hour when the rain began to fall. It started light at first, but grew heavier and heavier. Soon it was almost as dark as night, and the wind was so loud they had to yell to hear one another. It wasn't helping that the temperature was plummeting as well.
Aurora, who was in the rear, shouted to the rest, "We have to find some kind of shelter before nightfall. If we don't we'll freeze."
"In that case we are in luck." Daniel said pointing to a small square of light in the darkness.
1111121111111122111211112122121111112111.title: The four stop to rest for the night.

choices: Go to the four adventurers as they examine the light
Continue with the King and Queen
1111121111111122111211112122121111112111.content:
"Edward, it has been a over a week since she ran off, and you sent the knights after her. They should have caught up with her by now and we haven't even heard from them." The distraught Queen told her husband. Edward walked towards her to comfort her, only to stop as there was a knock on the door of his study. Opening it, he was greeted by a young courier from Arrya, who presented to him a letter. Thanking and dismissing him, the King took the letter and opened it.
"Who is it from?" the Queen asked, after she saw the look on Edwards face.
Now deep in thought, Edward handed the letter to Jasmine as he turned to a bookcase that extended across the side of the room. Jasmine turned her attention to the letter and read it for herself:

King Edward and Queen Jasmine,
"I am writing this to inform you that, while the other knights and I have not yet caught up to the Princess, we are hot on their trail. From what we can gather, we are consistently a day and a half behind them at the most. It would seem that they have gathered some companions in their journey thus far."
The letter then described what they knew of Aurora and Anton, including Aurora's apparent aptitude for "illusions",(as Thomas called it) and Anton's former profession. It also told of the quest she had undertaken.
The Queen had finished skimming over the letter when she noticed that there was a smaller note attached at the bottom. "We found this note from the princess in the village that this Aurora girl was from."
Edward had been scanning over the shelves of books when he found it.
"Ah, here it is." He said as he took a book off of the shelf.
"What is it?" Jasmine asked as she got up to see what her husband had been searching for.
It was a old looking book, one that had surely changed hands many times. The cover was somewhat faded, but embossed on the cover in ornate writing were the words, "Tales of the Ancient's."
"What is this?" The Jasmine asked, glancing towards Edward.
"This is the book that tells of this treasure that Isabella seeks. Well, it's the original copy of that book anyway. I had scribes make another copy for the castle library. I'm sure that Isabella brought the new copy with her." He responded, as he flipped through the pages. He finally came to the faded page that told of the ancient treasure.
1111121111111122111211112122121111112111.title: See how the King and Queen are holding up.

1111121111111122111211112122121111112111.content:
RD#42
As the four adventurers made their way to the mysterious light on the plains, the storm continued to gain strength. Isabella was leading the way as best as she could. The light was the only indication of their direction. Suddenly she stopped, almost causing Daniel to bump into her, and yelled to the others "Wait, I just remembered something". She then reached into her pack and pulled out the enchanted lantern Zarion had given her. She knelt down to the ground but then said "Wait, I don't know if mud will ignite the flame. Zarion said sprinkling a little dirt starts the fire."
"Let me see." Aurora said as she walked over.
Isabella handed the lamp to Aurora and she knelt down and with little concentration drew the water out of a small patch of soil. She quickly took a pinch of the soil and dropped it into the lantern. A flame sparked immediately, illuminating the area around them. Even though the wind was blowing with full force, the light didn't flicker at all, just as Zarion had said.
As they approached the light, it became steadily larger. Eventually they were close enough to tell that the light came from the window of a small farmhouse. They considered what to do for only a moment, before a large bolt of lightening light the sky and urged them to seek shelter.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Bundled up in their home, the members of the Regana family sat in front of the fireplace. Helena sat in her rocking chair, mending a coat, while Gregory sat in his chair. The twins sat in front of the fire with a blanket around them, and the eldest son was in his own chair, whittling away at a stick while watching the fire burn. The tranquility of the scene was broken by a sudden sharp knocking at the door. "Who would be out in a storm like this, especially at this time of night?" Gregory asked as he got up from his chair to answer.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
They did not have to wait outside of the house for long. Not long after they knocked a man opened the door and after a second of confusion quickly ushered them in and showed them to the fireplace. Upon seeing the unexpected guests and how cold and wet they were, Helena quickly rose and exclaimed "You poor things, come sit by the fire and warm yourselves. Gregory go get some more blankets. Jackson, go start some tea. Catherine, Catalina give one of them your blanket." The twins ran over to Isabella and draped their blanket around her shoulders, then ran and each got another from their father who had returned with three more. After she was sure they were drying off, Helena went off to the kitchen to take over the tea for Jackson.
The four adventurers had no chance to get a word in once Helena took over. They had been quickly ushered into the den and were sat down in front of the fire. Gregory returned to his chair and got comfortable, then began introductions, "Well, since you probably want to wait this storm out, I think we should all introduce ourselves. I'm Gregory Regana, this is my son Jackson," he said as he nodded towards the boy," and those two are the twins, Catherine and Catalina. My wife's name is Helena."
Daniel was the first to respond, saying "I am Daniel, this is Aurora, Anton, and Izzy." It had occurred to him that he should not tell Isabella's full name, just as an extra precaution.
"Well it's a good thing you got here, this storm is only going to get worse. It usually slacks off in the morning, so y'all are welcome to stay in here until then."
