1111121111111122111211112122122.content:
Ignoring the muttered gossip around her, Freddie scoured the pots in the sink before her. Oh how she wished she could submerge her head in the tepid waters and drown out their rumors. She had learned long ago how to ignore the injurious gossiping of nosy servants. Back then it had been about her black eyes and cut lips. She never thought that Daniel could ever cause their family to become a target of such salacious talk.

“Frederica, the Queen asked for you to bring her tea today. Take this tray up to her parlor,” commanded Marta, the kitchen matron. Freddie dried her hands on her apron and collected to indicated tray of tea and cakes. A practiced look of indifference on her face, Freddie pretended not to notice the hushed whispers and sideways glances as she marched through the kitchen door.

Freddie was hardly surprised the Queen had asked for her. Ever since news got out about the princess’s disappearance it was all anyone could talk about. It and the stable boy who had also gone missing, and the mother of said stable boy. Honestly she was surprised she wasn't hauled in before the King and Queen days ago when they first discovered the children gone.

When she knocked on the door to the Queen’s parlor and was bid to enter, Freddie half expected to be greeted by royal guards upon entering just waiting to arrest her for conspiring to kidnap the princess. Instead, she found the only occupant of the luxurious room was the Queen, sitting alone in an armchair gazing out the window.

Freddie place the tray on the stand beside the Queen and prepared her a cup of tea. Finished Freddie took one step back and waited as Queen Jasmine began to sip her tea. A servant’s life involved an awful lot of waiting and simply being at hand.

“Do you think they are alright?”

Startled Freddie didn't know what she was being asked, “Your Majesty?”

“Our children. Do you think they are safe wherever they are?” There it was. The guards were bound to show up any second now to take her into custody for questioning.

“I swear I don’t know where they have gone,” Freddie blurted out. Then added as an afterthought, “your majesty.”

Queen Jasmine turned in her seat and gripped Freddie in a piercing gaze. “If I thought you had even an inkling of their whereabouts, Frederica, you would already have been made to tell us.” Freddie stood frozen, unsure how to respond, having no doubt the Queen meant what she said. “Have a seat Frederica. Tea?”

Freddie carefully sat down in the armchair opposite Queen Jasmine and simply nodded as it dawned on her that maybe the queen just wanted to have a conversation. As incredulous as that thought was - a queen wanting to have a real conversation with a servant - these two women were connected through their children. Though they had been obliged to interact at times due to their children’s friendship, those interactions had never amounted to much more than a few cordial words. As adults they did not know how to bridge the gap in their statuses with friendship the way Daniel and Isabelle found so natural. Jasmine could never call Daniel’s mother “Freddie,” and Freddie could not break the habit of referring to Isabelle’s mother as “your majesty.” And yet they knew each other nearly as well as they knew themselves. Their children were always telling them stories about the other woman that very few were privy to. This fostered a mutual respect between the two mothers that they could not express to the other for the sake of propriety and for fear of betraying the other’s privacy by revealing how much they each knew about the other through their children.

“I pray for their safe return every day, your majesty,” Freddie began hesitantly. When Queen Jasmine nodded her head in agreement, Freddie took that as a sign to keep talking. “I only wish I knew where they had gone.” It was slightly more emotional than her previous statement, but still a relatively safe comment that could be said to a person of any class. “The one thing I know for certain, your majesty, is that wherever they are, my Daniel will protect the princess with his life if need be.” Freddie didn't say this to garner favor with the queen or because she thought that’s what the queen wanted to hear. She said it because it was true. Daniel cared too much for his friend to ever let anything bad happen to her.

“Yes, I believe that to be true,” the Queen responded, knowing it beyond a doubt. He may have only been a stable boy but his heart and courage more than equaled that of any of the king’s knights whose ranks Jasmine knew he so desperately wanted to join. How else could he stand before the king and queen after getting into some mischief or another with the Isabelle, often times trying to claim all blame for himself? Isabelle could not have a more fiercely loyal protector, and she would need one when she became queen. Jasmine knew Isabelle usually deserved most of the responsibility for whatever she and the boy had done; afterall she far outranked a lowly stable boy and Jasmine had made sure she knew exactly what was and was not acceptable behavior for a princess. And yet, time and time again, there was this young boy facing the wrath of not merely two angry parents, but two angry monarchs, and trying to claim he was the one truly at fault.

Both women sat in awkward silence trying to decide what else they could say and contemplating the friendship between their children. It was an unlikely friendship to say the least. Neither knew exactly how it had come about in the first place. They knew the two would not be able to remain friends for long; since birth their lives were set on two different paths that would ultimately create a distance between them. But for now, despite their misgivings for the future, both mothers were secretly glad their children had each other.

“How do you take your tea Frederica?” Jasmine inquired, not sure how else to break the silence.

As soon as Jasmine picked up the teapot and began pouring a cup, Freddie leaped out of her seat, “Your majesty! Please let me do that for you.” Freddie was barely able to contain herself and refrain from yelling it at the queen.

“Now, now Frederica. I am perfectly capable of pouring a cup of tea. Please sit.” Jasmine was shocked and bemused to have elicited such a response. Freddie on the other hand was mortified and confused; she didn’t know what to do. Which would be worse: allowing the queen to serve a servant or arguing with the queen over who should pour the tea. The former as definitely improper, but the latter could very well be considered treason. So Freddie slowly eased herself into her chair, ready to spring back to her feet at a moment’s notice.

Concerned that she had caused Frederica discomfort, Jasmine decided to let her pour the tea from that point on. It was Frederica’s job after all. Jasmine should have known better than to break the bounds of propriety like that. She was beginning to think this whole idea had been a mistake.
1111121111111122111211112122122.title: Two Mothers

choices: Aurora decides to stay, but Tenmar must go
Both Aurora and Tenmar decide to stay/go
11111211111111221112111121221221.content:
Her story complete, Isabelle took a deep breath and released her shoulders. She had not noticed how tense her muscles had become as she recounted the event, but it now felt as if speaking the words had released a burden. She had watched her companions closely as they listened, and she now wished to know what they thought.

Having begun during the telling, Daniel continued to pace behind Isabelle’s chair, occasionally shaking his head as he tried to put all the pieces together in a way he liked. Aurora examined the contents of the bag which Isabelle had brought out when she listed Zarion’s gifts. Aurora handled each item as if it were a priceless artifact, which they were in a way. These objects represented magicks and knowledge that had been lost to her people during the Decline. She had either never heard of them or had never met anyone capable of conjuring them.

While Daniel and Aurora were visibly moved by all they had been presented with in the past several hours, Tenmar appeared to have finally collected himself. “More of Zarion’s life force must still be conscious than we ever thought,” Tenmar mused. “Only magic, his magic, could have brought you to him. He has not had a physical body or appeared in any form for decades. And there is no cave behind the waterfall, only sheer rock face. Zarion must have created that bubble for you to speak. The magic expended on that meeting and these gifts may very well be the reason for the accelerated death of the waterfall.” A flash of realization crossed Tenmar’s face as he remembered the fast approaching deadline on their only guaranteed escape from Radigan’s sinister reach.

“Thank you for telling us about Zarion, Isabelle. I hope you realize how special such a meeting is.” Tenmar rose from his chair and began mentally checking off items on a list of essentials not to be left behind. “Aurora, time grows short, we need to finish packing,” Tenmar instructed. But, while he stooped to retrieve the wooden bowl which had rolled into the doorway, Aurora remained firmly in her seat, deep in thought. See that his daughter was moving to obey his command, Tenmar gently admonished, “Aurora, go and pack. I’m sure there are things you’d rather not leave behind when we cross through the waterfall. You won’t be able to come back for them.”

Still Aurora did not rise from her seat. She did not move a muscle except for her lips. “What was that?” Tenmar asked when no sound escaped her mouth.

“Maybe we should stay.” She was finally able to force the words out loud enough to be heard, but Aurora still could not bring herself to look at her father.

“Stay where? The waterfall is about to die and leave us wide open to detection and attack. Radigan must not find any of us.”

“But if the Treasure of Higani is found; Radigan can be stopped. We would all be safe,” Aurora argued, her voice slowing growing in volume and confidence while her eyes remained glued to the contents of Isabelle’s bag.

“IF the Treasure is found by someone other than Radigan. IF it even contains something capable of stopping him. IF the finder knows how to use it and is willing to risk his or her life. The danger is too great to chance on IF. Crossing through the waterfall now guarantees our safety. So that is exactly what we are going to do.”

“You said so yourself, it must have taken an incredible amount of power for the Nyx to appear to Isabelle. He wouldn’t have done that if it wasn’t important. If he didn’t believe she and Daniel could succeed.” Both Isabelle and Daniel were overwhelmed by Aurora’s faith in their ability to accomplish a mission which had only begun as a frivolous jaunt to get away for awhile. But all they could do was watch as father and daughter debated their chances of saving them all.

“Then let them do it. Or better yet let them go home to their families where it is safe. Like you they are children after all.” Incredulous, Tenmar could not believe what his daughter was saying. Gripping the bowl in his hands, his knuckles began to turn white from the strain.

Swept up in her passion, Aurora rose to her feet and finally found the courage to face her father and utter a singular statement, “They would have a better chance with our help and you know it is the right thing to do.”

Matching the gravity of her tone, Tenmar replied, “And you know exactly why we have to go. Or do you want their blood on our hands?” Tenmar gestured out the window. “Is betraying them the right thing to do?” Aurora’s eyes flickered with doubt as her resolve began to falter. Seeing this Tenmar softened his voice and drove home his point. “Doing the right thing isn’t always so cut and dry. It can take many forms. We have responsibilities we cannot ignore.” Tenmar and Aurora remained with their eyes frozen on each other as if a staring contest would decide their fate. Isabelle and Daniel stood by waiting to see who would break first.

Though Aurora dropped her eyes to the floor, Tenmar did not loosen his viselike grip on the bowl. Instead he waited, and hoped, for confirmation that she understood and acquiesced to his position. Aurora’s shoulders visibly drooped as she realized she could not dispute her father’s point, but neither could she concede her own. She struggled for a response, and the others waited to hear it.

“I need to think,” stumbled from her lips, and then Aurora marched straight out the front door without looking at anyone.
11111211111111221112111121221221.title: Disagreement

111112111111112211121111212212211.content:
Everyone else remained frozen until the slamming of the door had ceased echoing in their ears. Tenmar made his way to the front door, but with the wooden bowl still gripped tightly in his hands he could not open it. He simply moved his gaze back and forth between the door knob and and the bowl. He seemed to have lost control of his hands. He did not know how to make his hand release the bowl and turn the doorknob.

Isabelle followed Tenmar to the front door and placed her hand on his rebellious right hand, “It may be a good idea to give her a little space. Why don’t I help you pack while we wait for her,” Isabelle offered. Looking at Daniel, she implored him with her eyes.

“And I will go check on Aurora,” Daniel chimed in understanding immediately what Isabelle meant to communicate. So Isabelle guided Tenmar back into the kitchen, and Daniel went out into the village in pursuit of Aurora.

Isabelle and Tenmar worked in silence. She pulled kitchenware from cupboards and lined the up on the counter. He chose some to pack away in bags and boxes and others to be left where they lay according to an indecipherable list apparent only to him. Only after double checking all the items on the counter, ensuring they were neither needed nor wanted did he address Isabelle who sat in a chair at the kitchen table cluttered with items to be left behind.

“It is not that I don’t trust Zarion or you and Daniel,” Tenmar stated as he stood before the sink, his hands gripping the edge. “I just believe it is too great a risk, and one you and Daniel should not have to bear.” Turning his head to look Isabelle in the eye, Tenmar asked a questions Isabelle couldn’t yet answer, “Are you prepared to accept the burden of all the power hidden away with the Treasure of Higani?”

Isabelle had fled her father’s castle and all the responsibilities of a princess. This quest had no goal beyond one last hurrah before submitting to her duties as her father’s heir, including the political marriage her parents had decided she was old enough for them to arrange. Despite everything she had heard in the past day and a half about the importance of finding the Treasure and the prophecy, she could now allow herself to acknowledge it.

“I did not set off to save the world. I’m not sure I even believe these prophecies about the Treasure. Whatever Aurora decides, whether or not we find this Treasure, I do not intend on personally confronting Radigan, no matter what powers we find.”

~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~


Daniel found Aurora sitting beneath a tree on the edge of the clearing watching the other villagers load their belongings into small boats. Piles grew and shrank as families argued over what to bring and what to leave.

“They’ve known for years we would have to leave our homes,” Aurora mused as Daniel sat down beside her with his legs stretched before him and his hands planted behind propping him up, “but in the panic and rush they’ve forgotten the plans they made and rehearsed long ago.”

“You’ve also for years that you would be leaving,” Daniel pointed out, “Why fight it now?”

“I’ve always dreamed of the day we could go beyond the boundaries of our village without fear of persecution or exploitation, but I accepted it was only a fantasy. When I met you and Isabelle on the road, that was the furthest I had ever ventured out of our lands, and I don’t even know why I did it. With the appearance of the Nyx, though, and everything he told Isabelle. I don’t know. I think I’m beginning to feel hope that it could truly happen; that you and Isabelle could save us all.

“Why us?” Daniel asked.

“You do still plan on going in search of the Treasure do you not?” Aurora asked in reply, continuing to watch the frantic movements of the villagers by the waterside.

“I suppose so. I don’t think either of us are ready to return home. Especially after learning there is still so much about the world of which we are ignorant.”

Aurora turned her body so that she was sitting cross legged facing Daniel straight on. Then she asked one simple questions, “Why not you?” Fumbling for the words, Daniel tore his gaze from Aurora to scan the surface of the lake to buy himself time. “From what I have seen,” she continued, “you both have good hearts, sharp minds, and are more than capable. Who else can be trusted with the powers of the Higani Treasure?”

“We are only two people,” Daniel insisted. “Yes we will search for the Treasure of Higani while we feel it is safe to do so, but Isabelle is my princess as well as my friend, and I will not put her in such mortal danger. How can we be expected to go up against the obstacles put in place to the protect the Higani Treasure let alone against Radigan?”

“With some help.”

~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~


“Yes, of course your chances would be greater with help. And, honestly, with discipline and training, Aurora’s abilities may be stronger than either of us know. Recently they have come to rival any surviving Nykken we have met, and they are still growing, but that isn’t saying much considering the Decline and what Nykken powers used to be,” Tenmar’s words came tumbling angrily from his mouth at such a speed they began to run together and it was all Isabelle could do to separate them. It sounded as if his mouth had betrayed him by giving voice to those thoughts, but perhaps by saying them fast enough, the words would pass right by without stopping to interrupt his well reasoned argument.

The unthinkable risks involved and the extremely low possibility of three children succeeding where so many others - people who had greater skill and faced less threat from Radigan - had failed was a perfectly practical objection. Admitting his faith in his daughter’s abilities, however, made it less so.

Seeing one line of argument come apart, Tenmar fell back on the most basic and most powerful argument he knew, “No matter how strong she becomes in power and in will, I am still her father. It is my duty to protect her.”

“If you truly believe that,” Isabelle suggested, “then why not join Aurora in her quest. Surely your knowledge and experience could only help ensure our success and safety.”

“It is impossible.”

“Why?”

“Of all those still in the village, only Aurora and I are able to activate the gheestone and open the portal. And whoever opens the portal is automatically transported to the other side.”
111112111111112211121111212212211.title: Is this Goodbye?

choices: See what happens between Aurora and Tenmar
See how the King is doing
1111121111111122111211112122122111.content:
~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~


“So that is what your father meant about ‘abandoning them’,” Daniel realized. “If you or your father do not open the portal for them, all the villagers would be trapped here, cut off from a new and safer home and the villagers who have already gone ahead.”

“Precisely. I have no right to force that upon them. Especially with no guarantee that we’ll even find the Treasure of Higani, let alone read it before Radigan. Even if we find it first, who’s to say we’ll be able to use anything we find to defeat Radigan once and for all.”

“Then why are you fighting so strongly to stay and try?” Daniel asked.

After a brief hesitation, Aurora quietly uttered the only answer she had, “Because I feel it is the only thing I can do and what I must do.”

~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~


“I know I cannot stop her from staying behind and joining you in your journey,” Tenmar admitted in resignation, “but how do I say goodbye to my only daughter?”

“Because it is what she needs to hear. The truth is that while we say the words, ‘goodbye’ doesn’t mean what we think it does. We may part ways - for a few minutes or for an eternity - but those we love and who love us never really leave us. She is your daughter Tenmar. You are a part of her just as surely as she is a part of you. Every piece of advice you gave her, every lecture you scolded her with, every tear you wiped from her eye, and every smile you brought to her face now lives within her. As I am sure every one of her scraped knees and childhood nightmares, her hopes and dreams, her victories and defeats all live within you.”

~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~


“Perhaps I should just go,” Aurora mused. “Leave and begin my journey without saying goodbye to anyone. Maybe that would be easier for everyone.” She hugged her knees to her chest as she considered this. She couldn’t think of anything else to say to convince her father, and Aurora didn’t want to risk him changing her mind. Worse, she couldn’t bear the thought of him not changing her mind, of him letting her go, of him saying goodbye. “Having to say goodbye would be too painful, for both of us.”

“When I was seven my father walked out on my mother and I. Packed up one day and left.”

Surprised out of her thoughts of running away from home, Aurora fumbled for something to say, “I’m sorry…”

“Don’t be.” Daniel wasn’t looking for sympathy. He just wanted her to listen, and she did. “He wasn’t a good man. Never meant to be a husband or father. In fact, when he left, my greatest fear was that he would return.”

“I don’t understand.”

“He never said goodbye,” Daniel explained. “I never missed him once he was gone, and I put behind me everything he had put us through before leaving. The one thing I can’t seem to forgive or forget is the fact that he couldn’t even be bothered to tell us goodbye, not even in a note. Didn’t we deserve that much? Some acknowledgement that we had been a part of his life, that we were more than part of the scenery?” Daniel looked Aurora in the eye. “It isn’t surprising really, he was ever a cruelly selfish man who never saw us as people, but imagine if we had loved each other as you and your father do. Then tell me saying goodbye is too painful.”

~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~


“Saying goodbye is about closure. It lets them know you recognize they are a part of your life. It gives them closure so that they can go on with their lives even if you are no longer there. Goodbye is our final gift to anyone and everyone who has ever been in our lives. A gift that should never be denied to those we love most, if at all possible,” Isabelle didn’t know if what she was saying really meant anything, but it felt right. She wanted to ease Tenmar’s mind, but she couldn’t imagine what he was going though. For his part Tenmar couldn’t believe how wise she was for her age and inexperience.
1111121111111122111211112122122111.title: Why We Say Goodbye

choices: Stay with the King or other characters
Go back to the trio and Tenmar
11111211111111221112111121221221112.content:
“Sire?”

King Edward ran a hand down his face struggling to maintain his focus on the matter at hand. “Yes, please continue.”

“Sightings have been reported here, here, and here,” the commander continued. He indicated several new locations on the map in addition to the half dozen already marked. “The reports are vague and scattered, but they are consistent about what is being seen. I think it is safe to assume Radigan’s agents have begun crossing our borders. Most likely they are advanced scouts.”

“Any new information about the bulk of Radigan’s army?” Edward asked. Several weeks ago they had begun hearing rumors that Radigan was massing his forces and moving them toward the boundary between their lands.

“No, your majesty, we have received no further word about their movements.”

“Double patrols along the border. We cannot continue to allow these scouts to continue whatever mission Radigan has sent them on. If at all possible we need to capture and question one. If our patrols can carefully corner one within our lands have them do so, but they are not to seek them out. I do not want to risk one of our men accidentally crossing into Radigan’s territory.” They had no proof Radigan was planning anything at the moment. All they had was rumors and speculations. Edward did not want to inadvertently provide Radigan with justification to attack, but they needed to be ready just in case.

“Also, station men in these outlying villages. Have them lie low; claim to be there on a routine inspection. Do not worry the residents, but be prepared to evacuate them in the event of an attack.”

“I’ll see to it immediately. Any thing else sire?”

Examining the map before him, King Edward couldn’t help but wonder where his daughter was at that moment. He wanted to send more knights after her, but he had a bad feeling that every man he could spare would soon be needed. All he could do was hope that the five he sent would find her soon and keep her safe. “No commander, that is all for now.”
11111211111111221112111121221221112.title: Preparations

111112111111112211121111212212211122.content:
Their heads leaning in and foreheads touching, Aurora and Tenmar said their farewells at the edge of the lake. Isabelle and Daniel stood a short ways off to give them their privacy. Daniel thought of his father and tried yet again to say a final goodbye to the man who abandoned him, the man he secretly feared one day seeing in the mirror. Isabelle thought of her grandmother who had passed away a few years ago. She had been a truly tenacious woman and had thrived well into her twilight years. As a result she had had to say goodbye to a good many people before giving her own final farewell. It was she who had first given the speech Isabelle gave to Tenmar about goodbyes. At the time Isabelle couldn’t understand what her grandmother tried to convey. She had very little experience in really saying goodbye to loved ones. Even now she still couldn’t grasp much of it, but in seeing how those words and ideas touched Tenmar, Isabelle began to feel some of its meaning.

Daniel and Isabelle didn’t hear anything of what passed between father and daughter until the end when they pulled their heads apart.

“Stubborn just like your mother,” Tenmar smirked.

“No, like my father,” Aurora returned as they embraced one last time. Then Tenmar climbed into his boat with his belongings and rowed out onto the lake with the remaining villagers. Most were in boats, some treaded water beside boats carrying their families and/or belongings, and others stood in shallows submerged only up to their waists. Isabelle, Daniel, and Aurora were the only ones not in the water. Careful to stay dry on the shore, they watched the curtain of the waterfall part as Tenmar approached.

Isabelle was mildly surprised to see that Tenmar was right - the cave was gone and all that was left was a solid rock face. With his boat pressed up along the cliff, Tenmar passed his had in front of the rock wall. As he did so, a stone Daniel and Isabelle had not noticed before began to glow a pale indigo.

Tenmar glanced over his shoulder at Aurora, mouthed “goodbye,” and placed his hand on the stone. Aurora barely had time to return her father’s goodbye before he vanished before their eyes.

Once he was gone the waterfall returned to normal, once more concealing the gheestone behind. In the cascades of the falling water an image began to appear. Aurora took a step forward when she saw Tenmar in his boat floating on the surface of another lake in another world.

In a heartbeat the villagers closest to the waterfall similarly disappeared from the lake and reappeared on the other side of the waterfall with Tenmar. They were soon followed by the next villagers closest to the waterfall. Some waved to the three on the shore; others held their breath and braced for the journey. As the power of the gheestone rippled out from the gheestone toward the edge of the lake transporting wave after wave of people to safety, the waterfall decreased in flow and strength. Aurora retreated from the water lapping at her feet just before the last ripple of the surface of the lake was transported. She and her father gazed at each other through the faltering waterfall until the moment it sputtered out its final drops.
111112111111112211121111212212211122.title: The Waterfall Runs Dry

1111121111111122111211112122122111221.content:
Isabelle, Daniel and Aurora spent the night in the house she had shared with her father. The place looked as if it had been ransacked - items strewn about helter-skelter, cupboards and drawers left open and bare, and a deeper emptiness filling up every available space, saturating the household with the absence of its former occupant. This house was no longer a home.

Not knowing how to comfort her, Daniel and Isabelle gave Aurora her space. It was hard to say if she regretted her choice to stay or not. She didn’t say a word all night. There were no tears, no screams, no sighs, no stiff upper lip, no talk of plans. She simply packed a few supplies for the road and returned everything else to its proper place before laying down to sleep. Except for a few bare spots, the house almost looked like nothing had changed.

Before leaving the next morning Aurora had taken one of the remaining boats out to the base of the now dried up waterfall. All that remained of the gheestone was a handful of sand collected at the base of a small recess in the rock face where the pale indigo stone had once resided. Aurora gathered this sand in a pouch and hung it around her neck, then left the place she had called home with Daniel and Isabelle without once looking back.

~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~ * ~


After walking for a time, Daniel could no longer take Aurora’s silence. He didn’t want to press her too soon after her loss, but if they were going to be travelling together she would have to speak eventually. Curious, Daniel decided to ask about the contents of the pouch around Aurora’s neck. Daniel and Isabelle had watched Aurora collect the sand, but she still hadn’t said a word since saying goodbye to Tenmar. Since the leaving the lake Daniel had observed Aurora occasionally reach up and clutch the pouch in her hand, unconsciously reassuring herself it was still there.

“Is there any power left in that?” Daniel inquired as Aurora’s hand again grasped the pouch.

Looking down, her fingers gently brushing the pouch, Aurora gave an unequivocal, “No.”

“Then why hold on to it?” Daniel persisted.

“I had hoped more of the gheestone had survived than this. That I could still tap into some of its power however small. Unfortunately not enough of the its power survived. Still, even though it can have no use, having this small bit of the stone is comforting. It somehow makes me feel that my father and people aren’t completely lost to me forever. Foolish really.”

“Maybe not. What is a gheestone after all?”

As they continued to walk, Aurora explained that at the moment of death, if a person with magical abilities had the strength and will required, he or she could channel what remains of their life force into creating a gheestone. After that person is gone, the gheestone continues to possess what magick that person was able to pour into it. Once gheestones were passed down through families lines. They were remembrances of that person, a way for families to feel that their lost loved ones were still there with them. Some even believed that the stones contained the soul of the person who created it. This is why gheestones are sometimes called Spirit Stones.

In time, however, it was discovered that gheestones were much more than mere tokens used to remember someone, the magick within the stone could be tapped into and used by whoever activated the stone (whether that person had magick of their own or not). This made gheestones very valuable and extremely dangerous. Like any tool, these stones were not inherently good or evil based on whose life force it contained, but it could be used for either based on the desires of whoever wielded it. And if a person with malicious intentions amassed enough gheestones, he or she could use those combined powers to commit unspeakable acts completely unchecked.

As a result of the exploitation of magick, fewer and fewer gheestones were created. At the moment of their deaths people either did not have time to even think of creating a gheestone as their deaths came on too suddenly, lacked the strength of mind and/or body to focus their energy into a stone due to their mistreatment, or chose not to create the stone for fear of what a stranger might choose to do with that tangible piece of their soul.

“The gheestone behind of the waterfall was different,” Aurora elaborated. “We believe it was created by the Nyx when he gave his life force to the waterfall and the spells he left to protect us. When it was originally discovered no one knew what it was because the first few people who touched it could not activate it. And from what we knew about gheestones, we thought they could be used by anyone. However, eventually someone did touch it and managed to accidentally activated it. Unlike other gheestones we had heard of, the person who activated it had no control over it. The stone immediately carried out the spell you saw it perform last night: it transported everyone in the lake somewhere else.

“Naturally we were terrified. We didn’t know if they had been killed or if they had been sent somewhere or if that somewhere was safe or if they could ever return. We couldn’t even be sure it was the stone that had caused their disappearance. People were scared to put so much as a toe in the water lest they disappeared too. But we had to know what had happened. So one by one people were sent to the waterfall to see if they could get a reaction from the stone. It was discovered that when certain people got close enough to the stone it would start to glow. This let us know that these particular people could activate the stone by touching it.

“We still don’t know why the stone only responded to only those specific people, but our best guess is that the Nyx implanted safeguards into his gheestone. He was so powerful and so determined to ensure our safety; it must have taken a tremendous amount of effort to make sure that stone could only be used to protect us.

“Once we determined who could and could not use the stone, volunteers agreed to risk themselves by activating the stone to discover what had happened to the others and to see if the stone could do anything else. This time, since we knew what was coming, as soon as the volunteers in the water vanished we saw them through the waterfall. The window remained open long enough for us to see that they were all safe and happy and creating a new home there.

“After that, more and more people wanted to cross through the waterfall. It wasn’t long before we noticed the gheestone shrinking with each group that went through and we began running out of people who could activate the stone. So plans were made to ensure we’d all be able to move on in our own time.

“Well, you saw how well that worked out,” Aurora concluded, a hint of bitterness and sorrow in her voice.

“If this Treasure of Higani is truly filled with such incredible magicks, surely there is something there that can reunite you with your people once again,” Isabelle tried to reassure Aurora. “So the sooner we find it, the sooner you will see your father again. Though I personally am in no hurry to see my father again, for I am certain is will be very cross with me; my mother even more so. Maybe there’s something in the Treasure that will help me soothe their tempers, some magic elixir I can slip into their tea perhaps,” Isabelle joked. A small smile pulled at the corner of Aurora’s lips, but it may have been slightly forced for Isabelle’s benefit.

Daniel thought Isabelle sounded quite optimistic about finding the Treasure and getting Aurora back home. He, on the other hand, felt even less sure about this little adventure than he did when they had first set off from the castle. Aurora had left behind everything and everyone she knew because she thought Daniel and Isabelle were going to save the world and she wanted to help. He suspected Isabelle was beginning to have doubts as well and was putting on a brave face for Aurora and trying to convince herself that this was still some kind of game. Daniel couldn’t so easily deny that this bit of fun was becoming more complicated and potentially more dangerous. Still, they weren’t in any danger yet, and they couldn’t very well turn around now and tell Aurora that her sacrifice had been for nothing. For now, they continued walking the path they had chosen.

The rising dawn fell on the small party outside the stables where Isabelle and Daniel were readying themselves for their "journey" to see cousin Eric. Little did the Queen and King know that the two teenagers had no intention of going to Transylvania; they had treasure to hunt. The map played it self inside Isabelle's thoughts: Follow New Rhode to the split, turn east on to old Rhode, through Greenly forest, across Santher meadow, and on to Jagged Mountains.
"I'm having Sir Andrew and Sir Thomas escort the two of you to Transylvania. I have business there for them." Said the king.
"Father . . !" gasped Isabelle, then she turned on her charming smile,her dimples showing. "You don't need to trouble the knights with us--Daniel is capable of seeing us to Auntie's house."
King Edward leaned in to whisper in his daughters ear. "Your mother will not let you travel without the knights. You know how she worries."
Indeed, she did. But this couldn't have been worse timing. Isabelle flashed Daniel a 'Now what?' look. Daniel's brows were furrowed in a slight frown at this news of the knights accompanying them. Isabelle kissed her parents and set off for Transylvania.

Isabelle and Daniel rode along side one another with Sir Andrew and Sir Thomas bringing up the rear. Daniel could hear snatches of the knights conversation as they rode, and took this advantage to talk to Isabelle about their new prediciment. "I don't know how we're to get away for our treasure quest."
"We'll just wait for an opportunity and then slip away from the pair. You know I'm the best horse rider." Isabelle teased. Daniel rolled his eyes at her, but smiled any how. It was true that Isabelle was a good rider, but Daniel wouldn't think of running from the knights--it would be shameful--and these two were part of King Edwards best knights. They wouldn't stand a chance at escape and all their plans would be ruined.
"We'll just have to journey on to Transylvnia and see what happens from there."
"Once we're in auntie's hands, we'll never be able to leave." Isabelle pouted, which Daniel found most attractive, as it made her full lips fuller.
Isabelle and Daniel rode in silence; each one thinking their own thoughts. Daniel wanted very much to be alone with Isabelle, but he couldn't betray the knights either. He may not be a knight, but Daniel prided himself on following the code of knighthood. Now he was torn between the two.
Isabelle's thoughts were thinking up every kind of scenario that could come up and how she and Daniel could counter them in order to escape and begin their quest for the treasure. When the group came to the split in the road, Isabelle and Daniel each look wistfully down the path of the Old Rhode, knowing that was the start of the quest for the treasure. Daniel and Isabelle caught one anothers eyes and laughed. Isabelle knew that it would work out somehow.

Cresting the small hill, they came upon the town of Transylvania. A town completely surrounded by stone walls and a single entrance gate, where they headed even now. The knights were saluted as they passed though the gates; everyone knew King Edwards champions. Isabelle had just about giving up the idea of their getting away, when Sir Thomas came along side her mare.
Sir Thomas was middle aged, with brown hair and a well groomed mustache. "Princess, we must part from you here. Daniel is most capable of escorting you to the Duchess' home." Thomas bowed at the waist, gave a curt nod to Daniel and trotted off in the opposite direction. Isabelle could hardly believe their luck.
"Luck is with us." Daniel flashed Isabelle his dazzling smile, the one that made her heart skip.

Within minutes, Isabelle had procurred an errand boy to take a letter to her aunt, the Duchess, with instructions to not deliver said letter until fourth watch; late afternoon. Pressing a silver grint in the boy's hand, Isabelle watched the young lad skip away, she hoped he didn't take the silver and not deliver the letter. Well, she couldn't do any more about it, without taking it to her aunt herself. Now that would be a folly.
Quickly Daniel had Isabelle dress as a boy. She wore brown breeches, rust colored shirt of linen, and knee high boots. A wide brimmed hat covered the coiled braids of hair. Daniel studied Isabelle, sure enough she looked like a boy--a pretty boy at that. Quickly scooping some mud, he smeared it upon her clear skin. Eyes the color of jade green sparkled with amusement.
"There." Daniel said, brushing the mud from his hands. Isabelle studied her reflection in a hand mirror from her saddle bag. "Excellent! I'll be called James. James the younger brother of Daniel."
Daniel shook his head in amusement, watching the trusting look in Isabelle's eyes. She truly believed in his protection of her. A dark cloud entered his thoughts. 'Could he protect her if they came into trouble?' For a split second Daniel considered taking Isabelle to the Duchess, but it passed.

Daniel had located a small trail that would lead them back to the Old Rhode, away from the main highway. It was still early afternoon. They had a couple hours before the letter was delivered to Isabelle's aunt. Dear Isabelle; always sticking to her responsibilites. Telling her parents and aunt that she was safe with him and off to find a treasure, and would return soon.
Daniel knew he'd better enjoy every minute of their time together, because once they were found, Isabelle's parents would no longer be letting their daughter and heir, wander around with a stable boy. Surely he would be sent far away, forbidden to return. Shaking the gloomy thoughts from his mind, Daniel brought himself back to the present. They were coming to the Old Rhode now.
"Here we are! The beginning of our quest!" Isabelle exclaimed with glee. With excited thoughts, the two teenagers trotted away towards their quest.

~.~.~.~.~.~.~.~.~.~.~.

Meanwhile, as Isabelle and Daniel were happily beginning their quest, a spy of Radigan was apprehending the letter to the Duchess. Radigan had sent his spy Talimis, to follow the group and make sure Isabelle didn't make it to the Duchess' home. Everything was going along perfectly! Foolish Daniel--love sick fool--how little he knew that by taking Isabelle on this quest, he furthered Radigan's plan of taking over King Edward's kingdom. Of course, Isabelle would never return from her treasure quest. Talimis had orders to follow the pair, and once they had found the treasure, to kill them both.

Back at his abode, Radigan received the messanger falcon from Talimis with the note: 'All is set in motion ' The only signature was the signet of a raven.
"Perfect." Purred Radigan. He went to his coops to retrieve another bird to send to King Edward with a note that Isabelle was now Radigan's prisoner.

"Just a couple of boys out for a ride, are we?" he grinned.

"Let's leave by the servants entrance," she said as she took some soot from her fire place and smudged her pretty face with it, and to further her disguise, she dirtied her clothes with a bit of the ash as well.

Isabelle followed Daniel out into the halls, down the back stairs and through the kitchens, finally arriving out into the moonlight. Here she drew in a deep breath, a breath that could only be discribed as freedom.

Daniel hurried ahead leading her to the stables where he had two horses saddled and ready for their adventure.

"Racing, good sir?" he asked teasing.

"No," she said resolutely, "just a bit of exploration."

They mounted the fine roans.

"Alright," said Daniel,"Which way would you like to go."

Isabelle winked, "Catch me if you can." With that she gave the horse a sound kick in the ribs and was off like a shot.

Daniel raced after her down the hill and through the forest.

When the horses tired they slowed their pace and came upon a road in the forest which seemed to lead to a cottage that was well lighted for this
hour.
11221.title: The Late Night Ride.

choices: he tries to take one of the horses
112211.content:
They tied their horses to a low hanging branch on the side of the path and casually, somewhat cautiously - for who would be up at this early hour? - made their way to the cottage. Halfway down the walkway to the front door a loud crash and severe screaming stopped them in their tracks.

"Get up! Get up right now you lazy good for nothing! I told you that if I ever found you laying around, skipping your chores that you would be out!" Daniel and Isabelle fell to their knees with their hands covering their faces as a pan broke through the window.

"Ah, I don' need yo' scraps to eat and yo' floor to sleep on. I be fine on my own," another, younger voice yelled just as loud and crossly. The door burst open nearly falling off its hinges and a figure, apparently the owner of the second voice, stepped halfway outside, though not far enough to see any defining characteristics. Isabelle, grabbing Daniel's hand, pulled him behind some overgrown weeds so that they could see while goin unseen.

"How far do you think you will get in life? You have no proper training - in anything - you've never had any schooling whatsoever, you don't even speak well enough to converse with any of my simpler patrons."

"I'll make it far enough. I don't need no fancy schooling to make 'nough to get by. All I need know is how to work with my hands. I don't need you!" With this the figure stepped all the way out the door and Daniel and Isabelle saw that it was a boy aobut their age. The boy began walking along the walkway and a large bald man with a beard stepped through the door and threw another pan at the boy, who stopped and took one step tot he side just barely moving out of the way of the flying pan.

The man went back inside slamming the door, this time it did fall off its hinges and the man could be heard cursing his misfortune at ever giving that boy a job. Daneil and Isabelle watched the boy walk down the pathway still crouching behind the overgrown weeds. He stopped at the end of the walkway when he saw the horses tied to the branch.
112211.title: Anger

1122112.content:
The boy glanced to his sides (Daniel and Isabelle just outside his peripheral vision) and makes his way to the two steeds. Stroking the neck of Isabelle's horse, he calmed it and prepared to mount.

"Hey," Isabelle shouted without thinking. He turned around keeping one hand on the horse as Daniel and Isabelle stood.

"Who you?" he questioned. "What you want?"

"Those are our horses," Isabelle replied lowering her voice trying to match it with her male appearance.

"Really now?"

"Yes really."

"I saw them and no 'body 'round. Just thought to make sure they alright is all. Don't ya 'cuse me a stealing. 'sides, how I know they really yo's?" he challanged.

"Because we're telling you, that's how," Daniel chimed in. He and Isabelle walked up to the boy as he took a few steps from the horse. All three stood facing each other, staring, trying to make themselves look larger and meaner than they really were, and none showing any sign of backing down. Suddenly, this strange boy began to chuckle and backed down.

"I like you two. You got guts and stubborn as hell." Daniel and Isabelle smiled and relaxed at this. "My name is Saladeen. Ya can call me Sal or Dean, but don't you never call me Ladee."

"I'm Daniel and this is Is-"

"Isaiah. We're brothers."

"Brothers ay? Ain't got none, sisters neither. Hell I ain't never really even had parents. No worries though, I get by. What you doing here?"

"Me and Isaiah here were out for a little ride. We saw a cottage surprisingly well lit for this hour and just had to check it out."

"I see."
1122112.title: Daniel's New Brother, Isabelle's New Name

choices: Do as he says and leave
Try to take him to safety
11221122.content:
"Where ya two gonna go off to now?" Saladeen asked.

"I suppose we'll just ride around for awhile, then go on home. Don't really have anywhere specific we want to go. What about you, where will you go?" Daniel responded.

"Don't really know. I'll just wander 'round 'til I find somewhere that'll give me work."

"You're going to walk around aimlessly, on foot?" Isabelle, or rather Isaiah, was shocked. The nearest cottage was miles away, even the castle was quite a distance, and on foot it would take all day to reach one and who knows how long to find a place that would actually give him a job.

" O' course. I ain't got no horse likes you two. 'sides, I used to walking 'roud ever'where I go," he casually replied.

"Since, we're going to be riding around in no particular direction, why don't you join us? We'll drop you off at the next cottage," Daniel suggested.

"I s'pose that'd be fine. As long as I don't put you two out. By the way, where do you two call home?"

"We live at the castle and tend to the animals, take care of the stables." Daniel couldn't see how Isabelle could pull off a voice that so easily convince Saladeen that she was a boy.

"That's why you talk so well. You have to talk fancy if you 'round knights and the like all day."

"I guess so, but I'm sure the horses couldn't care less how we talked as long as they get fed," Daniel commented and Isabelle smiled. "Well, I guess we should get going, we don't want to be too far from home when night falls. Saladeen, you can take my horse and Isiah and I will share his, we're used to that."

"Aight." They swiftly mounted their steeds, Isabelle seated behind Daniel just barely on the saddle and they started down the road. With the sun rising higher and higher into the sky, they talked and joked and quickly became friends. It turned out they all had a lot in common, especially in that they all prefered not to do what the adults in their lives wanted them to.

After about half an hour they were startled when a rather bruised and bloody body wearing torn rags stumbled in the road before them. Even more shocking was that Daniel and Isabelle recognized him as one of the servants in the castle. Daniel immediately dismounted and telling Isabelle to stay put went to the fallen man.

"Dillan, what happened?"

"Daniel, is that you? Thank God I've found you. Is the princess with you, I cannot see that well?" Daniel was glad that he spoke so quietly otherwise they would have to explain everything to Saladeen, unfortunately it meant Dillan was nearly out of strength.

"The castle...the castle was attacked late last night. You and the young princess must have just left, you are lucky for that. The king and queen immediately knew that the two of you must have gone out and when they had a moment to spare they sent me to find you, to tell you that you must not return to the castle. Our defenses... just could not hold against Radigan, his sorcery and black magic was just too powerful. They t-told me to tell you that you must protect the princess. You two must lay low, hide until a later time when an army can be ra-raised to reclaim the castle."

He had to stop as he was overtaken with a nasty coughing fit. Daniel was just about to go to get him some of their water when Dillan grabbed his arm. "You must protect the princess. If the king and queen fall, she will be our only hope."

Daniel opened his mouth to say something, but was interrupted as they heard the sounds of nearing hooves on the ground. "I've been followed, you must go now. Now!"

"But what about you? We can't just leave you he-"

"Go now! Protect the princess! It is too late for me. Save yourselves!"
11221122.title: Homeless

choices: She hears noises all around her and blacks out
She waits perfectly still in the water to see who it is
112211222.content:
"We will not leave you. Saladeen, help me get him on one of the horses," Daniel commanded. Both Saladeen, with a look of mild confusion and slight curiousity, and Isabelle slide from the saddles of their steeds. Isabelle held the reins of the horses looking on with concern as Saladeen made his way to where Dillan layed and Daniel began trying to get a grip on him so tht he could bring him to his feet.

Mustering all his remaining strength, Dillan shoved Daniel from him knocking him to the ground. "Go!" He didn't know what to do, Daniel couldn't just leave him there, but he obviously wouldn't let him help either. Saladeen had just reached Daniel when the two horses began to buck and nay with Isabelle frantically trying to hold onto the reins and calm them. Unfortunately none of them saw the three riders until they were dismounting and coming after them. One unsheathed his sword and ordered them to kneel, whether or not he knew who they were they couldn't tell, all they knew was that they had no choice but to obey him.

On one knee with their heads bowed, none of them could see anything of the riders but their feet as they hovered over them. Feeling around her, Isabelle felt a rough, rather large rock and without thinking, jumped to her feet and slammed the rock into the face of the man before her with as much force as she could. At the same moment the rider hovering above Daniel had been raising his sword to strike Daniel, who took the opportunity of the distraction to swing his leg around kicking the man's feet right out from under him. Following suit Saladeen punched the thrid man in the gut and when he fell the his knees locked his arms around his throat cutting off the air until his body fell limp. Daniel had immediately taken the first riders sword and ended his life. Isabelle had also done away with the last rider with a a club she had picked up after dropping the rock, and with her eyes closed was still blindly swinging it unaware that she no longer had a target. Exhausted she dropped the club and fell to her knees to rest.

Retrieving the swords from the remaining two men Saladeen remembered the badly bruised servant and went to examine him. "Daniel, I don' tink he made it. Durin' he fighting he must o' kicked the bucket. Sorry." Daniel bowed his head with exhaustion and with mourning. "We'd better get out of here before more come," he said at last.

They strapped the swords to the saddles and mounted. Deciding it would be best to get off the path, they made their way into the forest. At dusk they found themselves beside a river and made up their minds to rest there for the night before following the river in the morning. Saladeen it seemed was quite adept at living in the outdoors and while he started a fire and set up camp Daniel and Isabelle unpacked the meager portion of food they had thought to bring (it would barely be enough for a late night snack).

With the fire roaring Isabelle noticed for the first time that all their clothes had blood on them, suprisingly hers was stained the most. "I'm going to go get some water and tried to wash off all this blood." Halfway through the sentence Isabelle remembered that she was supposed to be using a male voice, but fortunately Saladeen had not noticed.

"Isaiah wait up, I need to tell you something." Isabelle waited as Daniel walked up to her and whispered so that Saladeen would not hear. "I've got some bad news. You probably noticed that it was Dillan, one of the castle servants back there on the road. It seems that after we left last night," he paused unsure how to break it to her, "it seems that...that the castle was attacked. Their defenses were failing, and your parents sent Dillan to warn us not to go back. Isabelle, we'll figure something out. I'm sure your parents are ok, we'll find them. I promise."

"I see. Well, I really need to wash this blood off and we all need our sleep. So if you'll excuse me." She turned around and walked a short distance to a secluded part of the riverbed with tears in her eyes. Isabelle sat with her arms around her knees for a time before wiping her eyes and taking a deep breath. She removed the hat from her head allowing her hair to fall where it would across her back and in her face and plunged it into the cold water scrubbing away the blood. Once she had cleaned off as much of the blood from the hat as she could, she hung it on a tree branch to dry before beginning to strip the rest of her clothes to do the same.

The night was pleasantly warm and Isabelle decided to take a dip in the river to wash away the dirt, blood, and the events of the day. Stepping into the cool water, Isabelle shivered for a few moments before her body adjusted to the cold and started to relax. She closed her eyes and submerged her head washing away the blood, dirt, and tears. When her head returned to the surface of the water and night air she heard the crackling of breaking twigs and leaves nearby.
112211222.title: Clean

choices: They tell him the whole truth and nothing but the truth
They tell him a bold faced lie
1122112222.content:
"Hey, Isaiah. What's takin' ya so long? Did ya fall in the river 'n drown or something'?" came the recognizable voice of Saladeen from the shadows, his form quickly following. He stopped when he saw Isabelle in the water. "Looks to me like ya did fall in, and ya turned into a girl." More joking to himself than addressing Isabelle. "So, who are you?"

"My name is Isabelle," she replied hoping that he wouldn't recognize her and soon leave. It didn't seem that he recognized her, but he didn't leave either, instead he moved closer to the edge of the water. "Who are you? And what may I ask are you doing all the way out here?" Isabelle tried to act as casual as she could, which was hard considering that the water was quite clear and she was competely nude. She was also trying not to sink as she had her arms crossed over her chest hoping that he would not see her naked body.

"The name's Saladeen but you can call me Sal, or Dean, but don't ever call me Lad..." his voice trailed off as his eyes fell upon Isaiah's clothes hanging on a tree branch. Isabelle followed his gazed and silently cursed to herself, now he was going to find out and she'd have a lot of explaining to do and he'd probably ditch them not wanting to get involved or else start fawning over her like everyone else does which would just drive her completely insane. "You see, the reason I'm out here," he began, not taking his eyes from the hanging clothes, "is that I am looking for a friend of mine." Saladeen finally peeled his eyes from the clothes and stared directly into Isabelle's eyes, who found herself unable to look away. "He goes by Isaiah, is 'bout yay high," he gestured to a height just above his shoulder, "wears a hat and is covered in a lot o' dirt."

"Saladeen, Isaiah, what is taking you two so long? We need to get some rest and try to get out of here at day break before any more of those men find us. And..." Daniel stopped dead in his tracks when he saw Saladeen staring at Isabelle who was no longer disguised as a boy. "What's going on here? Saladeen?"

"Oh Daniel, good o' you ta join us. I just met Isabelle here, and was askin' her if she's seen Isaiah. Isaiah - I mean Isabelle, was just about to answer. Weren't ya?" Saladeen never moved his eyes from Isabelle's.

Isabelle sighed and rolled her eyes. "Alright, I'l explain everything, but do you mind giving me my clothes so I can get out of the water and we can move into the light and warmth of the fire?" Saladeen's eyes opened wide with the realization that she was naked and that he had been staring at her for quite awhile now. He turned his back and went to the campsite. Daniel retrieved the clothes from the branch and held them out to Isabelle with his back turned. "You know its all-"

"Don't say a word Daniel. I had to get the blood off, its not my fault," she interrupted him as she yanked the clothes from his hands and hastily threw them on, once again disguising herself like a young man even though there was no longer a need since Daniel and Saladeen were the only other peope around and they knew she was no boy. Together they went back to their makeshift campsite and sat down around the fire with Saladeen. He merely sat there waiting for them to tell him why Isabelle had been cross dressing.
1122112222.title: Saladeen, meet Isabelle

choices: They wake early and set off without any complications
Something interrupts their sleep in the middle of the night
11221122222.content:
Isabelle, her clothes soaked anew (her hat especially from absorbing the moisture from her hair) sat considerably closer to the fire than either Daniel or Saladeen trying to dry her water chilled bones, her arms wrapped around herself for warmth. "We weren't lying when we said we lived at the castle tending to the stables and the animals, its merely that we no longer do. One of the king's advisors had it in his head that we were trouble, and one way or another he found a way to throw us out. Of course no one dared stand up to a king's advisor, seeing as how his orders usually come from the king."

"Also, we are brother and sister," Daniel continued, used to creating stories on the spot to tell people at home, "it just seemed to make sense to travel as two boys rather than risk mercenaries viewing us as vulnerable and setting their sights on Isabelle, though she is anything but vulnerable."

"As you can see we did not have enough time to collect any supplies on our way out, and when we met you we were looking for somewhere to stay. Then Dillan showed up, but that did not change much."

"Dillan was a fellow servant at the castle. He informed us that the castle was attacked late last night and fell to the forces of Radigan. Its really a miralce he escaped and got as far as he did. But all that means now, is that there is definately no chance whatsoever to return to the castle, not until Radigan is defeated, which who knows how long that could take. Now, that we've got that all sorted out, I suggest we get to sleep so we can leave before any more of his minions find us." Saladeen seemed to accept there explanation, at least for now and he and Daniel stood to go to sleep on the brushed off saddle blankets and leaves and branches that made up their beds. Isabelle remained by the fire still soaking wet, and, now that she was alone, shivering, for she did not want Daniel to worry or to appear weak before Saladeen.

The blazing fire danced and entranced Isabelle that she barely even noticed the cold seeping into her every being. Shadows surrounded her, cast by the flames of the fire, that she could not see the shadow looming behind her reaching towards her head. A moment later a hand reached out and took the hat from her head. "Hey!" she harshly whispered, hoping not to disturb the sleep of her companions, and jerked her head around. "Saladeen, what are you doing?"

"Ya gonna get sick 'n die in them wet clothes."

"Thank you for putting it so delicately Saladeen."

"It's the truth 'n ya know it." Saladeen stepped into the light of the fire and sat down beside Isabelle, who was now able to see him saw that he had no shirt on. "Take me shirt, change inta somethin' dry. Leave of the hat, and let ya hair dry too. I'd give ya me pants, but then I'd be walking 'round completely neked."

"But what about you? Won't you be cold without your shirt?"

"Naw, I'm used to sleepin' out in the cold, once I did have ta sleep without no clothes outside. And let me tell you, it weren't atall conforteble with all them twigs 'n rocks 'n leaves 'n bugs."

"Thank you Saladeen." He began to walk away as Isabelle changed her shirt, it was too big for her, but she was used to wearing boys clothing that did not fit. "By the way," Isabelle gently called after him, he turned around and waited for the rest, "I've noticed that sometimes you speak perfectly proper, and other times it gets difficult to know exactly what it is you're talking about. Could you explain?"

"Well, don't tell nobody, but I have had some schoolin'. There was this girl at one of the places I worked, she lived there for awhile, well she decided to help me learn some stuff. So I started to learn to talk well 'mong other things, but in between lessons I had to talk like I was stupid, 'cause otherwise my sentences really would make no sense, half proper, half stupid. So, she taught me to talk all nice 'n respecable like, but there ain't no one gonna believe a lowly little homeless servant like me talkin' so good. It's just easier to talk like I ain't got no sense. 'Sides, it's lots a fun watchin' the faces o' nobles and such when I talk to 'em like this 'n they have no idea what I say."

"I suppose I see. It is sort of like me and dressing like a boy, I could dress like a girl and get all dolled up if I so choose, but its just easier, not to mention more comfortable this way."

"Exactly, well I'll bid ya good night then young sir."

Isabelle smiled, "Good night." In a few moments all were asleep and the forest fell silent except for the occassional cricket's song or owl's hoot.
11221122222.title: Confessions

choices: someone emerges from the woods onto the path before them
112211222221.content:
In the early hour of dawn before the sun had completely emerged from beyond the horizon Isabelle awoke. She was used to waking early in order to sneak out of the castle before anyone saw her, so she was rested, refreshed, and wide awake. Isabelle sat up and remembered that Saladeen had given her his shirt to wear over night. The fire was still burning, though significantly less brightly as the night before and it had thoroughly dried her shirt and hat. Daniel and Saladeen were both still asleep so she was free to change without fear of either of them seeing her. As she put on her shirt and hat and dirtied her face with dirt and ash, Isabelle let Saladeen's shirt finish drying and warming by the fire. Once Isabelle felt she again looked like a young man she retrieved the shirt and draped it over Saladeen's chest.

Isabelle sat by the fire watching it slowly extinguish and when only the glowing embers were left and the sun in the sky she rose. Seeing that both boys were still deep in sleep she thought, Those two. How can they sleep so late? And I thought my ladies in waiting and the other ladies of the court were lazy, and she decided to explore the immediate vicinity of their campsite. A few yards away she found some berries that looked exactly like those sometimes served at the castle. She washed them in the river and packed them in one of the saddle bags after tasting a few for herself, all the while listening and humming a tune along with the birds singing good morning.

With the fire completely extinguished and not a sign of heat left in the fire pit, Isabelle was ready - not to mention eager - to get going. An amusing idea in her head Isabelle hid behind the horses and called out, first in her own voice, "Daneil! Saladeen! Hlep me! No! Ahhh!" then in a much deeper raspier voice, "Shut up girl, don't make me hurt you. Radigan wants you alive." Daniel and Saladeen awoke with a start and leap to their feet frantically looking around.

"Where is she?"

"I don't know."

"If anything happens to her I'll never forgive myself."

"We'll find her. We have to."

"Well, good morning boys. A girl could get kidnapped," Isabelle smirked as she walked from behind the horses, "waiting for you two to wake up. You're just lucky I know how to take care of myself. Oh and I found some berries and packed them along with a canteen of water in the saddle bags."

"Isabelle don't you ever do that to me again," Daniel sternly commanded. Saladeen simply smiled and mounted his horse. Daniel mounted his shortly after and helped Isabelle onto the saddle behind him. None of them talked for awhile, they merely rode in silence. After an hour or so Saladeen finally broke the silence.

"That was a brilliant prank Isabelle. Our faces musta been a sight ta see."

"They truly were." They both laughed.

"That was not at all funny. Do you have any idea how much trouble we'd be in if you really had been kidnapped, and what if it was Radigan?"

"Calm down Daniel. It was just a joke." Saladeen couldn't know how much danger the kingdom would be in if Radigan did get a hold of her. Isabelle knew, but she was not yet prepared to accept that possiblity, so she just smiled and shrugged it off.

The road to the forest was wide at first and for the first half of an hour riding was easy and unobstructed. However as the two rode on thin pine branches and leaves began to brush their arms. And within a few minutes it became neccessary for the two riders to dodge and duck branches that would have otherwise dismounted them. "Well now look what you've done, you 'ave led us astray!" he smiled, Isabelle knew he was joking and was not worried in the least, he told her many stories of his hikes into the woods. Encountering theives, drunkards and wild animals. However she was afraid.
112212.title: The path narrows...

113.content:
"Why do I have to go to another one of my parents' balls?" Isabelle asked herself as she walked the long hall to the throne room. "Maybe I can finally persuade them to allow me to miss this one." She reach the tall elegant doors and took a deep breath before entering. "Mom, dad, I want to talk to you about something," she started, but when Isabelle looked up she realized that she was talking to herself, her parents were not present. "Hmm," it wasn't that surprising that they were not there, they were always off attending to some kind of buisness here and there around the castle. Isabelle turned around and walked out. She questioned the first servant she say, "Excuse me."

"Yes, your Highness? Is there something I can do for you?" he asked after a short bow.

"Yes, do you know where my parents are?"

"I'm sorry your Highness, but at the moment I am unaware of the whereabouts of their Magesties the King and Queen. Would you like for me to find them for you?"

"No, no. That's quite alright. I should be able to find them," she thanked the servant before setting off to find her find her parents.
113.title: Where Are My Parents?

1131.content: Isabelle runs around the castle looking for her parents. She finds Queen Jasmine in her dressing room, putting her hair up in a bun. Isabelle stands leaning against the door frame, waiting for her mum to turn around and see her. When Queen Jasmine turns around, she starts reeling off questions asking "why arn't you getting ready?" and other similar things. Isabelle isn't going to let this opportunity go, like she has with so many others and says to her mum " Why do I have to go? I would much rather stay here." Queen Jasmine looks at Isabelle and decides that the girl looks a bit feverish and tells her that she can stay home but has to stay in her room. 1131.title: The Dressing Room

11312.content:
Isabelle watched her parents' carriage drive off into the distance. Not long after she lost sight of them, she quickly sought out Daniel. It didn't take long for her to find him.

"Getting your horse ready to lose?" she asked playfully.

"You didn't go to the ball?" Daniel asked as he fed one of the king's prized horses.

"No, my parents actually let me stay home, can you believe that? Now come on, there's a race to run. Or should I say, a race for you to lose?"

"You're on, Princess," Daniel smiled, and the two teenagers were off.

They followed the same course as always. Start at the stables, across the King's field, to the forrest's edge, and back. They never dared venture into the forrest. Rumor had it the place was haunted. Others said it was cursed. Still others claimed that the forrest was where criminals were sent. It was an agreement between Isabelle and Daniel not to go into the forrest.

The race started off as usual, the two teens neck and neck. Both spurned their horses on, trying to outdo the other. Isabelle got a slight lead as they passed Queen Jasmine's garden. That's when it happened. A fox jumped out of the garden, scaring Isabelle's horse, sending it horribly off-course. The princess had lost control of it, as it careened towards the forrest.

"NOOO!" Isabelle screamed, trapped on her now out of control horse. Daniel urged his horse on, trying in vain to catch up to Isabelle. He finally caught up to his friend. He reached out and grabbed the reins to Isabelle's horse and jerked them hard. The horse began to slow down gradually, and finally stopped a few yards away.

The two teens got off of their horses and breathed sighs of relief. Then they noticed where they were.

"Oh no, we're in the forrest," Daniel said.

Isabelle replied, "Yeah, we should probably..."
11312.title: Out of Control

choices: The King and Queen catch them in the stable
113121.content:
"We should probably leave," Isabelle said, both shaken by the race gone wrong and by the forest itself.

"Yeah, I suppose," Daniel said. The two teens motioned their steeds out of the forest and back out into the lush field. Darkness was now taking over, and Daniel and Isabelle quickly headed back to the stables.

"That was freaky," Isabelle said. "I've never had that happen before."

"Yeah, I can't imagine what was going through your mind," Daniel said. After a pause, he added, "that being said, I still won the race."

"Come on, that didn't count!" Isabelle said as they dismounted from their horses.

"Oh it counts," Daniel said.

"Whatever."

"We should go back tomorrow," Daniel said. "To the forest that is."

1132.content:
After a half hour of searching unsuccessfully, Isabelle realized that she wouldn't be able to wander the entire castle by herself looking, so she began asking the servants. She asked eveyone if they knew where her parents were and when they didn't know she asked them to help her search. Within an hour the entire staff was searching for the King and Queen.

"Have you found them yet?" Isabelle inquired of a couple of servants.

"Sorry your Highness, but we still do not know where your parents are," they bowed their heads in remorse.

After several hours, it was concluded that the King and Queen were gone, and that no one knew where they were.

Princess Isabelle was quite perturbed. She was sitting on her parents' bed wondering what had happened to her parents. They weren't on any diplomatic missions or any pleasure trips. And what was she to do if they never returned? Isabelle wasn't ready to be Queen and she knew it.

Luckily her thoughts were interupted by a servant entering her parents' bed chamber. "Pardon the intrusion your Highness."

"Yes, what is it?"

"Madame, we have found no sign of what fate has befallen the King and Queen. What is it that you would like us to do next?"

What was she supposed to say - Isabelle wasn't ready to give out such orders. She never paid attention to what her parents did when they were working. "Well, I suppose...I mean, summon my father's advisors immediately. Have them meet me in my father's conference room, there is much to discuss.... You are dimissed."

He bowed and left. Well, that didn't go too badly. Isabelle was going to have to get used to all this. Until her parents' return she would have to be in charge.
1132.title: Taking Charge

11321.content:
That night Isabelle's sleep was plagued with horrible nightmares of what may have befallen her parents. Fortunately, she was awoken early that morning when the advisors finally arrived. She got dressed and went to the conference room. "Good morning."

They all stood as she entered the room, "Good morning your Highness."

She sat at the head of the table and motion for them to sit. There were about 8 advisors. Isabelle had often seen them in here at the exact same seats the were now. The only difference was that is was her father sittng wher she now sat. Even though she had often seen them and even sat in during some of the discussions, she knew none of their names. As she sat there in her reverie the advisors began agruing on what to do. She didn't even notice until it got too loud for her to think.

"Silence," she comanded.

They were all stunned, none of them thought she had it in her. "Sorry, M'Lady," one of them spoke.

"That's fine, but we do have a lot to talk about and it might go better if everyone wasn't speaking at once."

"Yes your Highness."

"Where should we begin? What should be done?"

The room immediately erupted in discussion once again. This time Isabelle stayed silent looking around the room. After a few minutes the advisors finally caught on that she was waiting and they quieted.

One finally spoke, "Well, I think that we should try to keep this all quiet. If the kingdom found out that the King and Queen are missing there will be mass hysteria."

"I don't think so," another argued. "The people should know. Maybe one of them knows somehting."

A third then chimed in, "I agree, besides they will catch on when we assemble the army. They'll know somehting is going on.

A fourth, "Who said anything about assembling the army?"

"Think about it. The King and Queen may have been kidnapped. We are vulnerable to attack with them missing."

"With the King and Queen gone, Princess Isabelle would be left as high commander of the army. Assembly the army will unnerve neighboring kingdoms, they may even think we are preparing to attack them and make the first move and attack us, and, no offense your Highness, but she is no where near ready for a full scale war."

"None taken," she replied. Since, the advisors were once again arguing, almost screaming at each other, she sat in silence waiting. After several more minutes they caught on and ceased their arguements.

"What do you think your Highness?"
11321.title: Discussion

113211.content:
"Well, after listening to your arguements I believe it would be best to try to keep this disappearance hidden from the people as long as possible. Also, it might be best to assemble the army. I only know of a few of the dangers that may befall this kingdom and I believe that we need to take that precaution. If there are rumors or if the people begin to worry, then, we'll have to cross that bridge when we come to it," Isabelle explained.

All the advisors agreed, proud of how well she was coping and taking charge.

"I just have one question. There was supposed to be a ball in less than a week. I'm not sure if we should cancel or what."

"Well, cancelling might cause some people to wonder and it may cause some fear."

"Yes, but if the King and Queen do not show to the ball, that may also cause some fear, and people will want to now why they are not there."

Isabelle thought for a moment while the advisors watched her expectanly.

"I think," she began, "that we will go along with ball. We will continue with it as if nothing is wrong. If when the time comes we feel it better to cancel the ball then we will. Until then, we will continue on with buisness as usual, and I will carry out my father's duties with you all there to guide me."

No one disagreed. Once, the loose ends were tied up Isabelle dismissed them and returned to her bed chamber.
