1432.content:
The treehouse was empty. Isabelle felt tears springing to her eyes - he was completely gone! She pushed off the narrow, wooden ledge and toppled down to the ground, ignoring the sudden (but not too terrible) pain in her right arm. Once again, she checked the stables: no Daniel. She checked the fields: no Daniel. He had disappeared. It was not his day off, which only came round at the end of the month, and he had definitely not been given a different duty that day. He had already told her it was the day for cleaning the stables, and that always took most of his working hours.
"Adam!" she called, recognising a farmer approaching, "have you seen Daniel, the stableboy?" She hurried forward, and stopped Adam in his tracks. He frowned.
"Danny? Aye, I seen 'im. Round the back of the 'ouse 'e is, with some 'ousemaid, playin' a game o' tag if I remember correctly. Aye, 'e seemed quite fond of 'er. Pretty little lass, she is." He smiled and strolled on into the fields, smoking a thin cigarette. Isabelle was rooted to the ground. Daniel with a housemaid? 'Fond of her'? It wasn't possible. Daniel only ever spoke to the housemaids when he was with the princess! And he couldn't be fond of anyone; the only girl he spent any amount of time with was Isabelle! She tearfully ran away from the stables to the palace. The back gardens were walled, but she simply pushed the heavy door wide and burst in.
1432.title: Do you trust a farmer?

14322.content:
"Daniel?"
Isabelle pushed through the gate, fearful of what Adam said lay behind.

"Oh, hello Isabelle." Daniel stood up, still holding a dirt streaked carrot and brushing off his knees. "Hungry?" he asked, holding the dirty carrot out to her with a grin. "Daniel, I... where is she?" Isabelle looked at him, her eyes wet. "Who?" he asked, stepping towards her with a confused look. "The maid, the pretty little maid. Adam said you were chasing a maid around the garden. And what are you doing picking vegetables? You said you were working in the stables today!"

"Isabelle, you and I both know that Adam has seen brighter days. Not a night goes by that he's not kicking back the tankards in the tavern down the road. A knock on the head back in the old wars didn't do too well for his mental clarity either.. He's just an old man conjuring up stories of pretty maids, nothing more. He asked me to pick the rest of these vegetables until he got back." Daniel took another step forward and placed his hand on her shoulder. "Besides, you know you're the prettiest girl around here anyway"

Isabelle looked away, embarrassed by the redness to her cheeks after his compliment. "What are you doing down here?" he asked, suddenly aware that his hair wasn't as straight as he would have liked.

"Oh, I was just.. well,I.." Isabelle fought for words, kicking the dirt with one foot.

"What? You were just what? Come on, Isabelle, you know you can tell me anything,"

"Well, I.. I want to run away." Isabelle blurted it out, knowing that if she didn't say it fast, she wouldn't say it at all. "And I... I want you to come with me."
14322.title: Adam the Drunk

choices: Adam returns, having eavesdropped on the conversation.
Adam returns, none the wiser... the two friends continue the plan.
143221.content:
"Really? You want to run away?" Daniel was amazed, he knew she wasn't happy where she was, but he'd never thought she would do something to drastic.

"Yes, really. I've thought it over as much as I'm going to, I want you to come with me. I'm sick of this place, and all it's... rules. I'm tired of being expected to do so much, I want to have fun and see something outside of these walls. Something other than dresses, and dances, and.. expectations." Isabelle found herself telling him everything, all that she had kept to herself for years and years. The two of them sat in the shaded garden on a wooden bench and talked into the day. Well, Isabelle talked, Daniel sat and listened.

"So, are you coming with me or not?" Isabelle leaned in closer to him, willing him to say yes. "Isabelle, you have been my friend for many years now, you know that I am there for you no matter what you decide and if you want to leave this place, I can find no other way but to go with you." Immediately, Daniel stood up from the bench, grabbed a sack from the garden wall, and began to fill it with vegetables.

Isabelle stood, confused at his quick decision. She knew he was a good friend, but she had expected to have to talk him into it a little more. "But, Daniel.. what about your job? Aren't you worried to leave it?"

"My job? What job? I clean dung out from under sweaty warhorses all day. I'd just as soon hang myself from the parapet than live in this castle for the rest of my days, there are no adventures in the life of a stableboy." Daniel looked back at her, seeing the worry etched into her face. "Listen, if you want to do this, we're going to have to have a plan. A princess doesn't just leave her father's castle, she either stays or is kidnapped. A stableboy caught with the king's daughter will not be treated as a friend of the family, if you know what I'm getting at."

"Gather all you need and meet me here at midnight tonite, we can sneak out of the castle through the postern gate; they don't guard it heavily, I know."

Isabelle was scared, but terribly excited. "Thank you Daniel, I'll go pack right now." She grabbed his hand and smiled at him, looking into his eyes for a moment before turning swiftly into the deepening shadows of dusk and disappearing behind the swinging wooden gate.

Daniel wiped the nervous sweat from his brow and bent back towards the vegetable patch. If Adam returned and found his vegetables not picked, he'd... well, he would be too drunk for much action, but Daniel decided they'd be better picked anyway.
143221.title: A Plan!

choices: Adam helps Daniel prepare for the escape
Adam takes Daniel to the guards, telling them of his plan.
1432211.content:
Daniel listened as Isabelle made her way across the courtyard back into the great hall, where she would no doubt be reprimanded by her mother for being out after dark.

Her father though was far too busy to concern himself with such trivial matters, he sat amongst his captains in his war room, his attentions fixed on the war against Radigan, the evil sorcerer and dictator over the lands of Aarnim. His raids had grown bolder with each passing day, pushing further into Edward's kingdom of Iylonra. Iylonra's armies had fought hard over the months of war, but Radigan had a seemingly endless supply of mindless soldiers. He cared not how many men he lost, so long as the land was his.

"Is it not enough?!" King Edward slammed his armored fist firmly down upon the oaken table. He was a large man, tall and broad with thick red hair and deep green eyes. His face was canyoned with deep wrinkles and old scars. He looked much older than he was, though still with a youthful air. He wore his finest armor, newly polished and draped with a dark green cape of thick wool. At his side hung a sword, old and battered, but deadly in the King's mighty hands. "Radigan has taken all the land from the south-eastern shores to the peaks of the central mountains and yet he still knocks upon my door, greedily waving his sword for more! Our allies have all been crushed. If Radigan could not bend them to his will through his false protectorate, he crushed them by the sword."

"What is the status of our armies, Sir Thomas?" King Edward nodded over to the armored soldier sitting at the table across from him. Thomas sat up straighter, clearing his throat. "My liege, our southern army is stretched across those borders and has suffered severe loses. I've sent word for them to regroup further north at the city of Ferth and hold that ground until reinforcements arrive. Sir Donovan is a fine leader and will hold out."

"And what of the armies to the west?"
"Sir Andrew and Bernard have not given news of their status since their defeat at Rindall, but I have sent riders to speed the word, my liege."
King Edward nodded solemnly. Sir Thomas' report was not what he had needed to hear, but he could not ignore it.

"Send conscription notices at once to all the cities and towns in the land. As much as it tears my heart, every able-bodied man and boy will be needed in this battle." With a nod and a wave of his hand, King Edward gave his captains their leave and silently sat, pondering his next move.


------------------------------------------------------------------------
"Ah yes, an adventure!" Daniel silently thought to himself, as he knelt down to tug the ripe vegetables from the dark soil.

He couldn't help but smile at the prospect of leaving the castle, especially seeing as Isabelle had asked him along. He'd known her since he had first come to the castle as a boy, had helped teach her to ride the royal horses, in fact. He chuckled to himself, remembering those first few times, she in her tiny, stiff court dresses trying to mount the huge beasts. She had fallen more than once, though she'd never allowed it to sway her. She was tough, strong, and she almost seemed to enjoy the dirt that had clung heavily to her velvet clothes.


"'ello there boy, finished picking me veggies 'ave ye?" Daniel was startled back to reality by Adam's drunken voice.

Daniel looked nervously over to the dozens of vegetables still planted firmly in the ground. "Ah, yes, all pulled and stored away for the day. Well, save for those... they were too, er.. Those weren't quite ripe."

Adam bent to inspect the plants, "Eh? They look a'ight to me." He looked up at Daniel, putting a hand on the ground to steady himself.
"May'aps you've spent valuable time conversin' with pretty maids rather than work, eh?"

"Oh Adam, dreaming of pretty maids again are ya? I've been by myself this whole time." Daniel attempted to play at innocence, busily grabbing tools and putting them into the shed built against the castle wall.

"No no, I seen ya." Adam lifted himself heavily from the ground, not bothering to brush off the dirt. "Princess and you got all sorts o' plans eh?"

"And here I am, thinking you've been off drinking yourself into a stupor when really you've been sneaking about in the shadows spying on myself and Isabelle. Adam, you really are a sneak." Daniel looked at Adam crossly, shaking his head as though he were a mother scolding her child.

"Danny, I 'ave been drinkin' meself silly, onliest reason I 'eard you two lovies scheming was your voice, bouncin' 'round this keep with excitement. Myself, I'm surprised the wallguards 'aven't locked you both up by now."

They both shook with laughter, trying now to keep their voices low in the darkness. Adam placed his hand on Daniel's shoulder, "Son, if'n you want to 'scape this place with your pretty lady, you're needin' more 'en just a 'ead on your shoulders, summat you 'taint got much of anyways," he laughed again, "'ere, come with me."

Daniel followed Adam's zigzag steps out of the garden, across the courtyard and into the night.
1432211.title: Unpicked Vegetables

14322112.content:
Adam, muttering drunkly to himself, led Daniel across the feilds. Daniel was absorbed in his own thoughts, thinking of the adventure they'd have. He did not realize where the drunken farmer was taken him.
"Sir Andrew," Adam called. a knight, clad in shining armor and a black cloak, trotted over on his horse. Daniel franicly tried to squirm away as Adam described the conversation he overheard.
14322112.title: The Guards

143221121.content:
"Thank you, Adam," Andrew said, cooly. "I apreciate your report."
The farmer muttered something and staggered off.
Sir andrew dismounted his horse and storde over to Daniel, who refused, at all cost, to show the fear that gripped inside of him.
"Is that true, lad?" andrew asked.
should he lie?
143221121.title: At the gate

choices: Andrew takes him to the king
1432211212.content:
what was the point of lying?
Daniel stood tall, his chin lifted. "Yes," he said, "We are both sick and tired of this life, and we are not going to stay one more day!"
Andrew raised an eyebrow. "With that attitude, you might," he said, coldly. Daniel was startled by the sudden ice in his voice. "do you think this is a wise move, lad?" he asked. "If they catch you out there with the king's daughter, there's no telling what they'd do to you."
"i understand."
"Well?"
"we're leaving."
Andrew sighed. "Then you leave me no choice."
1432211212.title: Resistence

14322112122.content:
Daniel took a breath. this was it. their plans had been crushed.
Andrew strode into the stables, leading a saddled horse. "here," he said. "And i'll just prepare another one for Isabelle."
Daniel's jaw dropped. "You're...you're not turning us in?"
Andrew shook his head. "I pity any soul who is forced to live the life a princess, especialy Isabelle."
Daniel couldn't believe his ears.
"And you want to be a kinght, don't you? you're not going anywere by being a lowly stable boy. this is your chance, lad. use it well!"
Daniel finally got his jaw to work. "Thank you, so much!"
Andrew smiled. "Get some sleep," he said. "T's going to be a big journey in front of you."
14322112122.title: Good Luck!

143221121221.content:
Daniel lay on his cot, thinking about the great adventure he was about to embark on with Isabelle. As a boy, he'd always dreamed of adventures. He used to play with Isabelle and they would make up stories and quests. Daniel had never though that he'd get a chance at adventure. But here he was, on the Eve of what would probably be the greatest adventure of his life. And he would have Isabelle there with him, which was more than anyone could ask for.

Isabelle was his greatest friend. She always had been and he knew she always would be. At one time, he had hoped that maybe they could be more than friends. But a princess and a stableboy? It would never work. One could always dream, however.

Daniel began to think of where they would go, what they would do, who they would see. Would there be danger? Would there be peril? Would there be fun. Probably yes, to all of those. It only excited him more.

A noise from outside made Daniel sit up. It was almost midnight, that was probably Isabelle coming. He grinned and grabbed his packs, running to the horses he had hid in the stables. He'd already gotten them ready for a journey. He'd packed as much food and clothing and supplies as he could. He only wished he could find a weapon to bring. The only thing he had was a small dagger. What good would a dagger do against the dangers they were bound to face?

There was a knock on the stable door. Daniel grinned and called out a soft, "Yes?"

The door opened.
143221121221.title: Ready to Leave

choices: On Isabelle's way to the castle
While Daniel is grooming the horses
15.content:
"I shall beat you in the next race Daniel."

"You say that every time I win." Daniel and Isabelle enter the stables leading their horses by their reins. Isabelle handed her reins to Daniel, who lead them into their respective stalls and unsaddled them, while Isabelle stepped into an empty stall.

"You know Daniel, I am the princess. Shouldn't you let me win?"

"We have known each other all our lives, the normal codes of conduct do not apply to us. Besides, you my dear are anything but the typical princess and I dare not insult you by treating you as such."

"You are just a sore loser Daniel, and you know it." Isabelle emerged from the stall in an elaborately embroidered, purple dress. Daniel began brushing one of the horses they had previously been riding. Isabelle gave both horses several carrots and had just picked up a brush to groom the other horse with when Daniel immediately stopped her.

"Isabelle, you put that brush down right now. I shouldn't have even let you feed the horses while wearing that dress."

"Why Daniel, was it not but a moment ago that you said you would not dare insult me by treating me as the typical princess?" She put her hands on her hips in playful indignation. Daniel was ready for the challenge, but he mamanged to remain somewhat serious.

"That was before, but now you have dressed the part. Am I misataken or do you not have a formal dinner to attend within the hour with Sirs Anthony and Wallace and their families? Her majesty, your mother, would be more than a little peeved at me for allowing you to sully that dress of yours. Now, do not argue with me, it is high time you went back to the castle to prepare and groom youself a little." Letting her arms fall limp to her sides, Isabelle forced a frown.

"You always get so proper when there is even the smallest risk of my parents getting angry with you."

"They are the king and queen. Now get a move on princess."

"Alright, I will go. I have some time, but I had hoped to stop by the kitchen for a snack before dinner. All that caviar, and mutton, and what not are not as appetizing as you would think." With and short wave Isabelle left the stables and made her way to the castle kitchen while Daniel returned to grooming their horses.
15.title: Grooming

choices: Matty sends the guards for Dylan
Isabelle tries to find out where Dylan came from
151.content:
Managing to make it inside the castle without being swarmed by her ladys in waiting and various other servants, Isabelle approached the doors to the kitchen, only to be greeting by aggravated shouting. It was partially muffled by the closed doors, so Isabelle was only able to catch a few words here and there, among them were, "theif" "vagrant" "miscreant" and "gypsy". Pushing open the door, Isabelle witnessed a small boy cowering in the corner, several loaves of bread and various fruits and vegetables scattered on the floor around him, and the head cook hovering over him shaking a rolling pin with a wild look on her face.

"What is going on in here Matty?" Isabelle shouted to be heard.

"Oh your highness." Startled, Matty dropped the rolling pin almost ontop of the poor child, causing him to jump and curl up into an even tighter ball. She then curtseyed before answering, "Your highness, I found this vagabond attempting to steal castle food. I was just about to call for the guards to have him escorted to the dungeons."

"He is a child Matty, and it looked more like you were frightening him to death. I shall take care of it."

"With all due respect your highness, it would be much safer if you allowed the guards to deal with him."

"Nonsense Matty, it is obvious he is of no danger. He is terrified and half starved. Leave me alone with him."

"Yes your highness." She curtseyed and along with the other servants in the room left. Isabelle carefully walked over the boy and crouched down beside him and gently touched his shoulder. He jumped and backed away from her with a gasp.

"It is alright. I am not going to harm you. Are you hungry?" His hunger, at least for the moment, seemed to outweigh his terror as he fiercely nodded his head. Isabelle gave a little chuckle as she rose to her feet, helped the boy to his, and led him to the table. Once he was seated she retrieved some clean food and placed it in front of him. Smiling as the child inhaled the food before him, Isabelle warned him to slow down so as not to make himself sick, he obeyed.

"I am Isabelle. What is your name?"

With a mouth full of bread he replied, "Dylan." Isabelle sat beside Dylan, contentedly watching him eat his fill. As she watched, she seemed to notice a kind of glow radiating from him, as if this simple meal had replenished his life and soul, and she was glad to have been able to help. After several more minutes Dylan pushed the food from him and his eye lids began to droop.

"Considering how hungry you were, I suppose I can assume that you have not slept in a real bed in quite some time either. Correct?" Dylan very groggily nodded his head. Isabelle took his hand and led him to her room and tucked him into her bed for a restful nap, avoiding as many people as possible on the way.
151.title: Hungry

choices: She runs out into the corridor and...
1511.content:
Isabelle sat in a chair, smiling at the boy's peaceful face. He couldn't have been more than fourteen by the look of it, and obviously hadn't had a meal for days.
a commotion outside in the corridor shook Isabelle from her reverie.
"I swear, he was just right here!" Isabelle could recongize Matty's voice above the clatter of armor.
She hear a sigh and a deep voice, "Well, he's not there now, is he?"
"But he was! he couldn't have moved!"
"Perhaps he escaped."
"no! i won't believe that!"
"what would you propose?"
"Find the dirty little Gypsy and clap 'im in irons!"
1511.title: Corridor talk

choices: Dylan and Jackson leave the castle grounds
1512.content:
Once she had put Dylan to bed Isabelle sent one of the servants to tell her parents that she would not be able to attend dinner with Sirs Anthony and Wallace and their families that night because she had fallen ill, but that they were not to worry for it was not serious and all she needed was a night's rest. That done she had some of the old clothes she used to wear when she went out with Daniel washed, and a warm bath drawn.

Within the hour Dylan awoke. He was startled at first, unable to remember where he was, but Isabelle was waiting at his side to reassure him.

"Shh, it is ok. Do you remember me?"

"Y-yes," was his meek reply.

"There is a warm bath and clean clothes for you in the other room. You do know how to bathe and clothe yourself right?" His cheek flushed ever so slightly as he nodded yes. "Alright then, go right through there and I shall wait for you in here." Dylan went to wash up and within half an hour he emerged looking considerably better - both cleaner and healthier.

"Do you feel better?"

"Y-yes, thank you. What's your name again?"

"I'm Isabelle. How old are you Dylan?"

"Ten."

"Do you have any family?"

"A brother." Dylan gasped and clasped his hands over his mouth.

"What is the matter?"

"He told me to wait... I wasn't supposed to..."

"Calm down. Is he outside, somewhere on the castle grounds?"

"Yes."

"Alright, we shall go look for him. I will be back in a moment." Isabelle stepped into the other room and changed into some old trousers and shirt of Daniel's (one of the sets she usually wears when out with Daniel). When she was dressed she tucked her hair under a cap and lead Dylan through one of the hidden passageways out of the castle. Where should we start first? Dyan's brother could be anywhere. What have they been through that Dylan would try to steal from the castle kitchen? Why are they here? We'd better go see Daniel first, he'll be able to help us locate Dylan's brother.

"Follow me, we shall start at the stables. I have a friend there who can help us. Do you know anywhere your brother might have gone?"

"No."

"Is he younger or older than you?"

"Older, he is seventeen."

"Here are the stables, Daniel will... wait, do you hear that?" There were voices coming from the stables. One was distinguishably Daniel's, but Isabelle did not recognize the other.

"It would be a lot easier if we ask someone, officially get you some work."

"No, please, I would prefer if no one knew I was here."

"Alright, you help me around the stables and I shall split the wages with you. If I find any other work I won't hesitate to tell you."

"That is my brother," Dylan almost shouted before he rushed into the stables.

"Dylan, what are you doing here? I told you to wait out-"

"I was hungry Jackson. And then there was this cook and I thought she was going to beat me. And-"

"Slow down kid, what are you talking about?"

"The cook caught him trying to steal some food from the castle kitchen. Needless to say she was quite upset and wanted to call the guards. Do not worry, she did not. I gave Dylan some food, a bed to take a nap in, a warm bath, and some clean clothes."

"Thank you, umm..."

"Isabelle. It was no trouble at all... Jackson, was it?"

"Yes." Jackson put his arm over Dylan's shoulders.

Then emerging from behind Jackson, Daniel asked, "Shouldn't you be attending that dinner we spoke of earlier? Your parents are not going to be happy."

"You worry too much Daniel. I told them I was not well, you will not be punished, you have done nothing wrong."

"Wait," Jackson interrupted, "Isabelle? As in Princess Isabelle?"

"Unfortunately I have no choice but to say yes, for it is not up to us to which parents we are born." Jackson immediately bowed as low as he could taking Dylan down with him.

"Please rise. You need not bow to me unless nobility or those who are very traditional are around."
1512.title: Dylan and Jackson

choices: Isabelle and Daniel find positions for Dylan and Jackson
There are no open positions so they must unofficially work with Daniel
15122.content:
After getting Jackson and Dylan settled into one of the servants quarters knowing that they would not be noticed among the countless quarters and even more numerous servants, Isabelle swiftly made her way back to the castle and her bed before her parents could see that she had once again skipped her duties in order to go down to the stables.

That morning Isabelle's parents came to check on her and, once she had assured them that she had rested all evening and was again well, they left to spend a few days visiting the various villages in their kingdom and showing the people that they care. Before they left however, they made Isabelle swear to at least try to behave while they were gone.

Isabelle saw them to their carriage and spent the next couple of hours trying to escape the various lady’s maid, butlers, and assorted servants that seemed to be permanently attached to her ankles like dozens of high pitched talking balls and chains that never paused, even to breath. Eventually she was able to remove the chains, dodging into a crowded hallway and disappearing into a passageway hidden away behind one of the many suits of armor.

“I thought my mind would surely explode. With my parents away, I became the only target for their incessant fawning,” Isabelle irately bellowed as she seated herself atop a hay stack opposite the hay stack Daniel was situated upon.

“You oughtn’t to complain. Especially in the future when you are granted with more responsibilities, both in number and importance, their aid will be sorely need. I must also remind you that for now it shall only last for a short while.”

“True, but what shall become of me in the meantime, and in the future when there is no one else around for them to aid. If they could find a way they would do my breathing for me, and I fear that someday soon they may indeed discover a way to do so. However, this is neither the time nor the place for such matters. I hope your room was to your liking.” Isabelle gestured for Jackson and Dylan to seat themselves, but instead they bowed.

“Please, stand up. I believe I told you when first we met that in such informal company you need not bow, and I would much rather prefer you do not. Also, I understand it to be quite inconvenient not to mention uncomfortable for the back to bow so often. Now please sit.” Jackson complied while somehow managing to miraculously looking both a little uneasy and relieved at the same time, but Dylan opted to run around the stables petting all of the horses managing to frighten all but one.

“What kind of positions would you and Dylan be interested in?” Daniel inquired of Jackson as Isabelle, smiling went to join Dylan in petting the pure white stallion in the last stall.

“His name is Elias.”

“He didn’t get scared like the others.”

“I would imagine not. There is nothing to my knowledge that has ever frightened Elias, not even the men who took him from the wild and tried to break his spirit before offering him as a gift to my father.”

“He was taken from the wild?”

“Yes, and at a very young age I’ve been told. I was not much older when he came to us, but I have heard that he never lost his wild spirit even though many believed him too young to remember ever living in the wild. Just look into his eyes, however, and its plain as day that wild spirit still lives on within him.” She looked at the stallion and Dylan witnessed Elias bow his head to Isabelle, who bowed her head in turn, in a mutual display of respect. Looking into Elias’s eyes, Dylan saw that Isabelle was talking about, within those big eyes he saw pride, the same kind of look a beloved king would give to his subjects. “Daniel was the first Elias would let near him and the first to ride him. I was soon allowed the privilege as well. None others have been given the honor of riding him, Daniel and I very rarely ride him, out of respect. He has allowed some more people to get near him, but mostly only other stable hands who must care for him. Elias must like you.”
15122.title: A Horse's Respect

choices: They head off toward their respective duties
They find some other game to play
151221.content:
Isabelle stroked Elias’s mane and she and Dylan rejoined Daniel and Jackson. “I believe we have worked out duties for both Jackson and Dylan. Jackson shall help me in the stables and around the grounds. Dylan can work in the kitchens; you have said that they have been understaffed since Samantha…relocated.”

“Come now Daniel use the correct term. She vanished. Not that working in the kitchens is dangerous business; people have been vanishing from all the kingdoms.”

“Vanished?” Dylan inquired. “Indigo used to vanish all the time.”

“Dylan that is not the kind of vanishing they are speaking of. Indigo vanished into thin air where people could see him, and he always returned.”

“Oh.”

Confused, Daniel and Isabelle looked back and forth between Dylan and Jackson. “Might we be granted an explanation?”

“It depends. What is your king’s disposition in relation to…gypsies?”

“There have been some complaints that my father has had to look into and respond to accordingly, but he has never displayed any outward distaste for them. In fact, I can almost positively say that he enjoys their talents. We have much enjoyed their company at the castle as both guests and paid entertainment. I am quite fond of a certain seer in one of the local bands of gypsies myself.”

“Our mother and father died soon after Dylan’s first birthday. Orphaned and left alone we wandered the expanse of the kingdom of Lain, your neighbor to the northeast. Soon a traveling band of gypsies discovered us and took us in. They raised us as their own. However, little more than a year ago, the king of Lain decided he would no longer put up with the gypsy pests and outlawed anything related to gypsies. One night, the king sent his knights to disband all the gypsies they could find. Dylan and I escaped arrest, but were separated from our family. So we ran. In time, we found your kingdom but stayed in the shadows not knowing your king’s opinion of gypsies. Alas, we could not stay hidden for long. Considering who discovered us, I’d say fortune has taken pity on us.”

“Then fortune has taken pity on us as well,” Daniel announced as he friendly patted Jackson on the back. “We are glad to have met you and are more than willing to welcome two new friends. Lord knows I was beginning to tire of Isabelle’s company.” Looking at Isabelle, Daniel smiled.

“I could have you beheaded for saying that.” Isabelle smiled back as she rose to her feet.

“Ah, the freedom that would grant.”

Vocalizing an incredulous gasp, Isabelle dove for Daniel, knocking them both into a pile of hay behind. A moment later they emerged with straws of hay embedded in their hair and clothing. Unable to control their amusement, Jackson and Dylan burst into laughter and were soon showered with hay as Daniel and Isabelle opted to share their bounty. Still laughing, the four helped each other rid themselves of as much of the hay they could.
151221.title: Jackson's and Dylan's family

1512211.content:
Laughing to the point of tears, the four friends stumbled into the light of a midday sun. Collapsing in the deep green grass to the side of the path leading from the stables to the castle, the laughter gradually faded into a collective sigh. The clouds passed as lazily above as Isabelle, Daniel, Jackson, and Dylan all felt. Hours seemed to pass before any words were spoken; with only the breeze rustling the leaves to break the silence, they appeared to be asleep.

A bell tolling from within the castle called Isabelle back to her body and to the present. Propping herself up on her elbows, Isabelle gently invited the others to join her in reality, “Lunch shall begin shortly. It would be wise for us to give at least the illusion of attending to our duties.”

“Does that mean we get to eat now?” Dylan asked as he excitedly sprang to his feet ready to make a mad dash for the castle.

“Yes Dylan, but I am afraid there is a little work to do before we can eat.” Dylan frowned. “However, you may be able to snatch a few bites while you work in the kitchen.” With that Dylan’s smile quickly returned.

“Come along Dylan, I’ll walk you to the kitchen.” Dylan gladly took Isabelle’s outstretched hand and half skipped, half dragged Isabelle back to the castle.

Daniel draped his arm over Jackson’s shoulders and started for the stables. “We should make sure the horses have fresh water and something to eat.”

“I sincerely appreciate your helping Dylan and I. I do not know how much longer we could have continued on scavenging, trying to survive like that.”

“My pleasure Jackson, however, Isabelle really should be given most of the credit.” Having returned to the stables Daniel tossed a pitchfork into Jackson’s hands. “If you will give the horses some fresh hay and some oats, I will give them fresh water. Then, if there is time, we ought to brush them.”

After working in silence for a few moments Daniel began to whistle a song he could not remember ever learning but came so naturally. Almost immediately, Jackson joined in. This continued for a while, both boys perfectly content despite their strenuous work. Not until Jackson reached Elias’s stall did either even think of saying something, even think a complete thought. “Isabelle was right.”

“Hmm?”

“About Elias. There is something so regal, so commanding in his eyes. There is something else there, but what it is I cannot say. I never would have noticed if not for Isabelle mentioning it to Dylan.”

“Yes, Isabelle has a way about her, a way of seeing things differently than all others.”

“I can see that. She is so unlike any other princess I have ever heard of. Isabelle seems to be more like us than a princess."

“That she does.”

~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~

“Your highness.” Matty, the head cook, curtsied her greeting. An incredulous and bitter expression crossed her face as she saw Dylan peek around from behind Isabelle. “What is that wretch doing back in my kitchen?!”

“Peace Matty. This is Dylan. I understand that you have been short handed since Samantha. Dylan shall fill her position and aid anyway he can in the kitchen.”

“Your highness, I can manage,” Matty interjected, “I really do not think that –“

“It is my will,” Isabelle interrupted her, “that Dylan be allowed to do his share and that he be treated as an equal. If you cannot comply with my wishes than I suggest you seek employment elsewhere. Am I understood Matty?” Matty opened and closed her mouth several times, obviously wanting to erupt into a tirade she has long been withholding but fearing losing her position and the retribution that would undoubtedly accompany insulting the only daughter of the king and queen. "As you wish your highness."
1512211.title: Off to Work

15122112.content:
“Elbows off the table dear. Ladies know better.”

Even though her parents were away for a few days, Isabelle could still picture her mother at the end of the table with her father. “Yes mother,” Isabelle would return. Then aside to herself, “Ladies also know how to live uncomfortably and without any enjoyment.” Though the rectangular table at which they sat was considerably longer than most, it was short enough that even with the king and queen sitting at one end and Isabelle at the other; they did not have to shout to be heard. Lucky for Isabelle the table was long enough that her parents could not hear any of her ireful mutterings. She would smile at her parents and begin eating her soup, careful not to accidentally slurp very loudly and incur another lesson in manners from her mother.

They often had such discussions at meals. Sometimes Isabelle sincerely forgot, but it was far more common for her to purposefully disobey the orders of manners in order to break the silences. Despite the absence of her parents, Isabelle was by no means alone; standing against the wall opposite her stood the many servants who seemed drawn to her by some supernatural force. While she had managed a couple hours freedom from them, it appeared impossible to avoid them for very long.

As one of the servants took away her nearly empty bowl of soup – she hardly ever had enough time to finish the food in front of her before it was taken away – she brushed a few strands of hair out of her face and behind her ear. This movement shook loose a couple straws of hay she had earlier missed, and they fell before her on the table.

She did not even need to look up to know the servants were shifting where they stood and exchanging glances. Ordinarily she would respond with some sort of witty remark, but a positive outcome could no longer be obtained from such an act. Each servant had seen her acting in a way peculiar to that of a princess. True, this would add fuel to their gossip, but their imaginations were poor at best. No new rumors had begun to circulate for weeks; the old ones were merely being retold with the smallest of alterations.

Not only did they lack the creativity to invent new rumors, they also lacked the gall and imagination to enter into a battle of wits with her. This was one trait Isabelle loved in Daniel. He was practically all too eager to make fun of her to her face. They often spent much time exchanging quips and poking fun at each other, all in good spirit.

Smiling to herself, Isabelle dove into the leafy green salad which had replaced the bowl of soup on the table before her. Not particularly in the mood for salad, Isabelle found herself marveling at the many various shades of green on a single plate, only to be interrupted by the slamming of the kitchen door.

Dylan came stumbling out with a pitcher of water, obviously having been pushed out and doing his best not to trip and drop the pitcher.
15122112.title: A Lesson in Manners

151221121.content:
Dylan soon regained his footing. At the last moment, however, as if pushed by some invisible pair of hands, he lost his footing and accidentally poured the contents of the pitcher all over Isabelle. Immediately the servants gasped and all but one leapt to her side with towels and anxious expressions draped over their faces. The last, completely stone faced, hovered over Dylan where he had fallen.

“Please, I am perfectly capable of drying myself,” Isabelle insisted as she snatched a towel from a servant.

As the circle of servants around Isabelle began to disperse and resumed their positions of wall ornaments, Isabelle noticed that one had taken Dylan by the collar and was escorting him to the door. She rose to her feet. “If you would be so kind, I would like a moment alone with the boy. You are all dismissed.” Ignoring the questioning looks they gave each other, Isabelle remained motionless waiting for their departure. “You have been given no such order as to remain by my side every moment of every day. And despite what you may have heard or been told by my parents, I am the princess and in my parents’ absence you obey me. I do not enjoy giving orders, so I shall ask again that you leave us. You may take the rest of the day as personal time if you so wish.”

One last questioning glance at each other and, as if in a trance, the servants abandoned their long held posts and headed straight out the door. As the river flowed through the door, Dylan’s collar was let loose and his would be capture dissolved into the river of bodies. Once the room was finally clear of nagging servants, Isabelle stepped away from the table to help Dylan to his feet.

“I really do hate ordering them around. If only they would allow me some leeway, allow me to live at least part of my life without them. Perhaps this is an issue best left for another time. Are you ok?” A short, barely noticeable nod from Dylan was all the assurance Isabelle needed to know he was still somewhat shaken from a second threat of being arrested. “Why don’t you take my seat and I shall serve you lunch?” A second, more vigorous nod told Isabelle that the thought of food had quickly revived Dylan.

After making sure Dylan was comfortable, Isabelle left him looking around at the many tapestries and paintings adorning the walls. As she entered the kitchen, she was only slightly surprised that the kitchen staff was nowhere to be seen. Often they prepare the meal then, while one or two remain behind to serve the meal, the others attend to other matters. When the meal has been finished, they return to clean up. Isabelle was no stranger to this; instead, what surprised her was the fact that Matty had opted to leave Dylan alone to complete the serving. I do not believe she would trust such a task to Dylan, the miscreant she believes him to be, Isabelle thought to herself as she ladled soup into a clean bowl. No doubt she believes Dylan will fail his tasks. Might it be that she is expecting, even depending on his failure? It is quite likely that she hopes Dylan to fail and me to remove him from the service of her kitchen. I will not be manipulated so easily.

Isabelle proceeded to prepare a small salad, and, with salad and soup in hand, she reentered the dining room and placed the food in front of Dylan. He smiled and immediately began gorging himself. Smiling as well Isabelle returned to the kitchen to fetch two rather large, elaborate sandwiches. By the time she returned to the dining room, Dylan had finished his soup and was halfway through his salad. The astonishingly large quantities of food served at meals had always bemused Isabelle. She was never allowed to finish all that was put before her, but what she was given time she eat she could barely finish. Such being, there always seemed too much food used, to her at least. As both she and Dylan began eating their sandwiches, Isabelle could not help but notice how hungry Dylan had been. Perhaps the amount of food served was just right.

“I know you have a voice Dylan; I have heard you use it quite freely. Why then at other times do you seem to lose the ability to speak and become somewhat of a mute?”

At that moment, Isabelle heard a voice speaking to her from the doorway.
151221121.title: How Much Food is Enough

choices: They go back to their duties
They go out to have some fun
1512211212.content:
“He was not always like that.” Surprised, Isabelle looked up to give a face to the voice. Standing in the doorway before her was none other than Jackson.

“Jackson, you startled me.” Isabelle smiled and rose to her feet.

“I apologize Princess.”

“There is no one else here Jackson, you may call me Isabelle. I rather prefer you call me Isabelle. Won’t you join us?”

“Thank you, but I am not hungry.”

“At least take a seat.” Jackson complied and took a seat across from Isabelle beside Dylan. “Now, I believe you said something about Dylan’s seemingly selective muteness?”

“Ah, yes. Well, as I have said, our parents passed shortly after Dylan’s first birthday. Babies often are not very in touch with the world around them, but Dylan appeared to grasped exactly what had happened. He ceased the incoherent babblings typical of a child his age; he ceased crawling and standing and trying to walk. For about a year, he merely sat detached from the world. However, when the life did finally return to his eyes, he began behaving as if he had not lost an entire year, as if by simply watching those around him, he learned what most infants learn through trial and error.

“From then on, he grew as any other child. Until recently that is. He never had a chance to know our parents, and now he has been separated from the only family he has known. Dylan receded once again. Fortunately, this time, it was not for so long. He only fell silent for a couple of months. However, since then his speech has been intermittent at best.”

“I see,” Isabelle sighed. “I cannot imagine what you two have been through. I can only hope that I be allowed to make things easier – if not happier – for you two.”

“You have already done more for us two exiled gypsies than we could have hope. And you will be pleased to know that I have noticed that Dylan has begun speaking a lot more since you have taken us in.” Both Isabelle and Jackson smiled. It was then they noticed that Dylan had recently finished his food and was silently walking around the room admiring its lavish decorations.

When Dylan lingered before one of the tapestries, Isabelle left her seat, stood behind him, and placed her hands on his shoulders. He didn’t even bat an eyelash. Pointing, Isabelle said in a soft voice, “This tapestry is one of my favorites.” Jackson also took a place behind Dylan listening to Isabelle and examining the tapestry. “It tells the story of my father’s father’s father, my great grandfather Nicolai. You see, like you, he lost his parents at a very young age. So his father’s advisors kept the kingdom from falling to pieces while Nicolai was given time to mature and learn how to rule. Nicolai did not believe he could rule an entire kingdom, but I am told he was one of the wisest, fairest, and kindest in the history of our kingdom. I have not suffered any hardships – though the lack of privacy and independence, the rules of etiquette, and the thoroughly uncomfortable gowns seem like that worst torture there is. I only hope that I can one day guide my people as well as he did then and my parents are doing now.”
1512211212.title: Family

15122112121.content:
It was then that a middle aged, slightly graying servant poked his head through the doorway. "Pardon me your highness." Jackson placed his hands on Dylan's shoulders and eased a few inches from Isabelle's side, trying to meld with the background. Isabelle nodded for the servant to continue. "Master Daelos requests your presence in the grand ballroom. It is time for your lessons.”

“Thank you. Tell him I shall meet him anon.” With a quick bow, the servant disappeared as effortlessly and silently as he had appeared. “And thus I am once again called back to the ever continuous chores of a princess.” When Isabelle turned back around she found Jackson and Dylan moving to remove the plates from the table. “You do not need to do that. By the sounds of it,” indicating the clanking of pans and swishing of water coming from the kitchen, “it appears the kitchen staff has returned to finish the clean up. I’m sure Daniel would appreciate your help and your company. Perhaps you would like to feed Elias, huh Dylan? He may even be able to groom him.” The pure joy on Dylan’s face persuaded Jackson to put the dishes back on the table, and with a slight nod to Isabelle they left the room and headed for the stables.

Isabelle on the other hand headed for the grand ballroom, walking just fast enough not to be accused of dallying. She did not particularly dislike Master Daelos, but nor did she delight in attending his lessons. Master Daelos was in charge of instructing Isabelle on how to present herself in public and the numerous motions and dances she must know for various occasions.

The lesson proceeded in a dizzying blur of music and scattered phrases floating with each note. Relax your hands. Not that relaxed. Don’t slump. You’re stepping on my foot your highness. No no, the move is as such. A little faster here. Ow, that’s my foot. This part should be more fluid. Again, my foot Princess. My dear, the gentlemen leads, not you. Isabelle was exhausted when it was over. They had been at the lesson far longer than usual. Perhaps her mind was elsewhere, for she didn’t even realize how long it had been or how tired her body was until Master Daelos brought the lesson to a close.

Adjourning to her chamber, Isabelle decided to rest a while before dinner. She closed her eyes for a moment, and when she reopened them Isabelle found over an hour had passed. It was as if she had blinked away a portion of her life. There was still quite some time before dinner, but Isabelle still lacked her usual energy to go find Daniel for a race or some harmless pranks. Instead she consented to contemplating the many cracks in the ceiling. When she could no longer find any amusing designs in the cracks, a bath seemed the perfect thing for her weary body. Afterward she would head down for dinner.

It was only after dinner, again revitalized and on her way out the door did Isabelle learn that before departing, her parents had arranged extra lessons for her. Goodbye freedom, and with a sigh she turned in horse races for etiquette – for tonight at least.

The next day, Isabelle had barely finished her morning meal when she learned that she had lessons scattered throughout the day. Between the lessons and the servants stuck like glue to her all day, Isabelle was not able to slip away long enough check in on Dylan and Jackson or complain about the extra lessons and extra sticky servants to Daniel. Why the sudden onslaught of proper princess behavior and caution being thrown at me? Nothing came to mind. Her parents had gone away before without taking such pains to restrict her free time.

Hopefully tomorrow would be different.
15122112121.title: Lessons

choices: The boys are called away to work
151221121212.content:
Though pleased to find that she had only one lesson that day right after the morning meal, something did not seem quite right. Isabelle had had a restful sleep that night, but it was a dreamless night. It was not uncommon that Isabelle found herself unable to remember her dreams from the previous night. This was different. She felt certain that no glimmer of a dream had passed through her mind. It was as if for one night she had experienced the sleep of the dead. Isabelle was a little unnerved by this; she could not remember having such a dreamless sleep before. As she broke her fast that morning, alone (her parents would not return for a few more days), Isabelle contemplated this. The night had been both relaxing and disturbing.

Exhaustion. That must be the reason. My body lacked energy; my mind must have been equally as weary, too weary to dream. I suppose it is possible, and thus she played it off as nothing and discarded her worries along the side of the path on her way to the stables after her day’s lesson.

In the stables she found Daniel shoveling some manure from the horses’ stalls into a wheelbarrow to later be used as fertilizer, and Jackson was giving the horses some fresh water. Dylan was sitting off to the side eating what appeared to be his second apple. That boy always seems to be eating. Breakfast was not all that long ago, and lunch will begin shortly. Isabelle smiled to herself. The appetite of a growing boy I suppose.

“How nice of you to deign to see us today your highness,” Daniel said in mock reverence when he saw that Isabelle had entered the stables.

“Oh, I would not pass up the opportunity to visit with such loyal and distinguished subjects as yourselves,” Isabelle replied with equal sarcasm.

“But you really needn’t have bothered. We haven’t had the time to clean up; your dress may be sullied.”

“Then I suppose you’ll just have to lie upon the ground that I might have something to walk upon, or else I could merely have you beheaded at the day’s end.” Dylan stopped mid bite, and Jackson glanced back and forth between the two in confusion. “I thought the two of you were friends.”

Daniel and Isabelle smiled at each other, and Dylan returned to his half eaten apple. “Of course we are friends, we just like to poke fun at how so many people expect a princess to treat someone in my position,” Daniel explained. “Besides, I would never respond so cruelly as to have someone beheaded for something so trite,” Isabelle added

“I understand. The truth is that a friendship such as yours is rather unusual. And unfortunately, I have heard of royalty who have beheaded people for far less.”

“So, where were you yesterday?” Daniel asked as he leaned the shovel against the wall having finished scooping out all the manure.

“My parents arrange several more lessons for me without telling me before they left. Plus there were always a few servants around me, as if I might at any moment trip and shatter into a million pieces.”

“Well that makes sense, does it not?” Jackson inquired as he sat beside Dylan, who offered him a bite of his apple. “I mean, don’t princesses usually have a lot of responsibilities and things they need to know?”

“He right Isabelle, we’re not kids anymore, we’re both going to have to grow up sooner or later, take on more responsibilities. You parents probably want to begin teaching you how to rule a kingdom. I would not be surprised if they decide to present you society, start the process of finding you a husband and king to rule beside.”

“True. I had merely hoped it would not come so soon.” Isabelle sighed and watched Dylan toss his apple core off to the side. For a few moments all were quiet, the three teenagers contemplating the fast approaching end of their childhood. Even the horses, as if sensing the solemnity in the air, were as silent as they could be.
151221121212.title: Unusual

1512211212122.content:
It was Dylan or finally broke the silence, “I’m hungry. When is lunch?” The others could not help but laugh, and the stables seemed to wake from a deep slumber.

“You are a bottomless pit Dylan. You were just eating an apple, and already you’re hungry again.” Isabelle laughed.

“I gave most of the apple to Elias.” None of them had even noticed that most of the pieces he bit from the apple he fed to Elias.

“You must be patient Dylan,” Jackson admonished, “remember we are guests here.” Daniel ducked his head outside to check the position of the sun. When Daniel walked back into the stables he was attempting to wipe some of the dirt from his hands unto his already dirt covered pants. “And if we don’t hurry, you shall have to be patient even longer. For if we are late to lunch my mother may just deny us the meal. Are you coming, or are the three of you just going to sit there and eat hay and oats along with the horses?”

*~*~*

“Have you all washed your hands?” Daniel’s mother asked she set a few extra places at the table and the four friends walked into Daniel’s home. “Yes, mother.” “Yeah.” “Yes.” “Uh huh.” “And be careful not to track any dirt or manure into my house. If you do you’ll be the ones scrubbing the floors not me.”

After confirming that nothing on their shoes would sully the floors, Dylan and Jackson took their seats while Daniel and Isabelle went into the kitchen to offer their help. Jackson had just risen from his seat to likewise offer his hand in the kitchen when both Daniel and Isabelle were shooed out of the kitchen. “Sit down all of you. Relax. I am perfectly capable of tending to lunch on my own.

Isabelle had long since become a part of Daniel’s family, they were practically a second family to her as Daniel was like a son to the King and Queen (as much as their social positions allowed). As they enjoyed their meal and each others company, Dylan and Jackson were likewise adopted into the family.

*~*~*

“You’re parents are something Daniel,” Jackson commented as they made their way back to the stables. “Friendly, eager to offer whatever they can, and so perfectly content with they’re lot in life. Most people are always wishing for more. They truly seemed as if they simply could not be any happier. Your father, though, he seemed tired.”

“When he’s not in his smithery, he is in town selling his wares and services. It can be quite draining.”

“You’re lucky,” Isabelle was walking between them and Dylan was skipping along a short ways ahead of them, “nearly a year had passed before I was actually introduced to Daniel’s father. I’d seen him around, even been in his presence, but it was quite some time before I knew him as the father of my friend. Even more time passed before he was able to treat me as informally as you have seen, almost as his own child. You would not believe how many times I escaped my own parents’ rebuking only to be thoroughly admonished by him and Daniel’s mother.”

“Dylan and I also found ourselves with numerous adults looking out for us, some barely older than myself filling the roles of mother and father. It could be quite irksome, but they took us in when we needed it, and they did know how to have fun. You two remind me of them - you and your families. One day I shall repay you all for your kindness,” Jackson promised. “I just hope we will also enjoy the pleasures of being with out family,” he added much more for himself than his companions.

“You’ll be together again someday,” Isabelle comforted and linked her arm in Jackson’s.

“And you need never repay us.” Isabelle nodded her assent. “Isabelle’s a princess, and though my life is humble you said so yourself, my parents could not be happier. Besides, one day I shall be a knight and will be able to take care of them as they have cared for me these many years.”

Upon reaching the stables Dylan immediately ran inside and plopped down on a stack of hay by Elias’s stall. “You seem very sure of yourself. Are you that certain of becoming a knight?” questioned Jackson.

Smiling, Isabelle stood beside Jackson, crossed her arms, and replied, “I must admit he has many qualities desirable in a knight. Not to mention he fancies himself quite the terrific swordsman.”

“You’re a good swordsman huh?” Looking around Jackson found a decent sized stick and took it in hand. “What say you to a friendly match then?”
1512211212122.title: Parental Figures

15122112121221.content:
Daniel smirked and with a slight nod of his head accepted the challenge and likewise drew his weapon, the twin brother of Jackson’s wooden sword. They took their positions.

From the moment of the first resounding clash of their “swords” it was clear that these were not mere boys playing at knights – there was something there just beneath the surface waiting to be tapped into. Isabelle sat on the grass and even Dylan tore himself from Elias’s stall to stand just outside the stable doors and watch the match. They had each trained in different styles, and yet they could equally anticipate the other’s next move and react accordingly. Their techniques were markedly different from that of the knights under the command of Isabelle’s father, but the same skill and precision was as evident in the two boys as in some of the more seasoned knights. This and more was there, though much of it lay dormant within their very muscles, yearning to be harnessed and put to use. For now at least neither could boast of perfect form and each made amateur mistakes that would need to be improved if either wished to truly excel. Despite this fact, their match made for a magnificent scene.

The match continued for quite some time, with no sign of either Daniel or Jackson gaining the advantage. It was clear that they were both growing exhausted, but as true swordsmen – and, more importantly, young men - they were resolved to see the match to a conclusion.

Just when it seemed both boys were ready to declare a draw, with a swift strike Jackson knocked Daniel’s stick from his hand and had his own aimed squarely at Daniel’s chest in mere seconds, his form silhouetted in the slowly sinking sun. After playfully stabbing Daniel, Jackson let his stick fall to their feet. Almost before the stick had touched the ground Jackson and Daniel had let themselves likewise fall to the ground laughing away the fatigue in their muscles.

The not quite epic battle finished, Dylan plopped down beside them, and Isabelle brought them a goatskin of water from the stables. “Daniel, I must say you’ve improved since our last match. Unless you have been allowing me to win out of some misguided chivalry either because I am a girl or, worse, because I am the princess. In which case you know how I feel about such behavior.”

“For the most part,” his breathing finally returned to normal, Daniel responded, “no, I have not been handing you victory in our more recent matches; for I am well aware of how I would suffer for performing such a dastardly deed. I am not the only one to have improved as of late.”

“It pleases me to hear you say so. Thank you. Perhaps you will remember that next time you are inclined to treat me as a delicate flower that crumples at the softest breeze.”

“I must admit you are much more capable than most would expect of you, but you must also admit that your pride has made you believe your skills to be greater than in reality. For example, although you have bested me in recent matches, I am not so sure Jackson would so easily fall to your sword.”

A glimmer of surprise briefly crossed Jackson’s face, only to be immediately replaced by a good natured smile. “I appreciate the compliment Daniel, as I assume that statement is meant to be, but after our match I thought your opinion of my ability to be somewhat higher.”

“So you also believe that you are better skilled with a sword than I?”

“I mean no offense Princess,” Jackson attempted to conceal his incredulity that a princess could possess any more than adequate knowledge of the sword while trying to assuage any affront to her pride, “I have no doubt that your abilities more than surpass mine in matters of etiquette or court life, but as to matters deemed below and/or unsuitable for a young princess there can hardly be any question of the disparities between our expertise.”

“Of course all are entitled to their opinions, mistaken though they may be.” Looking to Daniel silently questioning whether the princess could really mean all that she is saying, Jackson is merely met with a resigned smirk. Whether it confirmed Isabelle’s opinion or Jackson’s was uncertain. Either it was mere talk or she truly was as skilled as she claimed.

Just then an out of breath servant stumbled towards them from the direction of the castle and spoke with some urgency.

“Your-your Highness –”

“Slow down. Catch your breath first.”

“Your Highness. There is a knight on horseback approaching the front gate unannounced. As of yet he has not identified himself, nor is he displaying any colors or coat of arms. But the man walking beside him, presumably a page, has requested an audience with their majesties the King and Queen.”

“Jackson, it seems we shall have to postpone the rest of this discussion. Now if you all would accompany me to the castle I shall see to this stranger.”

The knight is:
15122112121221.title: Swordplay

151221121212211.content:
The gates opened to reveal the knight slumped in his saddle and the page using a walking stick to offset his noticeable limp. Both rather worse for wear. Isabelle was just about to ask the identity of her visitor and his purpose when she realized not only was the knight not looking at her, or anyone else for that matter, but he was completely limp. Looking closer she realized he was, in fact, unconscious, and the page had blood staining his hands and walking stick.

“Help them inside, and fetch the physician.”

“But your highness –”

“Don’t question. Just do as I say. Now.”

They reached the strangers just in time to catch the page as he collapsed. The castle physician arrived immediately- - he had his own quarters in the castle so he’d always be at hand for such emergencies. Once the knight and page were inside, the physician quickly shooed everyone from the room so he could tend to their injuries unimpeded. Isabelle, however, was not one to be shooed away. She insisted on staying to help and to be there the moment either regained consciousness.

The physician first dressed the wounds of the knight as Isabelle began cleaning the wounds of the man who had come in with him. Now examining him closer, Isabelle noticed that he was not dressed as a knight’s page, nor did his body or face show any of the usual signs of the wear associated with doing the bidding of a knight. Whoever he was though, he knew the meaning of an honest day’s labor. From what Isabelle could see he had a strong spirit, and, whatever his injuries, he would survive.

Finished with the knight’s wounds and confident that he too was no longer at Death’s door, the physician took over tending to the knight’s companion, allowing Isabelle a closer look at the knight himself, his face no longer hidden by his helmet and a veil of dried blood. She recognized him immediately.

“Sir Bernard?” More to herself than to anyone else, speaking hardly above a whisper, Isabelle tried to make sense of the scene that had stumbled in from the front gate. “How has this come to pass? Who could have done this to you Bernard? You are one of greatest knight’s in the land. The only time I have ever seen you sustain any serious damage was when you were thrown from Elias’s back. And that was still not enough to keep you from breaking another stallion the next day. And now…. If it had taken you any longer to reach us – I fear you may have been beyond cure. It must have been a mighty foe to have dealt you such damage. And how have you come to be traveling with this stranger? He does not appear to be of our country.”

Moving from the side of Sir Bernard, Isabelle again looked down into the face of the stranger. “And who are you sir?”

“Your Highness?”

“Yes? What is it?”

“There is nothing more to be done for them today, m’lady. They need their rest, and when they awake they will require sustenance.”

“When can I expect them to rise and tell me what has transpired?”

“I am sorry m’lady, but there is just no way to tell. In the intervening time, the hour grows late. Might I suggest a meal and rest for your highness?”

“No. That can wait. One of the king’s best knights has been brought nearly to death by someone or something unknown, a matter which must not be taken lightly. With my father abroad it falls to me to discover how such an event has come about. I shall remain here for the time being.”

“As you wish Princess. I shall return to redress their wounds in due time.”

~*~*~*~*~*~

Over an hour had past and neither Sir Bernard nor the stranger had stirred. If Isabelle hadn’t known better she might have believed they had passed on since the doctor had left them.

Sitting in a chair a few feet from the sleeping men, Isabelle hadn’t even realized she had fallen asleep when she was startled awake and noticed one of the figures was sitting up, his hands cradling his head. It was the stranger. Now sitting up straight in her own chair, Isabelle wasn’t sure what to say or how to approach the situation – she was still young in the ways of diplomacy and nothing at all about the men before her. He could very well have been responsible for Sir Bernard’s current state. And yet, Isabelle felt no sense of unease with being so close to what could potentially be a threat to her person. Instead, any uneasiness she felt stemmed from her fear of whether she could effectively handle the situation on her own while her parents were away. For a few moments she merely sat watching him. It wasn’t long before he lifted his head and their eyes met.

“How are you feeling?” Isabelle had not even noticed when she decided to speak let alone what to say; all of a sudden the words were just there, flowing as naturally as breath.

“Better. Thank you. How is the knight?” His voice was hardly above a hoarse whisper, but the room was still enough to hear him clearly, the deep breathing of the unconscious Sir Bernard enhancing rather than disturbing the calm of the room.

“Sir Bernard? He shall live; he is just resting now.”

“Where am I?”

“You are in the castle of King Edward. You are safe here.”

The stranger:
151221121212211.title: The Stranger

1512211212122112.content:
“Would you like something to eat or to drink?” Isabelle rose from the chair where she sat her vigil over the two injured men.

“No thank you miss, I – ” He never finished his sentence. A pained expression crossed his face and his hand shot up to his temples. Just as quickly Isabelle was by his side, worry coloring her features.

“Perhaps you ought to lie back down. It appears you’ve been through quite an ordeal already and need your rest.” No sooner had he lain down then they were startled by Sir Bernard who groaned in his sleep but did not wake. Breathing a sigh Isabelle was again startled, this time by the stranger sitting up straight as a board, the color drained from his face.

“What is wrong? Are you alright? I’ll fetch the physician.” Isabelle moved to leave, but was stopped by a hand on her arm.

“No. No, I need warn – They must know – ” The words came out so fast Isabelle barely understood. He took a deep breath before continuing, slower this time. “Where are the king and queen? King Edward you said? I need to speak with him. It is of grave importance.”

“I am afraid that my parents are away at the moment and will not return for several days. If you would tell me what is so important I shall see what can be in the meantime.”

“No, no the king…” He paused a moment as the words sunk in, his face softening as he looked at Isabelle as if only now really seeing her. “Did you say your parents? You’re the princess?”

“Yes, I am Princess Isabelle, and I will help any way that I can. Now will you please tell me what has transpired here? What is so urgent?” The stranger’s eyes wandered to Sir Bernard’s still unconscious form as he pondered his next move, his next words.

Slowly at first as if still debating his options but growing more determined with each word, the stranger began to unfold the events that had led him and the knight to her doorstep in their present condition. She may not be queen, may not even have any real authority beyond these walls yet, but it could do no harm to warn her. And people needed to be warned. Even if he could only warn them one at a time.

“My family and I” a brief shadow of grief flickered across his face at the mention of his family, but he recovered quickly and continued with his tale, “were two to three days south of Lain’s southern border in the kingdom of Tamor. We had been traveling some time so we did not notice when we started hearing the noises; we merely assumed our imaginations were running wild and quickly discredited the signs. Even now I cannot tell you exactly when we crossed their path.

“A creature unlike any that has been seen in these lands for many generations emerged from the woods. A few of the men placed their hands on their weapons and kept their sense alert the creature, but we kept to our path. We hoped to make camp before nightfall. There was only one of the creatures, hardly a serious threat to us, but all the same it is not the kind of thing you want anywhere near you day or night. We just kept walking, and it continued to stare after us while walking parallel to us. Soon, however, one by one, more of those creatures began emerging from the woods and they all began creeping ever closer to our band.”

“What were they?”

“They were fierce creatures indeed – as big as bears, both canine and feline features, and, in their eyes, an insatiable hunger. But what they are called or from where they come, I do not know. When the second one came into view, the men slowly moved between the women and children and the creatures. But we kept walking. When the third came out of the woods, we drew our weapons. But we kept walking. When the fourth appeared, we ran and they charged….” He pressed his palms into his eyes trying to erase the images permanently burned into the inside of his eye lids.

“We tried to stay together all long as we could and fight them off as best we could, but the creatures were too fast and too strong. I saw a few men fall beneath the claws of those beasts and told the women and child to run, to save themselves.”

“My God.” Isabelle didn’t want to think about what it must have been like for him to see his family running for their lives and being unable to protect them or even keep them together.

“I do not know what happened next. We must have been close to your border because the next thing I remember is seeing this knight and running towards praying that he would help us.”

“And your family?” She wasn’t sure she really wanted to know the answer. The question came out hardly above a whisper. He looked down at his hands clasped in his lap, and there was such grief on his face it pained Isabelle to see.

“As I ran for what I hoped would be our salvation I looked around myself but not one of them was in sight. Neither were any of the creatures.”

“But then how did Sir Bernard get injured?”

“None of the creatures were in view as I made my way to Sir Bernard, but one at least not far away. I reached Sir Bernard and began to explain what had happened and to ask for his assistance. Neither of us saw where it came from, but we were both knocked to the ground in a manner of seconds. He fought valiantly; I would not be alive without him.”

“Did he kill this creature?”

The stranger looked up into her eyes and Isabelle already knew the answer as unbelievable and terrifying as it was.
