15122112121221122.content:
“He did manage to wound it. This creature was beyond reason; Sir Bernard’s sword could barely scratch its hide. It was wounded but its power was in no way diminished. I believed it was about to make one final strike killing us both when a terrible rumbling call, I can only assume came from the others, rose up in the distance and the creature ran off and disappeared as swiftly as it had arrived.

“I sat frozen in shock for several moments before I noticed Sir Bernard doubled over at my side. Not quite convinced that the creatures were really gone but knowing we could not simply stay where we were in that condition, I tried to clean our injuries as best as I could. Then supporting as much of his weight as I could, I helped Sir Bernard into the saddle of his horse who after being frightened away by the creature had returned to its master.

“How long we walked, stopping often to rest, I do not know, nor do I have a clue as to how we found our way this castle. Soon enough the gate was sprouting up in front of me and yours guard moved to intercept us.”

“This is unbelievable.” What is going on? How could something like this happen? There had been rumors of strange occurrences in some of the eastern kingdoms, but nothing specific, certainly nothing like this. Isabelle stared off at the open window trying to erase from her mind’s eye the quickly forming image of those creatures and the horrible scene of men, women, and children running for their lives but far too many unable to escape.

As her eyes began to refocus, Isabelle noticed the sky beginning to lighten as the sun rose on a world that seemed to her completely different than the carefree world she lived and laughed in the day before.

When she heard the man sigh she tore her eyes from the brightening morning outside the window and was momentarily startled by what she saw. The man’s face was cast in deep relief by the light slanting into the room through the window. He looked older and more worn down than she remembered at their first meeting some hours ago. Then again his arrival caused quite a stir and may not have gotten a very good look at him. And after all he’s been through, it’s no wonder the way he looks now.

“Well, you are safe now. I shall go get you some food and fresh clothes. Just rest for now. The is plenty of time to figure things out.” Isabelle rose and patted his shoulder reassuringly before heading towards the door.

She had walked several feet when she felt a cold tingling on her arm. Looking down she found that Sir Bernard had awaken and was reaching his hand out to her from where he lay. “Your highness.” He made a move to rise but fell back with a groan and gripped his side.

“Sir Bernard,” Isabelle knelt besides the knight and held his outstretched hand in both of hers. Her mother would not have approved, he was a member of the court and he was in pain. “Rest now. How are you feeling?” He looked confused and yet determined at the same time. As if he knew there was something important he had to say but try as he might he could not remember it.

“Valiant knight, it seems grace has decided to shine on us.” The stranger rose and moved to the knight’s side, smiling down on him as he spoke. “After leading me to you who saved my life from those monstrous beasts, the fates led us here to our safe harbor at the castle of your king.”

Just then there was a soft knock at the door, immediately followed by Daniel’s head poking around the door. “I thought I heard voices. Is everything alright?”

“Oh yes. Come on in Daniel.” Isabelle rose to her feet and dusted herself off before moving to the side allowing Daniel to greet Sir Bernard. Many of the knights of King Edward’s inner court knew Daniel, not just as the Princess’s best friend but as a young man determined to become a knight and few, if any, hesitations about incessantly asking them for advice and tips.

Daniel looked over Sir Bernard once, and although he could not disguise the same disbelief they all felt that now crossed his face it was quickly replaced by a good natured grin. “Looks like someone got the better of you old man.”

Sir Bernard could not help but return the smile. It was a pleasant change from the pain and confusion previous coloring his features. “So it would seem, but it was something rather than some one. Though I am sure you would have fared much better.” Unfortunately the good mood did not last. Another stab of pain wiped the smile off of Sir Bernard’s face. “Rest, Sir Bernard. This kingdom would not be the same without you. And I still have many more questions for you about becoming a knight.” They exchanged wry smiles.

Isabelle and Daniel moved off to the other side of the room and spoke in hushed voices so as not to disturb Sir Bernard or the stranger who now stood by the window looking out past the horizon. “Where are our new friends?” Isabelle asked.

“Dylan was hungry. They went to the kitchens to get something to eat,” Daniel replied, still distracted by the sight of so many wounds on the body of a man he once thought invincible.

“I should have known.” Pausing, trying to find the right words, Isabelle glanced back at the form of Sir Bernard. “The creatures this man described that attacked them. It is beyond belief Daniel.” She briefly retold the story of the attack. The stranger continued to star out the window, the knight looked absently up at the ceiling, but both heard what passed between these two. “Do you remember those rumors that have been circulating, about the strange incidents in the far Eastern kingdoms?”

“Yes. It is possible, even probable, that these creatures are the cause. But what are they, and what were they doing there? They are farther West than any one of the rumors have placed them so far.”

“They were an advance scouting party.” Sir Bernard had managed to pull himself up into a sitting position without either Isabelle or Daniel noticing. The stranger merely continued staring out the window.

“Sir Bernard, do you know what these things are?” Isabelle was bewildered. How could he know about these creatures?

“No, not what they are, but why they were there.” Daniel and Isabelle each took seats across from Sir Bernard. “You’ve heard the rumors of unexplainable occurrences – the disappearances and slaughters of livestock and strange sightings. What you may not have heard are the rumors that Radigan is extending the reach of his power. We cannot be sure since none of those kings have admitted to any of it, but it is believed that Radigan has been stretching out and seizing control of lands in the kingdoms surrounding his dominion. He may even now have full control of any number of those lands.

“And he is not stopping there. I do not know how, but recently incredible creatures suddenly appeared apparently at his bidding such as those that attacked this man and his family, as well as many more we have yet to see but have heard tell of.”

All remained motionless, the gravity of the situation bearing down on them. The same thought tortured them all: Radigan and those creatures are steadily making their way here, and everyone who crosses their path will almost surely die.
15122112121221122.title: In Radigan's Wake

151221121212211222.content:
“We have to warn them.”

“Your highness?”

“If that was only an advance scouting party you encountered, then there is still time to warn the villagers closest to the border and get them safety. We – ” There was a squeak as the door opened interrupting Isabelle’s train of thought. In skipped Dylan, chomping on a carrot. Jackson followed him in carrying a tray of food. “We thought all of you could do with a little nourishment.”

They both froze at the sight of the stranger who had spun around when he heard Jackson speak. Shocking Isabelle and Daniel, Dylan dropped the carrot, only half eaten, and ran into the arms of the man. Jackson looked as if he were about to dropped the tray of food. Sir Bernard, who was closest to Jackson, took the try from him and immediately placed it on the nearest end table unable to support it very long for himself.

Confusion filled the three faces of Isabelle, Daniel, and Sir Bernard. Pure joy filled the three faces of Jackson, Dylan, and the stranger.

“Uncle Nathaniel!” Dylan squealed with delight as he hugged him closer. Daniel and Isabelle were stunned. They had grown so fond of Dylan and Jackson in the past few days that they had almost forgotten they had had lives and known people before arriving at the castle. And the likelihood of one of the family members they had been separated from while in another kingdom finding his way here after passing through yet another kingdom was unfathomable. Getting over his initial shock Jackson joined Dylan in his embrace of Nathaniel.

“Oh my boys. How I have longed to see you alive and well. We never gave up hope.” The smile took years off Nathaniel’s face. He no longer appeared the same haggard man who arrived bearing the marks of incredible suffering.

“Jackson you know this man?” Daniel asked.

“Yes. Daniel, Isabelle, I would like you to meet Nathaniel. His was the family that took us in when we had no one else to turn to. Nathaniel, this is Princess Isabelle and Daniel. They have been good to us.” Unfortunately they joy of a family reunion could not last long. Nathaniel could not look into Dylan’s eyes when he looked up at him and asked, “Uncle Nathaniel, where all the others?” The pain returned to his face, though he tried to conceal it for Dylan’s sake. He failed.

“What is it Nathaniel? What is wrong?” He could not bring himself to answer Jackson’s question. Instead he looked to first to Sir Bernard, than Daniel, and let his eyes come to rest on Isabelle. She was just as hesitant to tell Jackson and Dylan what had come to pass, but she simply could not ignore Nathaniel’s imploring, despair filled eyes.

“Jackson, Dylan, perhaps you should take a seat.” Once everyone was seated they set about explaining what had happened, trying to soften the blow as best as they could. The farther they got in the story, the closer Nathaniel held Dylan. Jackson’s hands clasped into fists, but he remained silent the entire time.

When the tale was over and no one said anything for several moments, hoping to take their minds off the grisly scene, Nathaniel asked how they had come to reside at this castle with two new friends. Dylan explained about how Isabelle had saved him from the crazed cook. Nathaniel smiled; he knew very well the extent of Dylan’s insatiable appetite. He told of the fancy bath and comfy bed he got to sleep on. He talked about having lunch with Daniel’s family, and of Daniel and Jackson’s sword fight. Proudly he told Nathaniel how he helped in the stable, and of the majestic horse Elias. When he expressed his eagerness for the family to meet Elias, Jackson snapped out of his silence.

“We have to go after them. We have to find them before…. Before anything else happens.”

“Jackson, they could be anywhere by now.” Nathaniel said the words, but it was clear he felt just as Jackson did and wanted to go find his family.

“Those animals are far deadly than anything you’ve ever heard of kid,” Sir Bernard warned. “If you were to cross paths with even one…”

“All the more reason we need to find them before those creatures do.”

“We have only just now been reunited, Jackson. I will not lose you boys again. I will not watch more of my family torn down.”

They tried in vain to convey how dangerous it would be for them to jump headlong into a search with what they knew and, worse, with what they didn’t know. Jackson wouldn’t hear any of it. “If you will not help me I will go alone.”
151221121212211222.title: Lost and Found

1512211212122112222.content:
“No you will not Jackson,” Isabelle spoke up for the first time during the debate. “And before you say anything else,” she continued before Jackson could interrupt, “I have no intention of simply abandoning them. But we must be smart about this.” She had made up her mind the moment she heard that Radigan’s forces were about to ravage the lands of her kingdom and kill her people. Now a plan began to solidify, and it was clear what she had to do. Isabelle sounded so sure and determined that no one else said anything. They merely waited to hear what she had in mind.

But instead of disclosing her ideas, Isabelle silently walked to the door, opened it, and told the attendant standing outside to summon Sirs Thomas, Donovan, Andrew, and Jonothan immediately. He bowed and ran down the hall. When she returned everyone waited expectantly, Isabelle merely sat down and continued to contemplate. Was she doing the right thing? She had no idea, but something had to be done and with her parents gone, it was up to her. None could bring themselves to interrupt her reverie. They all remained motionless and their thoughts were so numerous and palpable one only had to reach up and pluck them from the air.

She really is maturing into a bright young woman. Beneath the surface a true leader does indeed lay in wait.

I can’t just leave them out there, not after coming so close to reuniting with my family. I will not lose another family. And Dylan must not be made to go through that again.

Underneath all the games and mischief and boys clothes and layers of dirt, I never forgot she was a princess. But now, now I can see a glimmer of the queen she will one day become.

I am overjoyed to find these boys alive and well. It seems I need not have worried. They are doing well, and seem to have made two incredible friends.

Please let this turn out well.

Eventually the four knights arrived. Isabelle had moved to gaze out the window, still working out what she was about to do, while everyone else was seated.

“You called for us your Highness?” one of the knights asked. All four bowed as Isabelle turned from the window to look at them. When they rose and noticed Sir Bernard, surprised registered on the faces of Andrew and Jonothan. Jonothan recovered his composure sooner. Shock flickered through the eyes of Thomas and Donovan, but as more seasoned knights they were quicker to regain control of themselves.

“Yes, I did. There has been an incident, and we seem to be on the brink of a great crisis. Sir Bernard experienced this first hand, and I will allow him to divulge the details,” she said before returning her gaze to the window. Between her own jumbled thoughts, Isabelle did not hear a single word of Bernard’s story. This was just as well, for she could not bear to hear it again. All of a sudden she noticed silence in the room and could not determine how long it had been so. The tale of the attack had long since ended.

When Isabelle turned around Donovan, Thomas, Andrew, and Jonothan had taken seats around Bernard. They made to rise, but she gestured for them to remain seated. Isabelle sat down before them and took in a deep breath while the others watched her expectantly. Once she finally began to speak, her voice betrayed no hint of hesitation or doubt.

“Donovan, Jonothan, and Andrew, I want you three to make all haste to our borders closest to where Sir Bernard last saw these creatures. As the fastest Donovan, you are not to hold back; Jonothan and Andrew will follow behind you. At a time like this, every moment counts. Get there as quickly as possible.

“You are to scout the area, ascertain if this or another advance scout party or any others of Radigan’s forces are nearby. If they are, do not engage. Whether or not you find any sign of them, warn the people in the surrounding area. They need not know everything, we do not want panic, but they need to be prepared for possible attack. While you are there, please keep your eyes and ears open for members of Nathaniel’s family, and let them know we mean to reunite them with their missing family members.

“Thomas, I want you to intercept my parents, alert them of the situation, and hasten their return here. Upon their return, most likely, a new plan of action will be formed. Until that time, however, I believe this to be the best course. Tomorrow, I shall likewise make my way to the border towns accompanied by Daniel and Jackson and, since I can already see they will not be left behind for the world, Dylan and Nathaniel. That is if you feel well enough for the trip Nathaniel”

“I do. And you have my sincerest thanks m’lady.”

“We will search out your scattered family,” she said to Nathaniel and the two brothers. “As well as warn and prepare the people of what towns we come across,” this second part she directed to the knights. After a short pause she continued, “If there are no objections, I would appreciate it if you go to it immediately. Our people cannot be left defenseless and clueless of the fate that may shortly befall them.” Without another word Jonothan, Andrew, and Donovan rose, bowed to the princess, and after a short nod from Thomas exited the room to prepare for their mission. Thomas remained seated.

“With all do respect your Highness, though your plan is much more sound than I would have expected, there is one rather egregious hole that should be addressed,” he replied in all solemnity.

“I will overlook that lack of faith in my ability to strategize and instead accept it as a compliment.” Sir Thomas nodded to indicate that he meant no offense. “Now, what issue do you wish to rectify?”

“As crowned princess, you should not be walking right into danger, especially not without proper protection.”

“Say what you will I won’t be deterred. And I won’t be as defenseless as you may think.”

“I understand completely. However, it is my duty to protect this kingdom and the royal family. I would be remiss if I let you go without accompanying you myself. Please listen,” he implored before she could interject. “I propose one simple amendment to your plan: I will accompany you and these gentlemen and we will send some other messenger to your parents. The King and Queen are in a completely other part of the kingdom; it is not necessary for a knight to fetch them. They will be quite safe with their own retinue. Besides, some of our fastest messengers travel faster than many of the knights. Not to mention your parents would kill me if I let you go without doing all in my power to keep you safe.” He was right and Isabelle knew it.

“I too shall accompany you,” Bernard spoke up.

“But Sir Bernard, you are not well.” They were all thinking it, but it was Nathaniel who gave voice to the thought. Their shared experience had bonded them, giving Nathaniel a unique license to be blunt with Bernard. They were already close friends though they knew nothing about each other.

“It matters not,” he addressed to Nathaniel. Then he resumed speaking to Isabelle. “A knight knows his duty. If you say no I will still follow behind you anyway, and, should we survive this ordeal, I will graciously accept any punishment.” Isabelle wanted to object, to say anything to keep him from potentially killing himself for her, but she knew nothing would work. “If it makes you feel better, you can think of it this way: that I am going to protect Nathaniel. It is said that if you save a man’s life you are responsible for him ever after. I only just managed to save him from those creatures, I’ll be damned if I let them or anything else finish the job.”
1512211212122112222.title: Look Before You Leap

15122112121221122221.content:
“Even as a princess I can’t get my way. Everyone insists on disagreeing me with,” said Isabelle. All the same, she was smiling. She would expect nothing else from this group. “So be it. Thomas if you would please send a messenger to the King and Queen as quickly as possible. Bernard, if you are up to it, I would like to detail your encounter with this creature to the senior knights. They need to be aware of what they may soon be facing. All of the knights – novices and veterans alike – will need extra training to prepare for what is to come.”

~*~*~*~*~*~

It seemed like no time at all before they were on their way. Dylan had packed plenty of food for the journey. Isabelle had saddled and was presently riding Elias – who seemed as eager as the rest to be on his way. Daniel and Jackson had been armed with brand new swords, Dylan was provided with a crossbow, and Isabelle, after much arguing, was allowed a dagger.

They now traveled the road out of the capital city two-by-two. Sirs Donovan and Andrew headed the group, while Sirs Thomas and Jonothan took up the rear. Daniel and Dylan rode side by side second; Jackson and Nathaniel rode third, discussing what they had been through since being separated; Isabelle and Sir Bernard rode next to last.

Donovan, Jonothan, and Andrew planned to accompany the others for the first day and then set off at a faster pace early the next morning. It was felt, among the knights mostly, that because they had set out from the castle close to midday they would not get much further ahead of the others before dark fell and that it would be more prudent for them to stick close as long as they could. Two of their number were injured, four were mere children (no matter how mature they thought they were or even acted in rare instances), and circumstances could easily change in the blink of an eye.

The group set out with a sense of urgency, but after about an hour that urgency began to wane. Soon the mood began to morph into one of near frivolity. The pace slowed, and the chatter increased. They stopped once to eat and rest the horses and a second time to rest Sir Bernard and Nathaniel, despite their protests that they were well enough to keep going. Just before stopping a third time Dylan’s voice cut through the conversation and all eyes followed the point of his finger. The young have a way of seeing things others may not – both real and imagined. They can see beyond the bounds of reality and they can see reality for what it is when others cannot. None of them noticed the dilapidated huts along the side of the path some distance from them until Dylan pointed them out. For some of the party, their eyes still did not see the buildings until they had traveled nearly a quarter of the distance.

The closer they got, the more ramshackle the buildings looked. Once they reached the row of buildings, they almost immediately continued on, not one doubting that they had long been abandoned. However, as the other horses began moving forward again, Elias refused. He shook his mane, whinnied, and took a few steps backwards, completely ignoring Isabelle’s directions. Sir Bernard reached out to take the reins from Isabelle’s hands and lead Elias forward, disregarding the horse’s protestations. As Elias stubbornly remained put, Isabelle heard a faint clatter. About to dismiss the sound as a breeze lifting a few loose leaves from their branches, Isabelle recognized a faintly metallic quality to the sound. Almost immediately she then heard Jonothan speak up, his words stopping them all in their tracks. “Wait. I see some movement beyond these cabins.”

Looking on, hyper-vigilant for any hint of danger, they saw that there were more buildings farther from the road, and many showed signs of some recent repair. Continuing to watch, one by one, they all began to see some small signs of movement, what looked like people walking to and fro.

"I thought this township was abandoned years ago." Donovan and Jonothan put their hands to their brows to shield their eyes from the setting sun. Jackson squinted his eyes trying to see farther into spaces between the buildings. Isabelle watched Dylan wave his entire arm from side to side at whoever stood in the center of the township.

"Perhaps that is how its residents wish it to appear," Sir Thomas cryptically answered their curious gazes.

"Maybe we should go speak with them," Daniel suggested, "it will be dark soon."

152.content:
The banquet hall portrayed the fun and laughter of the guests nicely considering all the noise that filled the air.

Isabelle’s parents were boisterous and overly heated from the ale consumed during the past hours of indulgence. It was not a pretty picture for Isabelle to watch.

To top it all off her younger cousin, by two years, had plagued her with questions all afternoon. Her latest being about her early morning rides along the royal cantor trail, which circled the grounds where the castle set.

She observed the good and the bad in clothing that the guests chose to adorn themselves with. The Lady Corinth seated to her right wore a ghastly collar and the Duke of Trove, seated directly across from her bore a multi-colored vest beneath a hideous overcoat. His straggly beard was none too clean, which caused her to completely lose her sparse appetite.

The kitchen had brought five different meats to each table. Wild quall was her favorite and there was trout from the bubbling spring the King’s fishermen had pulled out of the water. Hunts men brought squirrel and rabbit to the table and the turtle soup was a delicacy. The vegetables were raw and roasted as were the apples.

Isabelle was tired of smiling; all she wanted to do was to go to her room, but there was no hope of that, for at least another hour or two. The banquets were always so long; she dreaded every minute she had to stay, “You are a princess after all,” her mother always said.

Isabelle became very quiet as she dropped her napkin on her plate signifying the end of her meal. Queen Jasmine looked at her daughter and wondered if she was feeling alright. She spoke to her husband and then got up from her set and started toward Isabelle.

153.content:
Isabelle was frusterated at being pampered so, but the beautiful evening had cooled her temper. she breathed in contently. what a fine life it would be to live out here, away from the ridiculous politics and the perfumes of the palace! she was jolted from her thoughts by a deep voice behind her.
"My lady?"
Startled, Isabelle spun around to find a young man, only in his twenties, in long emerald robes and a black cape. he had warm, hazel eyes and his long golden hair was pulled back in a loose ponytail.
Isabelle frowned. "Never, ever call me 'your lady'again, Andrew." she snapped.
he smiled and leaned heavily on the oak staff with the emeralds and carvings of dragons. "And what is a humble traveller supposed to call the heir to the throne, my lady?"
"by her name." she answered, smiling in spite of herself. she always enjoyed his company, although his stiff, formal manner could be annoying.
"Fine," he answered. "But your father would kill me if he heard me call you that."
"Then don't call me 'your lady' in front of him," she replied lightly.
Andrew smiled, enjoying her rebelious attitude.
"We must get to the hall," he said, rubbing his leg. "Your mother has been worried sick about you!"

153.title: Andrew

1531.content:
"Alright then," Andrew said. "I shall tell you the story of the Princess and the Pea."

Isabelle slapped him. "Andrew! That's naughty!"

"Not that kind of pee," Andrew said. "The vegetable -- peas."

"Oh. I'm sorry I hit you then. But I would rather hear some other story."

"OK. Um... How about The Princess and the Dragon?"

"Noooo! Andrew! That's too scary! Do you know what dragons do to princesses?"

Andrew scratched his chin. "You mean in the story?"

"No! In real life! It's horrible, Andrew! Please tell me a different story."

"The Princess and the Fairy?"

"Mmmmm... OK, that sounds safe enough. There's no blood in it, is there?"

"No, no blood."

That night Princess Moslyn put on her walking boots and her traveling cape. She packed a bag of sandwiches and a bottle of lemonade and a change of underwear. 154.content:
Daniel didn't like telling Isabella to always be tidy, clean and proper. He appreciated the work in the stables, the chance, the freedom the reward of the work. He hoped his work would catch the attention of one of the knights, his care with their mount would draw a considerate word from someone.

However, he was on the opposite end of things from the princess. Beneath their notice. If he could get the princess to bring up that subject... just in passing, to one of the knights, he would grab that opportunity. With that thought in his head he hummed to himself as he groomed the horse. Smoothing it's coat, and clearing out any burrs and thorns.

A soft cough, startled him from his task. Turning he was startled to see Isabella had returned. But his eyes leapt to the wand held uncertainly in her hands. He recognised it as Gemmel, the court magicians. She stolen the damned thing, the tip already aglow was directed to the centre of his chest.

"You are my friend." Isabella said, "I need your help. This can work out for us both."

Raising his hands as if that could ward off magic, neither heard the sound of the brush hitting the cobbles, as the Princess' arms jabbed forward, and Daniel was wrapped in a cocoon of brilliant white light.

As the cocoon pulsed, it took on an emerald hue. Daniel saw gaps in the cocoon, as it started to slow it's whirling. Hints of emerald flashed across his vision, as glances of the princess appeared to him. Rather more importantly to him, was his whole body tingling from head to toe.

The tingling intensified, as the cocoon shattered, until his whole body itched, as if covered in scurrying ants. As his skin crawled he saw the tears in Isabella's eyes.

"Please,... I need an ally... a confidante..." her words barely more than a whisper.

Daniel wanted to promise her that he already was that to her... That he could be trusted with any secret, that he would do anything for her.

The tingling intensified, as Daniel's chest became warmer. A hint of green light rippling over his body, too late remembering that magic, Daniel looked down, in time to see his clothes transform. His simple stable-boy's outfit becoming a bodice... Moments later, his body shifting to make that suitable.

https://orig00.deviantart.net/f155/f/201...

As breasts burst free, bobbling into position, proudly displayed in a plain lady-in-waiting outfit. Simple but good enough for the royal court, and to not outshine his 'lady'. Daniel felt Isabella's eyes roam over her body. This time without the eagerness that he saw in her eyes, felt in his own quickening pulse. This time, it was more judgement, more as a comparison with her own figure.

"You'll be Lady Daniella..." she blurted, as she reached a hand out to the the still shocked Daniel.

1542.content:
As the light faded, Daniel blinked his eyes clear of tears. The dull colours of the stables, swam into focus. As Daniel took an experimental breath, deeper to calm himself.

It was only when he felt it contained, that a wave of strangeness swept over him. Hands searching for the constriction, found only satin, pressing firmly to discover a corset beneath. Hands rising higher to the top found breasts. Cupping them, mauling them to only discover himself gasping in shock. They were damned sensitive. Wiping the last of the blurriness from his eyes, Daniel looked down to see a well presented cleavage.

One he recognised, all too well. Though this was the first time seeing it from this angle. Looking over he saw his former body, standing with his hips cocked, and an amused smile on his face.

"You'll have to do a better job to pass as me." His voice sounding reedy and high, as he addressed, the newly-minted princess.

Similar thoughts were passing through her head, as she looked the newest stable-boy over. The pensive way he bit on his lower lip, the way he held his hands, the awkwardness in his stance. He couldn't have looked more disturbed to be male if he'd tried.

But he moved swiftly enough to pluck the wand from the princess' stunned grip. "I'll keep this for the moment. You have an embroidery session to attend to. I ... I have a note freeing me from work..."

He held up a piece of parchment, that she'd brought into the stables with her.

The clash of metal announced the approach of a guard, and the end of the conversation. As 'Daniel' busied himself with a brush, studiously avoiding eye contact with the looming guard.

From Isabella's perspective he reached up even higher than usual, towering over her even more than the stable boy.

"Lady Adira is waiting for you."
